content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												This game is honestly the best modern Fallout title to this day. It fixes almost everything that Bethesda flopped with in the original (DT is better than DR, the locales are pretty believable, dialogue checks are guaranteed with proper skills), and it just feels like what Fallout should have been with the transition. There's no level scaling, so there are some locations that are probably a bit too difficult until you reach a certain level, and it doesn't feel like an empty land to explore. There's vegetation and people trying to go about and make the world seem as if it's trying to repair itself 200+ years after The Great War rather than the DREARY POST APOCALYPTIC WASTELAND THAT STILL SOMEHOW HAD FOOD IN GROCERY STORES. Good character writing, quirky but not too far out there, and factions are well done. Karma system still sucks but is essentially irrelevant.Also, unlike FO3, there are actually 200+ endings in New Vegas. Just play this buggy mess instead of Fallout 3/4, because Bethesda needs to know that they suck at Fallout, and it's a shame that we might not see Obsidian take another jab at it. Remember to consent with Fisto.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
DIS GAME.Gameplay:I definitely love the gameplay. Roaming around the dry Mojave Desert day & night, slaughtering mutated creatures that were once normal, avoiding other tribes that will ruthlessly steal your damn clothing & supplies, murdering you is in the deal as well. Although V.A.Ts is a bit buggy, Example: You would use it & heaps of enemies would be around the area, it'd take afew minutes to actually lock onto the targets that are head of you. When you click one of the arrows to go right, it may go left, even though there is another enemy towards the right.Weapons:Holy♥♥♥♥♥/i> this game has heaps of weapons, actually reminds me of Borderlands/Borderlands 2, I know I know, this game came first, haha. Definitely your kind of FPS if you enjoy advanced technological weapons or old timey western guns! The concepts & designs are amazing for the futuristic weapons, my personal favorite is the "Q-35 Matter Modulator", the name is a cronky one, but how it looks is simply sexy & dangerous!Characters:Very unique character designs & clothing. However, as I stated, I loved the clothing, some of the clothing was completely Overused. I mean, I get it, it'd be pretty expensive to have every single character have different clothing! The ragged & digusting look of the raiders in this game is absolutely amazing! Originality blasting in this game, such as a car tire for a shoulder pad, haha.Voice Acting:Let's be honest, this game had so little voice actors. I didn't really mind it, but it kinda got old after awhile hearing the same voices over & over again! Some of the voice acting could use a little more work, such as the NCR soldiers & how almost every  civilian had the same dialogue.Soundtrack:Coming from a person who absolutely loves retro soundtracks & music, this game has to have my favorite OST! As for the ambience while you're roaming around or in battle, it's pretty intense & may get a bit creepy from time to time. The ambience really depends on your location & state, which is a pretty sexy addition to the game!Story:How I loved the story! It gives it a realistic vibe due to the fact you can literally slaughter important people.(Not that you should...) You have about 3 whole main choices in the game, Neutral, Bad, Good. Neutral being you forget about everyone else & fight for no one excluding a certain robot. Bad being you side with the Legion & plot for Vegas Domination. Good being you side with the NCR, New California Republic, taxes up the♥♥♥♥♥but that's what it will take to get the world back into natural order.Conclusion:Well, all I gotta say is you should really buy this game! I enjoyed it so much, I still play it! It'll give you endless hours of entertainment & fun, especially if you add in additional content, such as mods. Exclusive mods can be found at: http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/?10/10 ♥

Posted: June 5, 2015
												Ok, now that I'm waiting for Fallout 4 to come out, I guess I'm going to go back and visit the Mojave for a while.  The counter above the block where I'm writing this says I've played for 490.9 hours.  I might be willing to concede that such a thing is not necessarily healthy.Nevertheless:  if you consider yourself a gamer, and you haven't played this, you need to snap it up and find out what you've missed.  Some may wail about crashes:  cry me a river.  Save periodically.Yes, you may find some graphical oddities from time to time...but if you want richer stories, or more authentic post-apocalyptic atmosphere, you're probably going to have to wait until the real thing happens.  On the plus side, your wait might not be that long...so there's that.There are an endless supply of mods out there as well, so even after you've played through, you can still revisit and find new things.  Don't like the color of the post-atomic sky?  There's a mod for that.  Want real firearm textures? They got 'em.  Want to own your own casino?  You can fix up the one in Primm.If'n you don't, folks will be saying that 'Clint Eastwood' is the biggest yella-belly in the...whoops...wrong review.What are you still reading this for?  Step to!  And tell Victor I said "Howdy!"

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												A great rpg with a steady pace throughout the game. If you want a new generation fallout game that better represents the originals then this is the game, it follows a greater focus on character development and how you interact with the world; appreciating the fact that not everyone cares about pure run and gunning (you can still do that but there is a high chance of death involved). It may be a sudden change from the atmosphere of Fallout 3 now that they have somewhat of a more civilised stable society and its rather reminiscent of the wild west styled games but that only serves to continue the atmospheric development. If you can embrace actual adventure and actually role play then you are in for a treat of post apocalyptic wild west vibe. All I can say is give it a shot and don't try to compare it to Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												A game of limitless choices, possibilities, and complexity; something an RPG wants to be at its core. Fallout New Vegas is truly an 'epic' experiance, with a whole world of choices and options at the players fingertips, all of which is explorable and playable space. Want to be a space cowboy firing lazors and lever action rifles, sure. Want to be a swat trooper who bashes peoples knees in with a katana, you can easily do that. The game just has a lot of things to do.These choices, compound into its ultimate game strength; the sheer amount of content there is. The game has a massive world, with easily 110+ quests, and probably even more unmarked quests. As well, the vast arsenal of weapons, the variety, and the balencing the game has in regards to these are phenoninal. Any playstyle is viable in this game, and it is an experiance where everyone can flourish. The game is perfecly paced as well, meaning that at no point are you this indestructable God of death, you are fragile, you are not the best, you are mortal. The game teaches you that very well, that you are human, nothing more. You live in this shattered world, dealing with your own human nature; whether it be the mortality, the drugs, sex, disease, or just plain stupidity. But despite the games humanity, it falls into one major trap. That is, the game encourages metagaming at its finest. For instance, to get the best stuff/ending/quests, you need to know how/when to do things. This can be argued in the whole nature of the complex choice system as well, but because of the no turn back attitude of the game, it highly encourages veterans to play the game rather synthetically, rather than let it all flow together as it may. Yes, this does mean replayability, but its not as fun as a purely organic gaming experiance.Despite the main criticisms of the game, and other factors I chose not to mention (for length restraints), the game is not bad. On the contrary, its quite good, very good. Why is it good? Because it emplifies its core concept excellently: Humanity, and what it means to be human. That focus in what its about, makes it a must own.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												This game has the potential to be so much more. Anyone who has ever visited Nexusmods and seen the library of content created as an addition to New Vegas, can attest to the potential of this game. Bethesda, off the heels of success with Fallout 3, in my opinion rushed New Vegas and released it before it was stable. Non-modded, Vanilla versions of New Vegas with and without DLC, are prone to random crashing. Now, even with that most annoying of pet peeves for all gamers, New Vegas is another post-apocalyptic, immersive sandbox, Taking place in the Mojave wasteland, and with the DLC content, surrounding areas. Instead of playing the intrepid vault dweller, you are a courier for the Mojave Express, who is gunned down. You must uncover the reason behind your attempted murder, find your stolen package, and unravel the mysteries within. The Brotherhood of Steel makes a brief appearance, but does not play the central role of law and order, the way they did in Fallout 3. Now we are introduced to the government and military of The New California Republic, as well as the despotic and sadistic masses known as Caesar's Legion. Fallout New Vegas is a game that must be played with all available DLC, for the full experience. Despite all the flaws, there are hotfixes, such as official game patches and player created Mods, to combat game crashing. If you enjoyed Fallout 3, you will love New Vegas.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Yet another phenomenal addition to the Fallout IP. Fallout: New Vegas touches on many of the original concepts and mechanics of its predecessor but also improved on them. The amount of content in New Vegas and its ability to immerse you into its lore is astounding. How you shape yourself in New Vegas is virtually limitless, almost every choice to be made has several alternate paths that affect your experience greatly. Leveling in New Vegas feels more rewarding and desired than most games, sculpting your skills and traits are perfectly done here. In combat your options are huge, ranging anything from fists to laser rifles to mini-nukes. With the addition of Steam Workshop, your options and the amount of content really do become limitless.Fallout: New Vegas truly peers on top amongst the greatest in the genra. If you are a fan, you won't be disappointed. If you're new here but love immersive open-world RPG's and have an interested for post-apocalyptic scenarios, you're in for quite a ride. 94/100

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												I was writing a huge review, but I'll summarize it with one of the game's own quotes. While tacky, it perfectly describes my initial approach to the game, and modern videogaming as a whole."There is an expression in the Wasteland: 'old world blues.' It refers to those so obsessed with the past that they can't see the present, much less the future, for what it is." New Vegas is as close as you're gonna get to a contemporary update on the 17 year old fallout 2. And would you know it, they even had the decency to update and modernize the crashes, bugs, and glitches, so the new audience wouldn't miss out on such a crucial element of fallout gameplay.A masterful blend of old, new, and yesterday's news, that even in 2015 sees mods, fan content, and updates. More importantly, it's got heart, and while the base game shows some obvious signs of being rushed, the huge DLCs and fan patches take care of that.Above all, the game prioritizes player agency, and not the cute 'kill the guy, spare the guy' kind that's thrown around as a buzzword.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I really can not recommend this game enough. Easily one of the best RPG's ever made thus far. I may get some hate for this, but in my opinion, Fallout New Vegas has out done Fallout 3 in nearly every regard. The story is pretty great. It can be slow at times, but when you make decisions, they feel like they actually matter. The setting is something many people used to praise Fallout 3 for, including myself, and it is no doubt one of the best game settings ever, but after several play throughs of New Vegas, I feel the Mojave has that extra bit of charm that the DC wasteland didnt have. Some disliked the Mojaves bright skie's and bright City for a post apocalyptic game, but for me it just felt very right. The writing for some of the Side Quests in this game, is truly phenominal, and I hope Obsidian gets another shot at a Fallout game once Fallout 4 is out. Overall Fallout New vegas, and the Fallout franchise as a whole is a master piece, with rich and interesting Lore, great characters, excellent gameplay, and HOURS of replayability. Expect 100+ hours per playthrough, and even then you'll still have not done everything. My playtime on steam for this is only about 128 hours as of 2/14/16, but when I used to play this on console, id say my time on it is around 600+.**EDIT: Having now played Fallout 4 and its overly simplified rpg elements, i've come to appreciate this game even more than when i originally wrote this. Here is a summed up list of the Pro's and Con's of Fallout: New VegasPRO's-Amazing and vast, variety of weapons.-Interesting and Fun characters.-Extensive character customization.-Great leveling system with awesome Perks.-Excellent setting.-Good story, and great variety of story paths and Choice's.-V.A.T.S-The Pip Boy 3 thousand, Enough said.-DLC's add a good amount of content for your character to take back to the Mojave. The way the DLC story lines tie in with the main games narrative is ♥♥♥♥ing excellent, making this games DLC some of the best i've ever played.-Very well optimized for the PC. Runs better on my fairly average computer than it did on my Xbox 360.CON'S-Occasional crashes, not as big a deal as people make it out to be. You should be fine unless your trying to run this on an Etch A Sketch or a Potato.-Sometime's a glitch will interfere with a quest or you might get stuck in a ledge. This is also Very occasional and not a real problem at all.If you dont already own Fallout New Vegas, why are you still reading this, go buy it. NOW!.10/10, Would herd Wind Brahmin Again.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Despite what Hideo Kojima would tell you, war never changes.Fallout New Vegas returns the Fallout series to it's west coast roots, sort of. While little of the action actually takes place in The New California Republic, the state DOES play a heavy role in the title. The player embarks on a quest of mythical proportions starting as a simple courier caught up as a pawn in the affiars of dicatators, emperors, and corrupt senators, and offers satisfaction to any who step into the wastes, in several ways. One can endavor make the post apocalyptic, post divergent hell (as opposed to pre-apocalyptic, pre-divergent hell, or even conteporary hell) a slightly better place through feats of heroism. Alternatively one can take out their aggression at the powers that be by establishing new orders under nefarious leaders of varying degrees of nefariousaritynessnessism (sp?). Or one can simply say "screw the rules, I have ______" where ______ is "money" or "all manner of fictional designer drugs and booze" or "a collection of exotic guns that would raise Heston from his grave" or "300,000 piles of scrap metal, duct tape, a radioactive toy rocket, and some bubble gum!" The morality system is still in place, and the game can be heavy handed with this, though in addition to "break stuff steal things, versus fix stuff, save idiots" are a series of factional based fame meters. Remember how back in high school, you accidentally peed your pants in the cafeteria? Well instead of immediately gaining the same amount of infamy among all the cliques, the art kids, and tweakers thought it was kinda cool, in an ironic way. Same thing goes in FO:NV. Blowing the facial bones out of a random scumbag with a kids BB gun, maxed skills, and the "Bloody Mess" perk may toque off half the factions, but it may just earn your a little bit of positive feedback from other groups - maybe that guy pooped in their Sugar Bombs. Added to this iteration of Fallout is also increased crafting as a mechanic. One can skill up abilities in making medical and food aid items, which come in handy if one plays the real game (hardcore mode) and not just "Cousin Timmy's, I'm Too Frail to do Even Live Hard in a Simulated Reality Weekend Adventure" (regular mode). Hardcore mode requires the player to consume food and water, as well as sleep regularly or risk stat debuffs or even death. And healing items take longer too work, along with stat buff items risking negative side effects like addiction, far more frequently than in Cousin Timmy's experience. All said, FO:NV is what Fallout Fans were hoping for from FO3, Fallout franchise based setting, more guns, more items, huge map, hours of gameplay and sidequests, but still with all the bugs one can expect from Bugthesda, though you shouldn't complain - If you're reading this, you're in the PC mustard race, and therefore console is always a tilde away, and through tilde, all problems can be solved. Some may not enjoy single player only, but this is the apocalypse. All your friends are dead. JK, you never had any friends, that's what the charming classical radio tracks are for.. All in all, one of my personal favorite.Final score: 875/1000 RadsProtip: Generally speaking, honest heats will tell you the DLC was lackluster, however, while it was a lonesome road to get to this point, for the current going price, I'd say all are worth the dead money. I'd have something clever to say about Old World Blues, too, but out of all the DLC it was the only one worth the initial cost, as it was clever enough on it's own, and is this reviewer's personal pick.

												The current game in the Fallout Franchise, New Vegas awaits, to entertain, to corrupt, or just to provide you with those home comforts, like that 12gauge you just never get tired of pumpin'. Gun firing a bit crap? Go upgrade it at the Gun shop by trading all that crap you found lying around, for that shiny new recoil compensator for your 5.56mm Marksman Carbine!! This game is an excellent RPG/shooter hybrid. I personally love the V.A.T.S combat system, allowing you to momentarily step out of real time to select those body parts that you think will look better being severed from that body, you don't know why, but you just wanna see the guy's head explode ha ha ha! Hrm...who's that over there, hey! It's a companion, make friends, get them to carry all your stuff, on first name terms already? Great, Why not give them a gun and some ammo too and you can double team those mutated Wasteland horrors like they were the best days of your life! (well they were for me mmkay..)  Choose wisely on the course of action to take when encountering strangers, or just  generally♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the army. Not sure about that creepy looking character you met in that strange bunker? Hrm...do his bidding? Or betray him, up to you! Run off with the loot or give it to the homeless people for street cred, the reputation is yours for the making as everyone you interact with has the potential to aid you, or slow you down (cos you spent waaay too much time zooming in on her ti-♥♥♥♥♥♥.) After over 200 hours of playing this game, I'm lightyears away from getting bored of this Titan, I aint never growing up !!! 8/10. There's room for improvment..but that's what sequels are for, fool! Load up and get your kit, it's gonna be a long walk and your gonna need to get your game on out in the Wasteland..some of the critters out there just get real mad if you shoot them! Good luck! Oh..and try not to die!

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I recently played a game titled, Fallout: New Vegas, it was developed by Obsidian Studios, which many of the company’s members happen to be former members of Interplay Productions’ Black Isle Studios, the ones who brought you Fallout 1, Fallout 2, Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel, and Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel. The game was published by Bethesda Softworks, the Makers of Fallout 3, as well as one of my other favorite game series, The Elder Scrolls.The game takes place in The Mojave Wasteland, which is the Post Apocalyptic version of the areas of Nevada, California, and Arizona. The game follows a The Courier who has a package delivery go wrong, as you find out at the very start of the game. This is one of the few games that I recommend watching the intro all the way through on, as the intro is very well done, in fact I enjoyed watching it my first playthrough, and then after I had played the game through several times, after which I noticed many different things that you would only notice after having played the game in depth. The game is played in 1st/3rd person perspective, and the player interacts with the world and with items using a GUI called a Pipboy 3000, which can be upgraded to the Pimpboy 3 Billion (Which is a gold plated version of the Pipboy 3000.) after completing a certain quest. The game has a nicely done crafting system for creating items for the player to use/sell. You can make items from a few different hotspots, those would be, a fireplace or hot plate, a workbench as well as a repair bench. This game unlike so many of its kind, actually has a nonlinear questline, which basically means you can chose who you would like to side with, as well as how you want to handle a situation in most cases. The games main factions that you can side with during the main questline are Caesar’s Legion, Mr. House, the New California Republic (NCR), and for an independent New Vegas, you can side with a overly friendly and forthcoming robot named Yes Man. Caesar’s Legion is led by no other than Caesar, aka Edward Sallow, Caesar co-founded his legion with a man known as Joshua Graham, whos name is not to be spoken within The Legion without punishment. Mr. House or Robert House, founder of RobCo Industries, is a man who spent the latter years of his Pre-War life, planning for how to keep himself alive indefinitely, and protect the Vegas Strip from nuclear attacks.The New California Republic is a fairly large democratic federation that is the absolute enemy of Caesar’s Legion.The music choices in Fallout: New Vegas are fantastic, it perfectly fits in with the early 1900’s feel of the game and while a few may disagree the music itself is very good, with selections of the greats of the 1940s and 1950s with genres including classical and jazz. I feel like this revived a great period of time for music, so that new generations could enjoy it for themselves. This game is amazing and I would recommend it as a must play for gamers everywhere.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas is the next entry to the critically acclaimed Fallout series. Taking place 3 years after Fallout 3, you find yourself tied up, and being shot in the head by Chandler Bing. New Vegas was made and produced by Obsidian Entertainment and published by Bethesda, unlike Fallout 3 which was produced and published by only Bethesda. Fallout: New Vegas has some improved gameplay elements from Fallout 3, like the ability to aim down sights, a new reputation system, and a better companion menu. The story is well written, with a lot of star power voicing the characters, and a story that has 3 or 4 branching endings. Like the game that came before it, it is also an open world game.PROS+ Improved Gameplay elements from Fallout 3+ Open world, with many more quests than the previous entry+ More weapons and enemies+ Great voice acting+ Returns to Fallout's dark sense of humour that Fallout 3 more or less lacked+ Includes a "Wild Wasteland" perk that adds tons of easter eggs, and is in my opinion, the only perk worth getting at the start+ Large map with many interesting cities+ Big city near the top of the map, New Vegas, that includes casinos, and hotels. New Vegas also has a ghetto north of the city, that has more than a few quests to enjoy+ A new reputation system that effects how factions (and their enemies/allies) will treat you+ Great radio soundtrack+ Amazingly written, interconnected DLC storylines+ Amazing DLC environmentsCONS- Sparse towns make the map seem too big at times, and can be a pain to walk around- Very little change in landscape- Radio soundtrack can be very repetitive- Companions can be hard to locate, and are sometimes overlooked. - Main quest is very short, and can take only about 4 hours to complete- Armor can be hard to find and acquire without the Courier's Stash DLC- A few bugs and problems here and there.Overall, a great game with a story that (in my opinion) is better that the one of Fallout 3. Buy the Ultimate Edition when it's on sale.9.5/10

												This game is one word, "amazing". I purchased it on Xbox on release day then on PC in summer 2013. This game gives you so many choices to choose from, you pretty much have four storylines to go with. There are tons of quests in the game that are actually really fun to complete, I liked them a lot more than in Fallout 3. The storyline is amazing, something I felt lacked in Fallout 3, New Vegas really makes you feel like you have a goal to accomplish. The combat system is highly improved from Fallout 3. The only thing I criticize the game about is the empty spaces, there are a lot of them but then again it is a desert after all. This is one of my favorite games of all time, and I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to get into the Fallout series. I give the game a 9/10.

												Frankly, I'm astounded by how good New Vegas is. It brought back the true Fallout feel, especially the clever and witty humor. On top of that, it completely overhauled everything that Fallout 3 had, producing mechanics that actually work rather well, a world that gives you incentive to explore and reward for doing it, a great deal of solid difficulty, much improved combat, and a TON more role-playing ability. The only problems are that the story is somewhat weak and it has a MASSIVE amount of technical issues. Still, this is what Fallout 3 should have been.

Fallout New Vegas is one of the best games I've ever played, hands down.

												Personal Rating: Not a bad game - I expected moreClassic Rating: ★★★☆☆New Vegas doesn't add too much to what we saw in Fallout 3, in my opinion: there are companions, enhanced crafting (which is pretty useless anyway), maybe more weapons and mods but it's the same old game - I can't tell one true change in game play or UI.Main story falls short in comparison to FO3: NV it's mostly made of side quests - some of which very interesting, I have to admit - but all the Courier's story starts and ends in a flutter (not going to spoil).● I loved FO3 dark setting, I liked New Vegas.● I loved FO3 story, I liked New Vegas.● I had some crashes in FO3, I had many more in New Vegas.● I don't remember any particular bug in FO3, I found a lot in New Vegas - from mid game to end I had to open the wiki almost every time I played.● I had to fast travel very often in NV because of silly quest while I spent more time actually playing in FO3.● Factions implementation is not good in New Vegas, in my opinion: if you don't pay attention to what armor you wear, your playthrough can get f****d up.As you can see, there's a lot of things I didn't like, BUT I cannot say New Vegas is a bad game; I can just tell to whoever is still doubtful about choosing Fallout 3 or New Vegas, go with the former, you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												I used to think no game could come close to how good Fallout 3 was but all my friends would say to me "You bought Fallout: New Vegas collector's edition on launch day! Why haven't you played it yet?! It's so much better than Fallout 3" and how right they are.Fallout: New Vegas is a First-Person Shooter / Role-Playing Game / Survival Horror game developed by Obsidian Entertainment and is set in a post-apocalyptic western United States, an area largely untouched by the events of the great nuclear war of 2077. You are a Courier, delivering messages around the wasteland and have been assigned to deliver a package containing something very special. Unfortunately, you are captured, package stolen, and left for dead in the wasteland. What happens next will eventually determine the fate of the thousands inhabiting the Mojave desert for years to come.The huge open-world of Fallout: New Vegas is well constructed and very atmospheric. I found however, that it feels slightly less interesting than Fallout 3. In Fallout 3 you would worry all the time about what is around the next corner. In New Vegas, the landscape, at first, looks fairly flat and uninteresting. Is this a fault of the game or is it to be praised for being authentic to the area in which it is set? I have friends that have visited Las Vegas and they tell me "Yes, the area around Las Vegas is pretty much how it looks in the game".Which ever way you look at it, you'll get lost in the atmosphere in no time. The ambience and music gives the game a great western vibe as well at the nicely crafted musical score (which also includes tracks from Fallout 1 and 2 for added nostalgia)The world is also not immediately open to the player. Going North is pure suicide early on in the game so the player is encouraged to explore the south before venturing north. By closing off certain areas to the player early on, I found that it really helps to emphasize just how much of a dangerous place the Mojave wasteland really is and it increased my wanting to explore those areas later once I got some better gear.The plot in Fallout: New Vegas however is a lot more open and is better written than Fallout 3. Right up until the very end of the game, you have total freedom to choose your own path in the world. The story also doesn't take itself as seriously as Fallout 3 does; the characters you meet, situations you are put in and overall tone of the game is lighter, funnier and doesn't centre around one specific key character. You have a world, an event is happening in that world, get going and help shape what happens!The game mechanics are deep, very very deep. There are almost System Shock 2 levels of complexity in this game; It keeps pretty much all of Fallout 3's FPS/RPG elements and statistical goodness everyone has come to expect from a Fallout game but also re-introduces mechanics from Fallout 1 and 2 back into the mix. Damage Threshold and Damage Resistance are back and really well implemented into the combat. I learnt pretty quickly that it is futile to chip away at a creature's thick hide or somebody's metal armour with a 9mm pistol, you're going to need the right gun for the right situation which means thinking on your feet. Guns can also degrade in quality over time and depending on what ammo you use which means keeping your gear in top condition is very important.The game also allows you to create your own food and ammunition. Different types of ammo will require different components you can get from either de-constructing existing ammo or finding them in the Mojave and will affect different opponents in different ways; Use 12 Gauge, Slug rounds to pierce through Armour or use 12 Gauge, Dragon's Breath rounds to set squishy things on fire!The game introduces an optional 'Hardcore mode' which, amongst other things, requires you to eat, drink and sleep in order to stay alive. Ammunition has weight to it and getting health from Stimpaks occurs over time. It will drastically change the way you think about approaching situations and provide you with a more survival horror type experience.Not only all this but your actions will affect people's opinions of you. Do good things and people in that region, town or faction will like you and will come to your aid in times of need. Do bad things and expect to be hated, shot at and have general abuse hurled at you.I've only scratched the surface of what the game can do here but now it's time to talk about the Downloadable Content that the game contains. There are four packs and they all differ widely in settings and theme but they all tie together cleverly to create one big story to play through:Dead Money DLC - Holy crap this is one atmospheric ride! You are sent to uncover the secrets of the Sierra Madre and I can't say much more as anything else would be a spoiler. This is probably the creepiest DLC out of the four, It's bursting with places to explore and things to find. Anyone who finds that a lot of Fallout: New Vegas feels quite empty and void of small detail in a lot of places will have nothing to complain about here. Great characters and very nicely paced with amazing atmosphere.Honest Hearts DLC - You are hired to travel with the Happy Trails caravan to Utah's Zion National Park. This is the first of the DLCs to give the player an open world to explore. The world is, once again, very nicely crafted with real attention to detail but unfortunately it suffers from being quite boring story-wise. It's nice to meet characters that aren't your average wasteland survivors though but sadly, most are largely forgettable and the story can go out with either a small pop or a whimper depending on what you want to do.Old World Blues DLC - This is probably the funniest and most bizarre DLC made for New Vegas. It was even nominated for a 'Best DLC' award! This is a real turn around from Honest Hearts; hilarious from start to finish, incredibly well written story and characters, a new huge open area to explore, perfect pacing and the DLC will prove a real challenge for players of all skills. Absolutely worth playing and taking your time with.Lonesome Road DLC - The final DLC and it is something quite special. This is really worth playing if, like me, you disliked the game giving you a character that was both a blank slate and had some kind of past that was a complete mystery. This will definitely fill in some of those blanks and make the Courier more interesting. It's a return to a linear world like Operation Anchorage but it is so full of more interesting places to see and things to do. You will find yourself backtracking to either find all the hidden secrets or opening up new areas but a lot of the time, it's worth doing. There are cool set-pieces (which is a must for this kind of DLC) and what happens to you (and/or others) at the end is amazingly good. A great end to an impressive series of DLC.With all of the praise I've given the game, it has its faults. Bugs mainly. There are a few hanging around and whilst they aren't game-breaking, they can range from floating objects to random crashing to desktop. Another issue depends on your point of view, the game falls into the same trap Fallout 3 fell into by letting the player level up too much and becoming too powerful making most of the RPG elements like speech-checks largely pointless. An RPG isn't an RPG any more when you're good at everything!I'm already planning my next play through of Fallout: New Vegas and after playing it, it makes Fallout 3 a very hard game to go back to. Fallout: New Vegas is just an all-round better game, despite it's small flaws and if you enjoyed Fallout 3, I urge you get your hands on this as soon as possible! Hundreds of hours of enjoyment guaranteed!Recommended Mods:JSawyer and Mission Mojave. Use these to make your game a better RPG and fix over 27,000 in-game bugs.

												I haven't met any bug until now (44 hrs), and wiki is very detailed so i think bug wont be a problem.whenever i play a open-world rpg i always wonder that can every door be opened? Can every npc tell his own story?But when i play NV, I never have that thought. There are far too many stories, far too many quests and far too many choices I had to make. And what makes me more exciting is ALL THOSE CHOICES MATTER. I'm not some kind of puppet just follow those shining points on the map and kill everybody whose name is red. I'm a man in this world, and what I do, how I do, when I do all will change the further situation, not to mention if I'm a true imbecile with rather low intelligence and speech ability, I will be really funny to look at XD. NV is a garden of forking paths, that is exactly the experience I'm expecting in an open-world RPG. Open-world is about BOTH open and world. Bethesda, please give Obsidian another shot for a new fallout. Please leave fallouts to Obsidian and make great skyrims. Your skyrims are fabulous.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												I have a good 250+ hours worth of play of Fallout:New Vegas, and I have to say that it is one of my favourite games, ever.Obsidian have always been great with RPGs, but as my first experience of the Fallout franchise, this remains to be one of my favourites.I have explored every possible element, looted every corpse, cabinet and dead Brahmin that I could find; there is SO much content, and with 3 DLCs, you have plenty to work with.Some of the voice acting gets a little...groovy within dialogue, corpses fly to the ceiling with V.A.Ts shots, rescuing followers from behind boulders becomes a frequent chore, and if I have to listen to one more run of Johnny Guitar, I may scream...but a solid 10/10 overall from me.In short; if you enjoyed Skyrim, give this a try. For a lover of stories, I would say this still holds a lot of weight despite the new game now launched (just don't expect the graphics to be on-par.)Guns rather than pew-pew magic.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												This review was requested by a bunch of my friends!Fallout: New Vegas is Obsidian's attempt at recreating the Fallout games after Bethesda's attempt at Fallout 3 (And I thought they failed at that attempt) but this time, I think Obsidian was successful.The visuals are mediocre at the most, but there are a few times in-game where the graphics look great. The faces for the NPCs and even yourself seem awful. Plus, the big con above the mediocre visuals is that the atmosphere, where Fallout was dark, scary like the previous entries (Yes, even 3) seemed to bright. The enemies didn't seem terrifying thanks and I couldn't fully enjoy a real Fallout experience. The gameplay is smooth, and I enjoy using VATS (The more tactical approach to the gunplay) and people who don't like the full-out shooters that don't require thinking will enjoy it too. However, I can't put that as a con due to Fallout 3 having this too, so why should I? But like I said, the gameplay is smooth. The shooting is simple and the melee too, but the explosives and such can be a bit useless. However, the hardcore survival experience is highly enjoyable and makes up for the useless explosives. The gameplay does not disappoint.The story is pretty solid, and also if I'm not mistaken, Fallout: New Vegas actually holds the record for the most lines of dialogue in the game. Why am I saying that? It's a major pro for some and a major con for others. Because I enjoy strong storylines, it's a pro for me. If you like "Get to the point" NPCs, be wary that you won't find that in Fallout. Benny (The checkered suit guy) is a solid villain who legitimately tricks you at one point in the game and is able to smoothtalk you into nearly killing you. Correct me if I'm wrong here, but I can think of only a few antagonists who successfully manipulated the character with ease, Benny among them. The con to the story though is the fact that the game ENDS, meaning you can't play anymore, after you do the main storyline. The story is great, just be wary of the fact that the game ENDS.The audio is very impressive. The voice actors have more personality than your average Call of Duty, Halo, and whatnot. Plus, I enjoyed the songs that played on the radios and just made me think of the new Guardians of the Galaxy movie. Fallout: New Vegas and GotG both have something in common: Despite the fact that it takes place in modern/future time, the primary soundtrack uses songs from the 50's-80's. It's good to see a game like Fallout (3 too) not use your average dubstep/epic orchestral music for a soundtrack. You will definitely enjoy the audio from this game. The sound effects, the voice actors, everything.I'm a one-and-done kind of guy for replayability, this game included. However, I've seen people get hundreds and hundreds of hours in this game. The replayability, much like its cousin (or brother, or sister) Elder Scrolls have high replayability. After you beat the game, you can create another character, and then another character, and another character! The replayability is some of the strongest in the whole series.In the end, Fallout: New Vegas is nowhere near my favorite RPG, but it's still an amazing experience. I didn't really enjoy the experience as others did, but if you get this game, you will probably side with them, so I recommend this game for any RPG fan.Graphics- 4.5/10Gameplay- 8/10Story- 8/10Audio- 9.5/10Replayability- 9.5/10.:8.0/10:.+High replayability+Amazing hardcore mode+Outstanding performances by the voice actors+Clever antagonist-The game ENDS for real-Awful graphics-Explosives are useless-Bright atmosphere

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Whether or not you will like Fallout New Vegas will most likely depend on your personal preference. For example, it depends on whether you prefer the blade or guns. After playing Oblivion and Skyrim, I tried this game and was both pleased and turned off. The cool stuff:I got a mod that imported Star Wars droids into the game, and they are awesome.The costumes can make your character look awesome!There is a jetpack mod......http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/37140/?The main city of New Vegas is pretty nice, and Freeside is fun to explore. The Liberty Loft is the house to get there.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/41822/?In addition, it is easy to be a total bada** in the game, which is pretty fun.The guns are also diverse and fun, the gunplay is solid. There are also throwable weapons (which Skyrim should have).The soundtrack is good.The uncool:Oblivion and Skyrim spoiled me with beautiful worlds and exciting combat, so I expected a world ripe for exploration and screenshots. However, while it may be great for exploration, its sheer ugliness completely turned me off. On top of that, deadly monsters roam the bleak landscape and serve as bullet sponges, so I ended up being content staying in the City.The NPCs seem fake and are not interesting (if that makes sense).There are some annoying mechanics such as dehydration and radiation. It is fun sometimes and annoying as all heck other times. There are great ENBs, but the game looks bad without them. I now know that I much prefer Elder Scrolls over Fallout. Although Fallout has its perks, I will always rather invest my time in Oblivion and Skyrim's gorgeous worlds, spells, potions, sword combat, and quests. New Vegas' ugly and unrewarding world, unfortunately, dampened my excitement to do a serious playthrough.But: Do not let this deter you. Try it out for yourself and see if you like the elements this game has that other games do not. Plus, check out the Nexus Mods. There are some pretty cool ones there!

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2013
												This is an amazing addition to the series, highly underrated. Has to be one of the best RPGs to date.I highly recommend getting the Ultimate Edition to enjoy the brilliant DLCs, the game is much more complete with them.Game-play is as amazing as ever, pretty much following the same game-play as Fallout 3 with a few improvements here and there. Strangely they decided to add an iron-sights mode when shooting, which would be fine, but seeing as this game doesn’t have the best graphics, it can sometimes feel like your aiming down a brick. This can be easily corrected by disabling it and going back to Fallout 3’s zoom, however. All the guns feel great, all with a specific purpose and good against certain enemies, there is a great deal more strategy to the gun-play than with Fallout 3, with many more available stats, weapon mods and weapons which are useful in particular situations. This game also introduces hard-core mode, where the game is set to the hardest difficulty (very hard) and forces you to eat, sleep and drink on a regular basis in order to survive. This mode tends to start extremely hard, with endless treks searching for water or supplies and provides a hefty challenge for experienced players, but once you’ve played this game to death, you’ll have enough supplies to not really have to worry about impending starvation any longer.I could go into much more detail on game-play but many of my points would also apply to Fallout 3, which if you haven’t played, I recommend doing so before getting this.As far as visuals and soundtrack go they are beyond exquisite, with a great mix of a western style Mojave theme and the classic 1950s twist that was evident in earlier games.The story is excellent, following your life after being shot in the head. The game has over 62,000 lines of dialogue, holding the Guinness World Record for the most dialogue ever produced for a video game. It also has has some of the best written characters I’ve ever seen in gaming, most of them appearing the DLCs. The actually story, well, that’s up to you. Do what you want; don’t do what you don’t want to do. This is the definition of strong story-telling in a truly free game world.Where the game has many of its problems is in mechanics. Perhaps it was rushed out, thanks to Bethesda only giving Obsidian 18 months to make the game. Very small aspects of the game do sometimes feel unfinished, or the remnants of an idea that was originally in the game are left lying around. There can also be a number of pesky bugs, most of which can be fixed by a few easily installed community mods.What truly should sell you on this game is the endless supply of amazing mods on the Nexus. These mods with the game and DLCs combined will give you endless hours of fun.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												The Fallout series is one of the most acclaimed that has also a retro-futuristic touch that charms you when you see it for first time until you finish the game. New Vegas is no stranger to it's predecesors.The player visits the city of New Vegas and it's Mojave desert that are just ruined by the radioactivity and the different factions that are in war. You, most known as the Courier, were hired to deliver an unknown package from the Mojave to the New Vegas Strip but you were intercepted, shot in the head, and left for dead by an also unknown man who steals it.Afterwards, you are found and healed by a local doctor and then, your story begins. No complains on the writting department from me.Being an Open World Action Role playing game gave Bethesda give the gamers so many things to do in the map: from following the main story, or just not and complete side quests; or from being an explorer of the wasteland to wander just in populated places. This game gives you freedom to choose what do you want to do in it and how do you want to develop your     story and character (as you have speech,lockpicking and multiple skills to upgrade by playing). This game even lets you choose how you want to end it as you choose your side in the faction crisis (NCR,Caesar's Legion, Mr House... or none)shown through all of the story. This is what keeps the player so connected to the game: the freedom of playing as you want.The gameplay is  similar from Fallout 3: the Pipboy is back with all it's previous options modified a bit to fit in this game (radio included, lol), the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System or V.A.T.S for the specific aiming of a limb and the real time effects of it (brilliant), the karma and your reputation (good or bad, your choice), companions, weapons modding and the adding of the Gambling (cheating is included) are the most unique things of the series and of course, it's signature. Even the new players can blend in without any problem.Fallout: New Vegas is one hell of a game and will not steal minutes from your life because you will enjoy every second of it.You won't regret the experience.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Ah, Fallout. My first true RPG, and one true love. Full disclosure, I prefer 3 to NV, but it's almost solely because of the radio personalities; Mr. New Vegas is just kind of...blah. Luckily, there's an all-music station, and the in-game sound track is pretty damn good, too.So, hey, the actual game. For starters, super-fun story. I've always been a sucker for games that have you caught between large warring factions. New Vegas has three of them. Not two. ♥♥♥♥en three. AND, you can say to hell with all of them and throw in with the faction of Me, Baby, taking the riches of New Vegas for yourself. But whatever choices you make, they're all apparent during the final battle, which somehow manages to put Liberty Prime's curb-stomping rampage to shame.The world is beautiful and makes me wish I had a better graphics card. The vaults in particular are very well-written. I still get a feeling of dread whenever I crawl through Vault 34, and Vault 22 is supremely fun with fire-based weapons. The world is solidified by the fact that, unlike in F3, there are a number of large, well-established settlements, with whom you can gain or lose reputation as you and your shooting sprees see fit. The terrain itself is varried, from sprawling dessert to rocky cavern to lush forest to snow-sprinkled mountain, all within about a day's run of each other.Mechanics are glitchy but good as always. Love the condensation of Small Guns and Big Guns into just Guns, and the addition of Survival. I actually wrote my own physical copy of The Wasteland Survival Guide with all crafting recipes in it, just so I could better manage my inventory and decide what crap I could sell safely. I can't mod weapons to save my life, but based on the public achievement stats, I think I'm the only one with this issue. Doesn't bug me much, as there are enough unique weapons in-game to make moding almost pointless. I am, however, a huge fan of the new ammo types; armor-piercing rounds making it so much easier to kill higher-level enemies, and coin shot gives you something to do with all that worthless Legion money you're going to collect.Buy this game, Ultimate Edition. Everyone talks up Lonesome Road, and while enjoyable (partly because it gives you access to the best companion in the game), it's one of the slowest points in the game - and filled with Deahclaws. Old World Blues is hilarious and gives you invaluable resources, Honest Hearts is beautiful in its simplicity, and Dead Money...well, Sierra Madre Martinis make Tin Cans worth something, and there's some good loot towards the end that does help your midgame. God damn, just writing this review makes me want to play again!

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Ya know after putting a lot of thought into I can honestly say Fallout 4 is a great shooter and builder game, of course others do it better but beside that it's good at its one thing.The down side is, this ancient title that was dug up from the tombs of Bethesda way back in the fantastic year 2012 still somehow managed to be a better game. Which is upsetting to me in a lot of ways, but this game is truly a fantastic RPG in almost every regard of the word. It's not a simple Yes simulator like Fallout 4 is. I feel connected to my character in this game, I feel like I can really play someone give them a backstory, a life and a reason to keep pushing through the mutant rampant lands that we call the Mohave. Is it perfect gameplay? No. But mods fix that. And moding is 100% free (as long as you aren’t playing on a toaster). The melee system is clunky no matter what, the gun play is fun and you can mod weapons, it's very limited yes. But it's not overwhelming and you don’t have to lug around the entirety of a hoarders belongings in order to make sure you can upgrade your pipe pistol from the start of the game to still be relevant. I love this game, I played it for hours back when I still had a functional PS3 and I'm probably going to play it for way more then what I have right now. Get this game, it's the best Wasteland survival RPG on the market.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												A few years ago, Bethesda said "I'm going to make Fallout games" everyone waited the new fallout game with curiosity anxiety and hope. some people liked it some people didn't, but whatever happened, everyone sat and played at least once. As far as novelty is concerned, it adds a beauty and new excitement to everything in life unless it is overstated. So while the old Fallout is a classic, this new version is becoming another classic in its own style and taste.First of all, the story of New Vegas is completely different from the story of the third game. At the outset, now the serade is classicized, "I turned into a fish out of the Vault" does not apply to this game. This is not an old Vault member, we are a wasteland person. It's a little more than we've been through.Fallout: New Vegas is almost four years from Fallout 3 in 2281, and 204 years after the Great Nuclear War in 2077. The story goes in Las Vegas, Nevada and Mojave Desert. Unlike other cities in the Fallout series, Vegas is not directly affected by nuclear attacks. The majority of buildings in the city are intact and the number of mutations among people is very small. This isolation is reflected in nature in a sense, clean water and food are more common than other places in the country. We can also compare the city of Vegas with the old Reno. Because it is one of the rare cities where the post-war world has electricity. It is also located near the famous Hoover Dam.If we come to the story; Our scenario character, written by John Gonzales, is a simple element for a courier company called Mojave Express. Something goes wrong during an ordinary deployment and we are attacked and shot by a group to bury a landscape. Fortunately, however, it is being rescued by a robot called Victor and we are opening it up at Doctor Mitchell's house. So our adventure begins.The main story is about finding out who shot us, why, but of course there are many other side missions as well. Like the Fallout 3's twin in terms of New Vegas technical structure. Physics engine, character designs, models, shaders, etc. They are all the same as the third game, so I do not have to talk much about it, but I have only one desire from Obsidian; Please, but please let me create characters that look like human beings no more. There are still a lot of choices in face design in the character creation phase, but unfortunately all the combinations of these options do not give you a proper look. Okay maybe this world is a world where you get dirt and nukes, but not everyone looks like a pug-eyed alien.Like I said, the game has the same technical features, but there are also a few minor bugs about graphics. I think we will be quite satisfied with the game in terms of visuals after these mistakes that will be corrected in short time. In fact, when talking about the ready-made character model and graphic mistakes, let's talk about one or two bad sides of the game before it hides its beauty so that when we finish our writing, we have a nice taste in our mouth.Apart from the two technical faults I mentioned above, there is nothing I can complain about the technical part of the game. Beside this, I experienced some sadness about the music and sounds of the game. Music or voices are not bad, just few. Especially with the 5-10 songs you hear on radio music, it's just a piece of music playing on the fence while you are walking around. I still have old jazz and blues pieces, and occasionally I have two rock 'n' rolls. Regarding the voicings, it is not very inadequate as it is not bad at all, considering the logic of the game, neither technically nor quantitatively. But human beings are not enough! The character, ambiance and other voices are quite nice. Sounds and mouth movements are in sync. The sound of the surroundings really makes you feel like you're walking around in a circle. But I can not say the same for artificial intelligence. In general, artificial intelligence acting logically, sometimes can do really stupid things. In some places, if you are an enemy, your supporters, nonsense objects or walls can be stuck in place. But that's all. Obviously I'm going to do a bit of a bad review on the game, and that's a problem, except perhaps a music patch - a problem that can not be solved with a simple patch.As a first innovation we can start with traits and advantages (perk). While there is no change in skills, the features and benefits have been renewed. Also, the game does not force you to choose your first features. It offers you a choice of "Choose 2 features or never". Another innovation is camp fire. You will find these in many places. In campfires, you can make medicines and meals with the plants you collect around.Another innovation is in the work tables. Now, besides the classic work table, there is also a working table for preparing your own ammunition or for creating ammunition for the weapons you use with the pieces you have obtained from this unarmed ammunition. Of course, for these two innovations, you have to have your talent as well as the material. The game map is much smaller than Fallout 3. But do not perceive it as having less work to do. On the contrary, the fact that the map is small makes the game more full and lively, and I think it was a good tactic. One of the nice innovations is that you can now use binoculars. Now we do not have a problem to see far enough to find a scoped rifle, so I've been looking a lot for binoculars in the third game.The bobble heads we gathered in the third game have been replaced by snow globes and star aisle covers. What you will notice directly when you first target your weapon is that the weapon is not fixed. Yes, there is a coherence in weapons now. So you will usually want to squat and shoot. VATS was one of the most favorite battle strategies, and it still gives you the opportunity to make special strikes in addition to weapons other than firearms, and it is cinematic during these strikes. You already learn all these innovations in the village of Goodspring at the beginning of the game. As I said at the beginning, this village is actually prepared as an exercise section and you can say that I can absolutely recommend it, you can play this exercise section. We can say that great innovation is the interaction and the effects that this interaction creates in our stories. First of all, I have to say that reputation now has a very big prefix. The Mojava desert is shared by many groups; The most important of which are NCR and Caesar's Legion. NCR (New California Republic) is an organization that started after the war and a group of law-makers united and formed militias, and then it is growing considerably. They have power, money, technology and most important power. They provide electricity to New Vegas with the Hoover Dam on their hands. Caesar's Legion is a slavery-focused rebel group. NCR is not as strong and organized as the NCR, but literally insane. Apart from these, many other small group games are out in the game. This is where the reputation you make at this point affects the reaction you give to the groups that you encounter by coming after you. In every town, there is a reputation according to your attitude there, and at this point the game leaves you in a complete void. You will be on the side of a group during the game, or you will not be able to decide whether you will choose your side. There is good and bad here with no exact meaning. The people you say are good and want you to do things that sometimes you do not even doubt yourself.Dialogs are solid. It gives you detailed information about your life and your life here. Depending on your SPECIAL abilities, you may encounter different dialogue methods. In addition, the people you talk to change their face expression according to the subject or current mood.Overall: 11/10 LEGENDARY

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												I typically prefer to play simulation and strategy sandbox games because I can get countless hours of replayability versus games with a storyline as eventually the story ends. Reviews and trailers for Fallout 4 caught my attention, but I wasn't quite ready to dish out the money for a genre I've only started to dabble in recently. Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas caught my attention when it was discounted during this past Winter Sale, and I went with Fallout New Vegas because I was worried about Windows 10 and Fallout 3 not being optimized past Windows 7.  I am soon to be 30 hours in and there is someone with almost 4,000 hrs of gameplay out there, I do not regret my choice and it speaks to the opporunity to replay the game when I am done with my first playthrough.Fallout New Vegas welcomed me in without the need to play the previous Fallout games, the storyline is captivating and well-planned thus far. The quests help me to explore an almost open world, exposing me to various creatures and gangs. I am not an expert and no where close to ending the game, but I like the fact that I can choose to replay the game differently by altering my choice of SPECIALS, skills, and choices that in turn affect how the game continues. I have restarted a few times while learning which SPECIALS and skills work best with the character build I am interested in. I finally have a better understanding of the setup and I find that the game provides a challenge without completely sinking and frustrating me as a new player to the genre and franchise. I imagined originally that I wouldn't like it because I don't typicaly play first person shooters but the whole aspect of combining elements of an RPG that I am dabbling with as of late with FPS has suddenly made me more fierce with a gun and explosives. I LOVE that I can cause damage but on the side of good. Some day, maybe I will walk on the darkside to see what else Fallout New Vegas has to offer in terms of quests, but until then I am shooting ghouls, creepy crawlers, and gang members in favor of those in need.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												Despite what some people might say, Fallout: NV is the better game compared to Fallout 3. It has the same basic "Fallout 3-esque" gameplay but it's much improved. They took many popular mods from FO3 and implemented them directly into the game and it's much better for it. I'd even go as far to say that "hardcore mode" is the way you should play Fallout: NV. It feels much better with that turned on...like a real wasteland and you're trying to survive in it.NV is exactly what Obsidian does best - They take a good IP and improve upon it in almost every way....especially the writing. Bethesda couldn't write a decent story to save their lives. Their writers are down-right horrible and every one of their games' story was a joke. They make nice lore, but they never write an interesting and involved story in a single game.The only thing FO3 has over NV is easy to see (literally). It's the visuals. FO3 takes place in a  ruined downtown DC area in the USA. Very iconic even to people who don't live in the US. The cowboy-esque visuals from NV are nice at times too, but nothing compares to a torn-up iconic environment most people have seen pictures of in real life.  It's the one real advantage that game has. Everything else though? Fallout: New Vegas actually does it better. Don't get me wrong, I liked Fallout 3 for what it was, but most everything was improved for New Vegas.Do yourself a favor and pick up NV today!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Perhaps its greatest strength is the fact that everybody can play it differently. Rigidly follow the main storyline – or wander off and ignore it entirely. Try and be as moral as possible – or kill and rob the first merchant you come across. It's a tailor-made gaming experience where everything can be done at your own pace and in your own way – no wonder it resonates with so many people.Fallout: New Vegas, the latest addition to the FRANCHISE, exemplifies all these great qualities in the series' best outing to date.The action this time takes place on the US west coast – the setting for the first two Fallout games – a decision which has granted Obsidian much greater scope for variety in landscaping and colour than the washed-out Washington DC of Fallout 3.Being further away from the game's titular nuclear fallout, there's blue skies, singing birds and more signs of civilisation – a marked tonal shift from the unremittingly bleak scenery seen previously.Aside from the familiar burnt-out cities and trailer parks, the centrepiece of this new setting is the New Vegas strip – a wonderfully distorted and dark version of its real-life counterpart. Vomiting drunks, voluptuous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and a selection of fully playable CASINOS(better max out your Luck rating first) make it every bit as vivid and memorable as the decaying US capital of the last game.In terms of the story, there's next to no foreshadowing this time around – players are expected to be familiar with the Fallout universe – and the main narrative follows your attempts to unravel the events leading up to your near-death, which prefigures the game.Fallout: New VegasI've been asked a few times whether it's 'better' than Fallout 3's central plot and to be honest it's hard to say. It's a looser strand to follow, meaning side-questing fits in much more easily, though the blank nature of your character means it's hard to care too much about what happened to you – especially when there's so much fun to be found elsewhere.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2011
												There are two main groups of the Fallout fanbase as of 2011: people who played all the Fallout games and the much larger amount of people who only really played Fallout 3. I'm part of the first group. Leaving aside the fact that said group is the most toxic fanbase on the Internet, suffice to say that I think Fallout 2 was a big improvement over the first (awful opening area aside).Fallout 3-gen fans tend to dislike New Vegas. But to people like me, Fallout: New Vegas is what I've been waiting for. It's designed by many of the people who made Fallout 2, specifically New Reno. The shortcomings I felt with Fallout 3--the lack of region/NPC-specific endings, the quest solutions not really having much of an effect on the game or world, the dialogue/writing of the NPCs, etc--have all been fixed here. The VATS targeting system is no longer invincible and targeting is redone to use FPS mechanics (where you aim = where you shoot). It'd be hard to go back to Fallout 3 from this, & I liked F3!

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Played 40 hours on my first playthrough, then lost the save file right before the fight at Hoover Dam.Now, one year later I finally build up the courage to start anew and begin an adventure that will help place Fallout: New Vegas as one of the most immersive, and addicting games I've ever played. The glitches give it that charm that lets you know not to take things too seriously, many laughs to be had. The game provides challenge as long as you play at least Normal and up.This game also gives you the option the literally play through the adventure, in many numorous ways whether it be what main story path you'll take (NCR, Caesar, House, You having an entire robot army)On top of that, you're free to decide how you will deal with every situation. You want to be a blood thirsty melee mad man? Maybe you'd prefer to deal with things in a more "peaceful" way, vanilla new vegas has been proven to be able to beat without killing a single creature or person (You can look up the YouTube playlist) Or like any regular person who likes the pick up Fallout, just wants to get 100 Guns and shoot any man creature or creepy ghoul proostitute, lockpick into everything (Which is nicely recommended) and all in all, have fun. The DLC is also all really well done and worth picking up. This game I recommend for everybody who has a brain420/10 changed my life.P.S. In H&H Tools Factory, read every single terminal, it's worth it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas is a very nice video game. From the story to the gameplay, it has eaten the past 100 hours of my life and I'm  very pleased to waste my time. From the art style to the music to the characters, it all just fits in so well. You could say that it's no different from Fallout 3 but unlike Fallout 3, this is a much brighter and much more difficult and polished up experience with only a few flaws within the game. The DLC is fantastic, offering lots of new content and areas to explore. However, there is the problem that it's a Bethesda game. Why is that a problem? Because it's buggy. You have to be careful with the game. If you can get over the annoying save bug (where you can't load your save, requiring you to start the game from the start in order to be able to load your oldest save), to some quest breaking bugs that require you to cheat in the console (I had this occur for me once, but still). The other problem is that the battle with Caesar is very very badly executed. But, that doesn't stop the game itself from being good. If you're looking for a very fun and enjoyable experience, I highly recommend you try it out. And the game itself isn't that expensive with all it's DLC anyway.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												This was the first of the Fallout Series that I've played and I am thoroughly impressed. The creators and successors of Fallout truly love their creation and put so much passion into their games and related items of interests. Only finishing FO:NV, I realise that I have only touched like 5% of the whole story. It made me curious and so I read the timeline of events in the whole Fallout universe and pleased myself with the reading of the whole story. I really enjoyed that as well!(From a first-time player of Fallout) FO:NV has great FPS gameplay including the VATS feature. The leveling, skill, S.P.E.C.I.A.L, perk and reputation system is vast and astonishing. I enjoyed starting new characters with high strength and luck and yolo it out in the Wasteland. The mass amounts of items, armor, weapons, ammo and drinks you can find is another aspect that'll make me enjoy and not get bored. Storyline is very non-linear and links up few quests so you don't have to got through too much trouble. The A.I is nicely designed for the era of the gaming industry when FO:NV was in. Companions are cool and there are many options to do with the companion (fight, stay, disband or just have a nice chat). Overall I just think FO:NV as an incredibly badass game.The main reason I played FO:NV was because of the massive hype for Fallout 4 that provoked me to try out the Fallout Series. I know now that I will definitely buy Fallout 4, when I have the money ofc. I am proud of Bethesda, Obsidian and the original creators Interplay. 10/10 I write poetry in my Brotherhood of Steel armor. Lasers are my ink. My enemies are my paper.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2013
												A fitting love-letter of a bygone era known only as the '50s, it reminds me of a dusty ballroom recording, with its crackles and pops, genuine improvisational finesse, and its propensity for dryness. It seamlessly blends diverse modes of visual art, ranging from retro-futurism to Art Deco to modernist sensibilities into its quirky and idiosyncratic world.You, the Courier, wander the vast expanse collectively known as the 'Mojave Wasteland', a post-apocalyptic, divergent vision of the United States in 2281.On a quest to seek revenge against a mystery man who left you in an unmarked ditch to die, you are inadvertently thrown into a quagmire between three major factions: the 'New California Republic', 'Caesar's Legion', and with the enigmatic 'Mr. House'.The main story revolves solely on these three factions, which I'll get into in relative detail. (Spoilers below).The 'New California Republic' touts itself as a last bastion of a democratic federation, structuring its government and its system of laws after pre-War United States sworn to egalitarian ideals. This ideology was handled rather poorly by bureaucrats and serve as an annoying hindrance to civic order. (They are now dealing with a conglomerate of loosely connected but independent city-states.) Problems arise regarding but not limited to: laissez-faire capitalism, populism, rampant corruption, extensive senatorial infighting, and most recently, aggressive expansion.Edward Sallow was a former member of the Followers and the NCR. Here is a man who took charge of his life, as a true anarchist like himself would. He familiarized himself with the 'Commentarii', Julius Caesar's firsthand account on the Gallic Wars and emulated his character, even taking on his title. He quickly established himself as a man to be reckoned with, resorting to shockingly barbaric ways to make his point, and established the monolithic 'Legion'.One might think Caesar's Legion would serve as a direct dichotomy to the NCR, but they're very analogous if you think about it: both are nationalistic (strictly in the traditional sense), militaristic, imperialistic, and arguably totalitarian. The Legion takes it one step further and "obliterates the identity of every group it conquers", a homogenous culture of racialists, galvanizing under one banner.And of course, you have Mr. Robert Edwin House and his roaming army of Securitrons. A mysterious and undoubtedly interesting figure, a staunch antitheist, and an ambitious, calculating autocrat with great oratory skill and prowess, he practically owns the New Vegas strip. He is also a self-described visionary of technological and economic gambits, and wants total control of the Wasteland.(I won't even mention all the fracases you can get into with minor factions, specifically with the Three Families, the Boomers, the Great Khans, the Brotherhood of Steel, the Remnants of the Enclave, etc. simply because there's no room for it.) These storylines are just as enjoyable and original, if not moreso than the main quests.This is a game that's politically versed, wholly engaging, dark and humorous, and always fun to play. Mod it to your heart's content, and explore the Wasteland, a dried-up canvas that keeps on giving. Fallout at its best.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas may seem like an expansion for Fallout 3 than a stand alone game, but that is only at first glance. Fallout: New Vegas takes the focus of the Fallout franchise back to the west coast and does so in a very good way. The story isn't exactly amazing, however it lends itself to letting you create your own backstory, and making your own decisions. There really isn't too much to hold you back from doing what ever you want? The base game alone has hundreds of hours of contnent in it, and has a huge amount of replay value, from four different major endings and dozens of smaller end pieces. That being said it is not without a few flaws: namely the glitichs and instability. It manages to be worse than its predecesor in that regard, as well as numerous bugs; some hilarious, some that can ruin a run through. The only other real complaint I have is that you CANNOT continue the game after you beat the ending, which is a shame. Still there is more than enough to do in New Vegas, and with all of its DLC this is a must have for any Fallout fan, as well as anyone who likes RPGs.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												War? War never changes. Neither does Fallout. Between Fallout 3 and New Vegas not a whole lot had changed. Heck, usually a sequel adds significant technical improvements. Not New Vegas. New Vegas trades out the setting for a slightly different one, trades in its story for something that Bioware would be jealous of. And adds a few new weapons and options. Other than that, New Vegas and Fallout 3 are pretty much exactly alike. And that is not a bad thing. I would have loved a more intuitive interface, or higher walkspeed, but I guess the developers held true to their creed of "do not fix what isn't broke." They also didn't fix was was broken, but big games have these small issues, and New Vegas is big. Huge. Ginormous. Not just in scale, but also in scope. There are so incredibly many things to do; if you'd try to do them all, you'd go mad. It is impossible to do it all in one playthrough; many quests have different angles and outcomes, and your alignment plays a big role. Oh, and this game isn't cushy with good and bad alignment. No, this game has a tonne of factions, and each keeps tabs on your relationship with them. You can suck up to all of them, or a few, or just go full paraiah and just kill everyone. Also, the game generally doesn't care about how you finish up a quest; just that you put an end to it. New Vegas is a true, and both technically and literally a sandbox game. Most of the world is desert. Miles and miles of barren, irradiated sand, rocks and broken roads. This is where the tedium sets in. Because for all its superfluence, there isn't much variation in the design. All the buildings look the same. Someone built the same dingy shack about 18 times over, all across the Mohave desert. You can only distiguish the various derelict factories from the name on the door. It's a shame. For all its complex relationship mechanics and over the top gore, it is easy to see where the developers cut costs.None of it really matters. The narrative just sucks you in, then spits you out to the side so you can go fishing for airplanes, only to draw you back in as you are rummaging through random hotel rooms. When you finally hit the climax, you'll have no idea about what and who you were working with. All the more reason to play it again, and waste even more time, looking for snowglobes in a giant desert while the future of mankind is at the mercy of antiquated fanatics who like to nail people to crosses for fun. Serious business.
