content:
Posted: January 27
												This game is awesome.Fallout New Vegas really feels like the middle child between the firstborn (fallout 3) and the newest member of the family (Fallout 4).  Fallout 3 laid the foundation for what was to be expected from the next iterations in the series - a solid, well rounded achiever that was the first modern foray into an unexplored first person Fallout.  Being the first allowed it to carve out the series' baseline expectations; a fresh, interesting, and well received experience that introduced a number of new ideas. Fallout 4, the newest bundle of joy, is young, athletic, and good looking - trying to capture its attention from the audience on mostly looks alone, but lacking the depth of the firstborn.  It can run circles around the other two graphically and is good at sports, but spends too much time in front of the t.v.Fallout New Vegas, being the middle child, found its identity by studying hard at school and differentiating itself from the other siblings.  It added the deepest of the modern Fallout RPG elements and excelled in English class, with interesting well-written quests.  It also learned to do things that the firstborn couldn't, building on its foundation, but lacking the flair of the youngest of the family. It can't compete with Fallout 4's superior looks, but knows deep down it will eventually get the girls when they become bored and look for a deeper commitment.Pros;Great quests/faction interactionsRPG elements/perksImproved gunplaycharacterslength (the dlc is fantastic)16,000 + mods on the NexusCons:can be temperamental (glitch)Less emphasis on explorationgraphical fidelityFallout New Vegas is a must have if you enjoy RPG's.  It might have a few pimples, but it can hold a long, interesting conversation with you.  19.99 for the ultimate edition really is a steal, especially compared to what I spent on the original Xbox 360.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												A few months ago I wrote a negative review about Fallout New Vegas. It was wrong of me to only play this for an hour and call it trash without actually getting to embrace the game. Now my playtime is over 30 because I began to learn how much of a fun game this was.Remember those old Fallout games back in the 90s? Those point and click ones? Bethesda came up with an idea to reuse the elements of the old games and bring them back to a resurrected FPS. The execution of this idea does not dissapoint. There were things I liked about the old Fallout games that caught my eye, such as the type of ammo that can either pentrate armour or do more damage. Bringing them back to New Vegas was the bomb. (No war-pun intended) Companions in New Vegas are now more easy to manipulate with the Companion wheel, and the fact that you can choose your own ending instead of the game choosing it for you is like Nuka Cola combined with some Sunest Sarspirilla. However this game is not perfect. There will be crashes here and there when you play, which get a bit annoying if you didn't save your game. Sometimes, the Mojave Wasteland looks blank and dead, which makes sense since the setting takes place in the desert, but nothing like some Fiends and Deathclaws to add a bit of flavor to the taste. Overall this game DESERVES a 9.5/10. I highly recommend you get this game if you enjoy RPG's and like a bit of challenge here and there. But if you do, word of advice...Actually I have no advice to say, only play this game like there is no tomorrow c:

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Bethesda Softworks' release of Fallout 3 in 2008 went a long way in reviving a series which looked to have been milked for all it was worth, and brought a new set of fans for the series. Yet, while the new fans were being entertained by Fallout 3, some of the older fanbase – including myself – bemoaned the game for its poor story and dialogue, the liberties taken with the canon, and the disappointing ending. When the development of Fallout: New Vegas was announced, I must admit that I felt a bit of trepidation. Obsidian Entertaiment was composed of members of the Fallout development team when Black Isle was at its prime, but were they the right people to take up the mantle of a new Fallout game?In the development of Fallout: New Vegas, Obsidian drew in elements from the incomplete game which was to have been the third instalment of the main series, Van Buren, with various changes to their implementation to deal with the smaller geographical area. Gameplay-wise, though, Fallout: New Vegas strongly resembles Fallout 3, and could be best described as a refined variant of the first/third-person action role-playing action that distinguished Fallout 3 from its predecessors in the series. The skill set has been cleaned up somewhat, removing the Small Guns and Big Guns categories, and placing their weapons into the Guns and Explosives skills accordingly. The new Survival skill ties into the expanded crafting mechanics, and is of particular concern to the new Hardcore mode, in which the character must eat, sleep and drink, in which ammunition has weight as in the original Fallout games, and in which healing takes place over time, rather than being instantaneous.In an increased attempt to make non-weapon skills useful, the crafting mechanic has been expanded to include the ability to hand-load ammunition using shell casings, powder and lead at a reloading bench, along with cooking and the production of poisons at a campfire. The reloading mechanic is particularly welcome, allowing for the recycling of excess stockpiled ammunition, as well as the casting of rare ammunition types, including certain enhanced ammunition exclusive to the reloading bench. Meanwhile, the cooking mechanic gives a new use to those boxes of Cram which seem to be littered around the wasteland, allowing a skilled player to produce food which can heal more effectively and, in Hardcore Mode, which satiates the character's hunger for longer.Another new addition to the series is the “true ironsights” configurable option, which ties into a general tightening-up of the shooting mechanics. VATS has been weakened from Fallout 3, and in its place, the shooting mechanics feel somewhat more satisfying, at least at long range, where long rifles feel a bit more useful than they did in Fallout 3. Indeed, weapons under the Guns skill feel a lot more capable of getting one to the end of the game than in Fallout 3, and it is perfectly possible for somebody to focus on one weapon skill – apart from possibly Explosives - and to have few problems proceeding onwards.The biggest way in which Fallout: New Vegas is distinct to its immediate predecessor is that it feels like a character- and dialogue-oriented game, rather than the exploration-oriented approach of Fallout 3. One of my biggest disappointments with Fallout 3 was its rather poor storyline, in which one felt railroaded into a set of actions, even when they didn't make logical sense for your character, and which worked to the detriment of the rest of the game. Fallout: New Vegas, on the other hand, allows for a greater amount of flexibility with the storyline, with four distinct paths for one to set on, a lot of choices to make in the wasteland, and far more logical consistency than Fallout 3. This does come at a cost, as the start of the game is very linear in terms of exploration, with powerful creatures making progression directly towards New Vegas difficult, but as this approach was taken – albeit more subtly – in both Fallout and Fallout 2, so this will only be a big concern to the players who enjoyed Fallout 3 primarily because of the exploration elements.Another area which Fallout: New Vegas improves on is the portrayal of its characters. Unlike Fallout 3, in which most of the main characters felt bland or clichéd, Fallout: New Vegas takes more care with several of its characters, giving them a bit more life beyond being simple quest markers. This is of particular note when it comes to the leaders of each faction, and also with the companion characters, all of which possess a well-crafted backstory and a personal quest which progresses their characterisation further. This makes a good comparison to the pack mule approach taken by Fallout 3, and even, to a lesser extent, by Fallout and Fallout 2.A welcome change to the dynamic of the game is the lessened importance of the karma meter, displaced by the Fallout 2 approach of community reputations, which has been expanded to allow for a broader variety of different reputations. A greater logical consistency is created with NPC reactions, something which felt lacking in Fallout 3. What's more, this allows for a bit more moral ambiguity within the game universe, a far cry from the rather binary set of moral interactions which resulted from Fallout 3's reliance on the karma meter.Aesthetically, Fallout: New Vegas is not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly graphically impressive when it made its appearance in 2008. With no significant improvements to graphics, Fallout: New Vegas looks mediocre, particularly in the wake of extremely GPU-intensive but especially flashy game engines for the PC in the interim. Sounds are effective, but not particularly striking, and simply serve their purpose without going beyond the call of duty.Inon Zur's backing music from Fallout 3 returns, with a few extra tracks added to the mix. Again, I'd argue that this music is just there to create the right sense of ambience, and rarely goes beyond that purpose. Some Fallout and Fallout 2 players will note the return of some of the music of Mark Morgan from these games, but again, this music always seemed to just serve a purpose with the exception of a few tracks which didn't make it into Fallout: New Vegas.As with Fallout 3, a healthy number of licensed tracks make their way into the game via the Pip-Boy 3000's radio. Some players may prefer this music to the standard soundtrack, while others may tire quickly of the repetition of the small library of tracks, but it's nice to see the option retained. The music also creates the ambience of civilisation within communities, so in that sense, it's still worth having within the game.Unfortunately, there is one very negative area in which Fallout: New Vegas has followed in the footsteps of its predecessors.  Fallout: New Vegas is still not entirely free of bugs, with graphical glitches and clipping issues still remaining. While the Fallout series has not had a reputation for faultless programming, partially a consequence of its extensive scope, it's disappointing and jarring to have an enemy – or worse, yourself – stuck in the side of a rock with no way to escape.Nevertheless, Fallout: New Vegas certainly progresses the series, working on the framework of Fallout 3, while taking more influence from the preceding Fallout games and instituting some of the visions that were planned for Van Buren. Paradoxically, in terms of the series progression, it may have made more sense to term this to be the third instalment in the main series, and have named Fallout 3 something along the lines of Fallout: Capital Wasteland. Either way, Fallout: New Vegas is a reasonably well-crafted and frequently fun game which only suffers from the minor disappointment of persistent bugs.

												Even though the initial game isnt as good as fallout 3 its a pretty fun game with plenty of new features to keep one entertained plus really cool DLC's. But the mods make this game incredible. Highly recommended for anyone a fan of RPG's or shooters.Now this game is something special, playing the game with a modest mix of mods make this game quite an experience, better than Fallout 4 by a long shot.First the RPG aspects are LEAGUES better than 4, leveling a character is a lot more advanced, which isn't saying much compared to 4, but it has depth and thought to it. You can create whatever character you want instead of being stuck with a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off dad. The dialogue is great as it has choice and can change the tide based on your character.Modding is very easy to do, no wierd way to do it.Once I upgrade my PC, I plan to reinstall this game and mod it to hell. While this game is a 8/10 for an RPG, the overall feel and gameplay makes this a solid 9.5/10, while Fallout 4 is a 4/10 as an RPG and a 7/10 as a Fallout game. Please support this game people, Bethesda needs to make a Fallout game with a lot more focus in the RPG aspect like this one here instead of forcing a backstory and character onto you.

Posted: August 17, 2014
												Best Fallout game, with alot of interesting quests, and a huge Wasteland to explore. The story this time is based along the war between the New California Republic (NCR), and the Legion. Both have their strengths and weaknesses, and you can join whichever you want to complete the game, or go through and independant New Vegas, and kick both of them out of Nevada. A vast improvement over Fallout 3 in terms of weapons, iron sights, and locations. The characters are quite memorable, and the companions are badasses if you get them the right gear. Both the Brotherhood of Steel and the Enclave make appearances, but in vastly dimmed down appearances than their Fallout 3 counterparts. Which is a shame, as I like the Fallout 3 Brotherhood better than New Vegas's. There are four pieces of DLC for New Vegas, but they all have their ups and downs.Dead Money is an extremely confusing, and creepy DLC to play, but gives you a good few hours of gameplay. This was my least favorite of the four.Honest Hearts is my favorite, as it gives you a huge part of Utah to explore (namely Zion National Park), gives you some awesome armor to wear, and has some pretty awesome characters, namely the Burned Man himself, Joshua Graham. A must play even just to get the Desert Ranger Armor.Old World Blues was a pretty standard run to this place, grab something, run to this place grab this, and so on and so forth. The one thing that sets this out from the rest is the "Brains", a group of former scientists from before the Great War who placed their brains in robots so they could continue living. I won't spoil anything, but their entire dialogue is absolutely hilarious to hear, and it is hard not to like their dialogue. This is my third favorite of the four.Lonesome Road. This is the last DLC, and the second best. The area you explore is extremly hostile, looks great, and everything is out to kill you. You also get to find out about your past before you accepted the ill-fated job from the Mojave Express. Ullysses is a great antagonist. Suffice to say, this is a great one to play as well, and you really should.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Hmm... Fallout: New Vegas. Ya know, throughout this series we've heard the phrase uttered time and time again; "War, war never changes". Each installment of the Fallout series has given us insight on what exactly holds for us if we ever do come to some sort of "End-of-the-World" pinnacles. Sex, drugs, guns, and money. Seems nothing more than simply a fantasy but when you look deeper into it, it's more than that. It's a reality. A reality of something that could be, because of both the human nature to preserve but also because of the most catastrophical ideal that we humans have. A trait that not a single person on this planet is free from. Something that given time, can destroy lives, families, friends, countries, and well.. even the world. Greed. Pure greed. Now, I may have lost you with the philisophical mumbo-jumbo, but hear me out. Fallout is easily known for reaffirming the negative repercussions of human greed within the series, but Fallout: New Vegas does it the best. Personalities such as Benny, Ceasar, and many other characters shown to us forthright how damaging their personal greed can cause so much chaos is scary. One damn near kills you and another damn near destroys all of New Vegas. As the player, you go through so many different obstacles that while not incredibly damaging to your playstyle, can seriously change the outcome of future events drastically. All winding down to something as simple as not being friendly to someone. In hindsight, this may not seem incredibly.. so much to do with just greed, but all of humanities existence. A test of patience and time, to make choices and risk the outcomes. To make friendships that will drastically alter the course of the game. Given all this, could you really sit here and say that this is a bad game? It takes a lot to accidently make people philisophically question things. It takes a lot more to actually try and do it.

												A classic game for a classic man.The land of the Mojave is incredibly "colorful." By that, I mean memorable. It's a mixture of suave 1940's-50's style finesse, and the dry, heated Hell of the Nuclear Desert. The characters you encounter are fun, dark, dry, deadly, and lovable all together. The combat, incredibly satisfiying as you aim, shoot, and watch as your opponent's head gets blown off. The combination of finesse, a great cast of characters, a mind-boggling arsenal at your disposal, and an entertaining story-arc will blow you away. Literally.Fallout: New Vegas truly is easily one of the best games I have ever played, and that's saying something.Traditional Rating: 3 out of 4.Personal Rating: "Legendary."

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												War. War Never changes.From the time these words are spoken, to the moment you reach the end of the game, you will experience one of the best game’s out there. Outdated engine, loads of glitches, and too few voices for too many characters. Despite these flaws, I believe Fallout New Vegas is the best game I’ve ever played. A fantastic story, interesting and diverse characters, hundreds of mods, and a return to good ol’ Fallout.I bought this game a few years ago, knowing only a little about Fallout, having only played Fallout 3 a few times, never for long, when I was young. So, with Fallout 3, I bought this game, not knowing what to expect. Here I am, a few years later, with over 250 hours of gameplay under my belt, and still more to come. Over the course of these years I have played every other Fallout game in existence and have learned the lore and history of both the game and it’s world. Every time I play one of the other games, I am hit by a sense of wonder, but I always end up coming back to this one, New Vegas.New Vegas has everything you could want from a Fallout game, bringing you back to the West Coast and the world of old Fallout. Hundreds of cool guns and missions and a gigantic world to discover, not to mention some pretty good DLC, for the most part. Las Vegas, now dubbed New Vegas, is the last bastion of civilization in the world, as far as it’s inhabitants can tell, led by the mysterious and enigmatic Mr. House. The NCR, who you may remember from Fallout 2, have spread out to Nevada to find the Hoover Dam. With the discovery of the Dam, comes the discovery of the antithesis to everything the NCR stands for, The Legion, a group founded under the ideals of old Rome. Before the start of the game, the NCR and the Legion duked it out over control of the Dam, the NCR just barely winning. Now the Legion is back, and after revenge. Mr. House sits in the protection of the walled city of New Vegas, ruling over it’s inhabitants under the ideals of the old world, as the NCR dukes it out once again with the Legion, with plans of his own. You are a Courier, a messenger of sorts, tasked with delivering a mysterious package by order of Mr. House, who must unite the Mojave Wasteland under the rule of either the Legion, the NCR, Mr. House, or yourself. And with that, the best game of the Fallout series starts.So with my FIVE STAR RECOMMENDATION, go ahead, buy the game, and start the journey of your life.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas™; a game everybody has their own, unexplored world in which to conquer, one quest at a time.You, as the main character, are a Courier, your job is to deliver a package to New Vegas; it is from the old world, a torned down, and rebuilt city that is a hubble of life, filled with many, many different opportunities that you get to explore. You are ultimately kidnapped by armed men, which you will get to know more about later in the story, and are shot in the head in a cementary outside of a small, un-disturbed town, known as Goodsprings. From here on out, you get to make your own decisions, and make a rebuttle of what is left of the Mojavé-Wasteland. This game is a huge advancement compared to it's predecessor, Fallout: 3™. The amount of gameplay added to this game, which, might I add, is much, much more defined in the sense that you're really there; you feel as if you know your friends, enemies, and places you've been to. The quests and DLC make a surgated wall that can support the main quests of this masterpiece; as in Fallout: 3™, they don't. Fallout: New Vegas™ adds many more intelligent AI with never-before-seen dialogue that you can fiddle with -- meaning that some of your perks and skills can actually change the way you play the game, if done correctly, that is..      Factions have always been a big-hit in this games overall franchise, and in this game, they really show you how they've completely re-fortified that way it was meant to be. They're not just a few, big ones in this game that are good and evil [Factions] that you only get to choose from one-or-so faction, but many of them. The three main factions in Fallout: New Vegas™ are the N.C.R., Caesar's Legion, and the Brotherhood of Steel. tl;drI highly suggest buying this game - it is absouletely worth the twenty-dollars you will pay for it. I also recommend buying all the DLC whilst you're at it. It will make you have a brand new experience of playing.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Bethesda Softworks' release of Fallout 3 in 2008 went a long way in reviving a series which looked to have been milked for all it was worth, and brought a new set of fans for the series. Yet, while the new fans were being entertained by Fallout 3, some of the older fanbase – including myself – bemoaned the game for its poor story and dialogue, the liberties taken with the canon, and the disappointing ending. When the development of Fallout: New Vegas was announced, I must admit that I felt a bit of trepidation. Obsidian Entertaiment was composed of members of the Fallout development team when Black Isle was at its prime, but were they the right people to take up the mantle of a new Fallout game?In the development of Fallout: New Vegas, Obsidian drew in elements from the incomplete game which was to have been the third instalment of the main series, Van Buren, with various changes to their implementation to deal with the smaller geographical area. Gameplay-wise, though, Fallout: New Vegas strongly resembles Fallout 3, and could be best described as a refined variant of the first/third-person action role-playing action that distinguished Fallout 3 from its predecessors in the series. The skill set has been cleaned up somewhat, removing the Small Guns and Big Guns categories, and placing their weapons into the Guns and Explosives skills accordingly. The new Survival skill ties into the expanded crafting mechanics, and is of particular concern to the new Hardcore mode, in which the character must eat, sleep and drink, in which ammunition has weight as in the original Fallout games, and in which healing takes place over time, rather than being instantaneous.In an increased attempt to make non-weapon skills useful, the crafting mechanic has been expanded to include the ability to hand-load ammunition using shell casings, powder and lead at a reloading bench, along with cooking and the production of poisons at a campfire. The reloading mechanic is particularly welcome, allowing for the recycling of excess stockpiled ammunition, as well as the casting of rare ammunition types, including certain enhanced ammunition exclusive to the reloading bench. Meanwhile, the cooking mechanic gives a new use to those boxes of Cram which seem to be littered around the wasteland, allowing a skilled player to produce food which can heal more effectively and, in Hardcore Mode, which satiates the character's hunger for longer.Another new addition to the series is the “true ironsights” configurable option, which ties into a general tightening-up of the shooting mechanics. VATS has been weakened from Fallout 3, and in its place, the shooting mechanics feel somewhat more satisfying, at least at long range, where long rifles feel a bit more useful than they did in Fallout 3. Indeed, weapons under the Guns skill feel a lot more capable of getting one to the end of the game than in Fallout 3, and it is perfectly possible for somebody to focus on one weapon skill – apart from possibly Explosives - and to have few problems proceeding onwards.The biggest way in which Fallout: New Vegas is distinct to its immediate predecessor is that it feels like a character- and dialogue-oriented game, rather than the exploration-oriented approach of Fallout 3. One of my biggest disappointments with Fallout 3 was its rather poor storyline, in which one felt railroaded into a set of actions, even when they didn't make logical sense for your character, and which worked to the detriment of the rest of the game. Fallout: New Vegas, on the other hand, allows for a greater amount of flexibility with the storyline, with four distinct paths for one to set on, a lot of choices to make in the wasteland, and far more logical consistency than Fallout 3. This does come at a cost, as the start of the game is very linear in terms of exploration, with powerful creatures making progression directly towards New Vegas difficult, but as this approach was taken – albeit more subtly – in both Fallout and Fallout 2, so this will only be a big concern to the players who enjoyed Fallout 3 primarily because of the exploration elements.Another area which Fallout: New Vegas improves on is the portrayal of its characters. Unlike Fallout 3, in which most of the main characters felt bland or clichéd, Fallout: New Vegas takes more care with several of its characters, giving them a bit more life beyond being simple quest markers. This is of particular note when it comes to the leaders of each faction, and also with the companion characters, all of which possess a well-crafted backstory and a personal quest which progresses their characterisation further. This makes a good comparison to the pack mule approach taken by Fallout 3, and even, to a lesser extent, by Fallout and Fallout 2.A welcome change to the dynamic of the game is the lessened importance of the karma meter, displaced by the Fallout 2 approach of community reputations, which has been expanded to allow for a broader variety of different reputations. A greater logical consistency is created with NPC reactions, something which felt lacking in Fallout 3. What's more, this allows for a bit more moral ambiguity within the game universe, a far cry from the rather binary set of moral interactions which resulted from Fallout 3's reliance on the karma meter.Aesthetically, Fallout: New Vegas is not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly graphically impressive when it made its appearance in 2008. With no significant improvements to graphics, Fallout: New Vegas looks mediocre, particularly in the wake of extremely GPU-intensive but especially flashy game engines for the PC in the interim. Sounds are effective, but not particularly striking, and simply serve their purpose without going beyond the call of duty.Inon Zur's backing music from Fallout 3 returns, with a few extra tracks added to the mix. Again, I'd argue that this music is just there to create the right sense of ambience, and rarely goes beyond that purpose. Some Fallout and Fallout 2 players will note the return of some of the music of Mark Morgan from these games, but again, this music always seemed to just serve a purpose with the exception of a few tracks which didn't make it into Fallout: New Vegas.As with Fallout 3, a healthy number of licensed tracks make their way into the game via the Pip-Boy 3000's radio. Some players may prefer this music to the standard soundtrack, while others may tire quickly of the repetition of the small library of tracks, but it's nice to see the option retained. The music also creates the ambience of civilisation within communities, so in that sense, it's still worth having within the game.Unfortunately, there is one very negative area in which Fallout: New Vegas has followed in the footsteps of its predecessors.  Fallout: New Vegas is still not entirely free of bugs, with graphical glitches and clipping issues still remaining. While the Fallout series has not had a reputation for faultless programming, partially a consequence of its extensive scope, it's disappointing and jarring to have an enemy – or worse, yourself – stuck in the side of a rock with no way to escape.Nevertheless, Fallout: New Vegas certainly progresses the series, working on the framework of Fallout 3, while taking more influence from the preceding Fallout games and instituting some of the visions that were planned for Van Buren. Paradoxically, in terms of the series progression, it may have made more sense to term this to be the third instalment in the main series, and have named Fallout 3 something along the lines of Fallout: Capital Wasteland. Either way, Fallout: New Vegas is a reasonably well-crafted and frequently fun game which only suffers from the minor disappointment of persistent bugs.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Out of all the Bethesda open world games out there so far, this one is probably the best, and perhaps ironically since this one is developed by Obsidian instead of Bethesda Studios. Though the combat may be dated as well as the graphics, it absolutely nails so much more. The quests are intriguing and probably more interesting than most modern games. The atmosphere and landscape of a post-apocalyptic Nevada is almost impecabble, with enemies that well suited to look like radiated desert monstrocities and a style of music on the radio that just really ties the whole thing together. Even though combat is a little clunky compared to most shooters today, the variety of guns is great and it's still fun to shoot baddies. Mods can do so much too, improve graphics, fix bugs, add new weapons and quests, pretty much exactly what you'd expect from Skyrim or any other game running Creation Engine. Personally I found the story to be more interesting than Fallout 3 and even 4, though it's not perfect. In the end, what's happening around you will be more interesting than the main course. The several large factions in the game are cool but unfortunately because of time constraints Obsidian couldn't make them as impressive as they probably would've liked, a big example being Caesar's Legion. Honestly if there was one major criticism to the game it'd be that it's not as polished as it could be. While most of the time it's a solid package, made much better with the DLC (get GOTY btw, the DLC is amazing) sometimes you get the feeling that if Obsidian got more time this game would be that much better. As it stands though, this is a near masterpiece and I hope Obsidian gets the chance to make another Fallout, combining the great combat and improved graphical fidelity of Fo4 and more fleshed out aspects of everything else from this game.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Hmm... Fallout: New Vegas. Ya know, throughout this series we've heard the phrase uttered time and time again; "War, war never changes". Each installment of the Fallout series has given us insight on what exactly holds for us if we ever do come to some sort of "End-of-the-World" pinnacles. Sex, drugs, guns, and money. Seems nothing more than simply a fantasy but when you look deeper into it, it's more than that. It's a reality. A reality of something that could be, because of both the human nature to preserve but also because of the most catastrophical ideal that we humans have. A trait that not a single person on this planet is free from. Something that given time, can destroy lives, families, friends, countries, and well.. even the world. Greed. Pure greed. Now, I may have lost you with the philisophical mumbo-jumbo, but hear me out. Fallout is easily known for reaffirming the negative repercussions of human greed within the series, but Fallout: New Vegas does it the best. Personalities such as Benny, Ceasar, and many other characters shown to us forthright how damaging their personal greed can cause so much chaos is scary. One damn near kills you and another damn near destroys all of New Vegas. As the player, you go through so many different obstacles that while not incredibly damaging to your playstyle, can seriously change the outcome of future events drastically. All winding down to something as simple as not being friendly to someone. In hindsight, this may not seem incredibly.. so much to do with just greed, but all of humanities existence. A test of patience and time, to make choices and risk the outcomes. To make friendships that will drastically alter the course of the game. Given all this, could you really sit here and say that this is a bad game? It takes a lot to accidently make people philisophically question things. It takes a lot more to actually try and do it.

content:
Posted: January 16
												Been a huge Fallout fan for so many years, played the first classic games and even dabbled a bit with fallout tactics and brotherhood. When Fallout 3 came out i spent so much time on that game it was insane, would play it for hours on end only stopping for toilet breaks, sleep and to eat something before i turn into a skeleton. So eventually when New Vegas was released i quickly grabbed a copy on the consoles and not long after on the PC and yet again had my time get sucks down the time sink. After playing it for 500+ hours i can honestly say it was ALOT of fun and i loved the amount of mods and freedom the developers gave to their fans when it came to making your own mods for the game, but of course there are negatives. I hated the setting the game was in, alot of the towns are great i abolutely loved Goodsprings and the strip, but got tired quickly of just seeing just sand, occasional building and flat nothingness. What i loved so much in Fallout 3 was that you were in a destroyed capital, you could walk through destroyed buildings walk across a huge city seeing buildings that collapsed, stores destroyed and so on. But in New Vegas its just....sand.While so many fallout fanboys will comment on this "Review" and get all butthurt that i didn't like their precious new vegas game, i by no means say its a "Bad" game. Just not a great one in my opinion, and i certaintly don't get how so many people are being butthurt over the newest installation Fallout 4. Don't like fallout 4 then get a refund and stop complaining about the dialogue box or the "Missing" RPG elements. Other than that i would reccomend this game to people who want to buy the fallout series and see what its all about and to more importantly have fun. But don't play the game if you are looking for a bug free game, its a bethesda game so its to be expected.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												A few months ago I wrote a negative review about Fallout New Vegas. It was wrong of me to only play this for an hour and call it trash without actually getting to embrace the game. Now my playtime is over 30 because I began to learn how much of a fun game this was.Remember those old Fallout games back in the 90s? Those point and click ones? Bethesda came up with an idea to reuse the elements of the old games and bring them back to a resurrected FPS. The execution of this idea does not dissapoint. There were things I liked about the old Fallout games that caught my eye, such as the type of ammo that can either pentrate armour or do more damage. Bringing them back to New Vegas was the bomb. (No war-pun intended) Companions in New Vegas are now more easy to manipulate with the Companion wheel, and the fact that you can choose your own ending instead of the game choosing it for you is like Nuka Cola combined with some Sunest Sarspirilla. However this game is not perfect. There will be crashes here and there when you play, which get a bit annoying if you didn't save your game. Sometimes, the Mojave Wasteland looks blank and dead, which makes sense since the setting takes place in the desert, but nothing like some Fiends and Deathclaws to add a bit of flavor to the taste. Overall this game DESERVES a 9.5/10. I highly recommend you get this game if you enjoy RPG's and like a bit of challenge here and there. But if you do, word of advice...Actually I have no advice to say, only play this game like there is no tomorrow c:

content:
Posted: February 22
												There is some debate over whether Fallout 4 was better than New Vegas, yet few can deny that New Vegas is a classic that still provides players with the post-apocalyptic RPG experience today, 7 years later.New Vegas is meticulously crafted, and the world and lore is immersive. Choices matter. Different people would prefer different endings and it really takes a lot of roleplay to decide which one you would prefer. In creating good and bad, the NCR might fight for the return of old world democracy, but come across as intrusively imperialist; the legion might come across as villanous brutes, but to a certain extent they would bring back order and stability, if you're willing to accept slavery as  a norm of society. House would bring about a benovolent dictatorship, and Independence really looks at the choices that you have made. Sub-factions are pre-determined if you follow NCR, Legion or House paths, but only in independence can you make your own decisions among them.Characters, especially the companions, were people with complex identities. Veronica reveals that she fell in love with a girl, but was frowned upon by the Brotherhood because it demands certain female roles; yet Arcade is openly homosexual and he's just going along, trying to find ways to do good in the wasteland, it brings to light the differing treatment of lgbt's (which Fallout is still opening up to, great!) but neither of their personal quests revolve around their sexuality, which is a genius approach to it; they're just who they are. Veronica is a vivacious, forward-thinker stuck in a conservative society that tells itself it will succeed because it has succeeded before with the old ways. Boone is associable because we've all made grave mistakes that we can't forgive ourselves for - but Boone takes it a step further, by blaming a big personal loss on fate catching up to him for a mistake that wasn't even his fault. You find him in Novac (a play on no vacancy) and it's almost as if he's juxtaposed to be living there as a purposeless wanderer because his past has consumed him so. Nightkin Lily takes prescribed medicine, which keeps her sane, but the medicine also causes her to forget her past life as a grandmother to two children. What you encourage her to do with her medicine also takes a lot of roleplaying and what you feel is best or right for her. Point is, these characters aren't stock characters. Hell, they're more interesting than the people I meet in real life, because I relate to them and in helping them through their personal quests you also come to understand yourself and what you value.Fallout New Vegas gives you a number of perks and skills to invest in, and they change the way a player goes through the game diversely. Female characters' Black Widow, for example, opens up special dialogue options when talking to male NPCs - creating rare opportunities to bypass longer processes. Speech 100 will get you through a lot in the name of fighting with words. Or you could just fight, with guns. 'It's a free wasteland.'Last but not least, I am hopelessly in love with the soundtrack, both orchestral and licensed. Music direction was good and it added to my immersion. It made wandering through the Mojave a little less lonely.I'm hoping, along with many others, that Obsidian will develop the new Fallout post Fallout 4, but this is the game that really piqued my interest in the series, and now I'm headed on to finish my collection.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I'm on the verge deciding whether I like  Fallout 3 or Fallout NV more, for me they're on the same level. I'm going to make a short comparison:Fallout NV:- Less power armor focused- Strong wild-west theme (some like it some not)- Interesting characters, questline for every companion.- More things to do (like gambling etc.)- An amazing faction system, way better than FO3's karma.- Some of the best DLC's I've played in any game.FO3:- Real post-apocalyptic feeling.- Simpler-cleaner game mechanics- The main antagonists are much more strong and interesting- Less bugs (only for me?)- More interesting locations and landmarks- Creepier, more eerie than FONV.Anyway if you plan on buying the game buy the Ultimate/GOTY edition with all the dlc, it worth it. Just like with any Bethesda game, modding it is highly advised (not only to get rid of the numerous bugs, but to enhanced the gameplay and outdated visuals).

In New Vegas there is so much to do that this game will keep you busy for weeks and you could end up putting 150+ hours into just one save.  It has addicting gameplay, intresting characters and loads of great side quests that will be more than enough to keep you busy.  But all of these thing aside the game does have some downfalls like texture glitches and fetch quests (Bleed me dry which is seemingly a waste of time except for the awesome rewards).  Don't let these things deter you from enjoying the game because there is plenty to enjoy in Vegas!9.2/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
												There is some debate over whether Fallout 4 was better than New Vegas, yet few can deny that New Vegas is a classic that still provides players with the post-apocalyptic RPG experience today, 7 years later.New Vegas is meticulously crafted, and the world and lore is immersive. Choices matter. Different people would prefer different endings and it really takes a lot of roleplay to decide which one you would prefer. In creating good and bad, the NCR might fight for the return of old world democracy, but come across as intrusively imperialist; the legion might come across as villanous brutes, but to a certain extent they would bring back order and stability, if you're willing to accept slavery as  a norm of society. House would bring about a benovolent dictatorship, and Independence really looks at the choices that you have made. Sub-factions are pre-determined if you follow NCR, Legion or House paths, but only in independence can you make your own decisions among them.Characters, especially the companions, were people with complex identities. Veronica reveals that she fell in love with a girl, but was frowned upon by the Brotherhood because it demands certain female roles; yet Arcade is openly homosexual and he's just going along, trying to find ways to do good in the wasteland, it brings to light the differing treatment of lgbt's (which Fallout is still opening up to, great!) but neither of their personal quests revolve around their sexuality, which is a genius approach to it; they're just who they are. Veronica is a vivacious, forward-thinker stuck in a conservative society that tells itself it will succeed because it has succeeded before with the old ways. Boone is associable because we've all made grave mistakes that we can't forgive ourselves for - but Boone takes it a step further, by blaming a big personal loss on fate catching up to him for a mistake that wasn't even his fault. You find him in Novac (a play on no vacancy) and it's almost as if he's juxtaposed to be living there as a purposeless wanderer because his past has consumed him so. Nightkin Lily takes prescribed medicine, which keeps her sane, but the medicine also causes her to forget her past life as a grandmother to two children. What you encourage her to do with her medicine also takes a lot of roleplaying and what you feel is best or right for her. Point is, these characters aren't stock characters. Hell, they're more interesting than the people I meet in real life, because I relate to them and in helping them through their personal quests you also come to understand yourself and what you value.Fallout New Vegas gives you a number of perks and skills to invest in, and they change the way a player goes through the game diversely. Female characters' Black Widow, for example, opens up special dialogue options when talking to male NPCs - creating rare opportunities to bypass longer processes. Speech 100 will get you through a lot in the name of fighting with words. Or you could just fight, with guns. 'It's a free wasteland.'Last but not least, I am hopelessly in love with the soundtrack, both orchestral and licensed. Music direction was good and it added to my immersion. It made wandering through the Mojave a little less lonely.I'm hoping, along with many others, that Obsidian will develop the new Fallout post Fallout 4, but this is the game that really piqued my interest in the series, and now I'm headed on to finish my collection.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas is one of my favorite RPGs of all time. It follows the same "Skyrim with Guns" approach that Fallout 3 takes but in my opinion has a better storyline, with "true" ironsights and better general gameplay. Some people appreciate the grimdark devastated atmosphere of Fallout 3 over the more hopeful, western approach of Fallout New Vegas, and I can understand that. It feels weird in a post-nuclear war to have such thriving societies built in the rubble, but I enjoyed the charm and innovative ways that society has managed to survive. In addition to this, during any kind of nuclear conflict they enemy would send millions of nukes at Washington D.C., where Fallout 3 is located so it makes a bit of canonical sense to have Fallout 3 be way more decimated than the Mojave Desert. I'm a bit too young to have played the earlier Fallouts but from everything I've read New Vegas is a more direct succesor to the older games.Fallout New Vegas has a faction system in lieu of a more traditional blanket morality system, which I find fantastic considering how the various storylines of the game can play out. It doesn't make sense that EVERYONE would be mad if you decided to shoot that innocent wastelander in the face, but if that wastelander happened to belong to a particular faction, they would be unhappy with you. This lets you reliably play as an "evil" or "good" character without the pre-conceived shackles of either disposition. If you manage to upset any faction too much be sure to expect them to send "hit squads" after you that can show up at any time, adding a real danger to exploration. The map also is a lot more packed with interesting locations, and the open nature of the environment means you can stumble across all kinds of mutated horrors that wayyyy outlevel you at any time. Really amazingly terrifying stuff. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system is still in place, as well as the perk system. I've found speech to be a bit OP, but I really enjoyed talking my way out of dire situations time and time again.Seriously, if you haven't had the chance to play this game yet, buy the ultimate edition now. The DLCs are all great fun and on PC, you can mod the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game. I recommend Project Nevada for beginners, it adds a sprint functionality and rebalances all the weapons and perks to be more challenging, but also more enjoyable. Walking across a desolate desert littered with the remnants of the old world, hearing rifle shots as your companion Boone murders anything hostile that comes within a mile of you while listening to the "Big Iron" by Marty Robbins on the radio, you too will come to realize the elegant brilliance of this RPG. If anything, play it to get a handle on the lore of the Fallout universe and prepare yourself for Fallout 4!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												One of the greatest games ever made. Although essentially the same base game as Fallout 3 the writing is superb and introduces enough new gameplay elements to really make things seem like a new game rather than a reskin or expansion pack.It focuses on factions and currying favor or hatred from the various groups rather than a binary morality system. As such, the gameplay is different, as you have to decide your allegiances fairly early on. This also really impacts replayability as the game will feel different and play differently depending on which groups you are actively trying to support.Although Fallout 3 really nailed the bleak post-apocalyptic atmosphere, New Vegas's landscape feels much livelier, and more hopeful. Compared to the Capital Wasteland of Fallout 3 the Mojave Wasteland is thriving, including an actual functioning city of Las Vegas. The world is very well populated with NPCs that are all unique and have their own motives and stories for you to explore.My two biggest gripes with the game are: 1. After a certain point enemies become so powerful that small arms fire is almost useless. 2. Unlike Fallout 3 after beating the game you cannot explore the world, so beating the game means you will no longer be able to play as your character, which is disappointing since you spend so much time trying to build the world the way you want, and then have no chance to see the results of your actions.Now I'll do the DLC's as separate, brief reviews:Dead Money: Hard. Although the enemies were not that bad, and the plot was interesting and the characters well written, I got so frustrated trying to navigate the insta-kill mines and bomb collar triggers that I considered skipping this DLC altogether. That said though, The Sierra Madre Casino is a fascinating and unique place and the storyline of the DLC is very well written.Honest Hearts: Again, really great storyline, although overall it is very short. The scenery of Utah is very well captured and beautiful to look at, but the DLC feels a little stifling. Doesn't really add a lot of new weapons or things to carry over to the main game. Worth it for the storyline alone though.Old World Blues: A lot of people consider this to be the best DLC. It is definitely unique, well written, and adds a lot of new items to the game. However, it is very difficult to do since enemies are scaled to your level and very damage resistant. In addition, if you are a guns user, ammo is very scarce. If you enjoy crafting this can be mitigated, but I hate crafting and was constantly having to scrounge for ammo or just use whatever weapons I had to get by.Lonesome Road: Also somewhat difficult. But great storyline. Really focuses much harder on the post-apocalyptic atmosphere that Fallout 3 was so good at capturing.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2013
												Each time I return to New Vegas, I find my self enjoying it more and more than previous playthroughs.Fallout New Vegas is as close to another Black Isle Studios' Fallout game as we are gonna get. It was made by most of the team that made those games to boot. You are a courier and you were shot in the brain. After somehow surviving that you are dug out of a grave by a sandman robot and you recover in an astonishing amount of time. Time to set out and go kill the limp dicked gimp ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that shot you.New Vegas uses the conventions paved from Fallout 3 except Reputation is something you need to keep in check. Killing factioned npcs will make you lose rep with that faction and they will eventually start shooting you on site, as well as locking out certain side quests.The story is great and includes some characters from previous BIS Fallout games, including Marcus the Super Mutant from Fallout 2.Everyone knows how great this game is but the real reason why people play this game is for the mods. Fallout New Vegas has so many ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed mods you could spend 8 decades modding this game and still find a new way to play.I may be a classic Fallout zealot but I acknowledge good game design, and this certainly is a good game. It can get a little boring, with some quests being point a to b fares, but it certainly isn't as ♥♥♥♥ing crippling depressing as Fallout 4.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												OBSIDIAN NEEDS TO MAKE FALLOUT 4!Fallout New Vegas is the best game I have ever played. It's ugly, yes, (fixed with texture and ENB mods) but the world is just so alive compared to F3, Skyrim, Oblivion. There are multiple ways to manipulate the fate of the world and it's factions. Also, there is a lot of humour in the game. Everything from sex robots to people blowing up when you shoot them in the foot. But at the same time, it's a dark dystopian universe with slavery, postitution, war, and serious issues for characters which doesn't feel like just another cardboard mute NPC.  Most of all, it's not F3. Vegas is all F3 should have been but never was. Bethesda has a lot to learn from the masters of Obsidian, which they ignorantly just didn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about in Skyrim. ♥♥♥♥ you, Bethesda, you suck.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												This is my 3rd Fallout game with Fallout 4 being my first and Fallout 3 being my 2nd.I love the story in New Vegas, the gameplay is familiar to me since I started this after I finished Fallout 3. All the factions have their different vision on what New Vegas should be and it's up to YOU the Courier to decide the fate. They made a lot of improvements from Fallout 3 such as optimization (less crashing), slightly better gunplay such as aiming down sights, and a better companion system. Obsidian did a fantasic job making a Desert interesting, not a lot of devs can manage to pull it off but they did. I will finish up writing the rest of my review after I finish New Vegas and its DLCs and I also hope that Obsidian makes another Fallout game in the future.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
 Fallout New Vegas Welcome to Vegas. New Vegas. It’s the kind of town where you dig your own grave prior to being shot in the head and left for dead…and that’s before things really get ugly. It’s a town of dreamers and desperados being torn apart by warring factions vying for complete control of this desert oasis. Fallout new vegas is a Action, RPG game released on the 22nd October 2010.This game is so Good , The huge amount of choices  the game gives you, makes you want to try every single one which makes this game worth playing. As with skyrim , you can install Mods for this game to make your gaming experience better but i wouldn't see why you would want to, The game is good already.Pros:- Very good gameplay- Good storyline- It makes you want to play more.Cons:- The graphics could be improved ( in my opinion).I will give this game a 9.98/10 because i am a graphics fanboy so that 0.02 percent that didn't get added was because of the graphics but it's a Splendid game.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
SPLENDIDPROS+Awesome dialogue+S.P.E.C.I.A.L.+Perks and skill system+Fascinating characters (Lanius, Ulysses, and so on...)+Weapon mods+Gripping story+Branching questline+Weapons and armor variation+Black jack+Equally interesting factions (NCR, Legion, etc.)+Hardcore mode+Mods+Huge amount of side quests+Great DLCs+Satisfying endingsCONS-Really similar to Fallout 3-Weak gunplay without V.A.T.S.-Many bugs and occasional crashes, almost unplayable without anti-crash mods-Boring world, mostly desert and hills-Poor graphics for its timeThe game has a great story and lots of cool characters. Rather than playing Fallout 4 first, I would recommend either this or Fallout 3. I am only bothered by the crashes and the empty world of New Vegas, other than that this game is awesome!Rate: 8/10

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												You start the game dead and buried, and unearthed by your robot companion who hates you. A kindly doctor breathes life back into you before sending you off to fight in the arena you later learn is New Vegas and it's surrounding desert. Giant scorpions and bandits who explode when punched dot the landscape, eager to greet you with grenades and gunfire as you pop their heads using your godhand and wristwatch calculator. Wearing glasses improves your stats, boosting you from an average Joe to a green beret as soon as you put them on. Ghouls prove to be the most loyal creatures in this game, probably because they understand you're just as dead on the inside as they are.Vegas itself is heavily guarded but not really that interesting, since everything is broken in Fallout except the super computers on top of very tall towers which remain undamaged by the global nuclear destruction.Augementing yourself with a government issue nano-suit, you eventually punch, kick and jab your way to revenge, impaling the villain on a pool cue with the rest of his evil brethren.It's then revealed that computers are the source of all life's misery, and you're given a crucial choice to play the game out or end it there.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												I got so many and mixed feelings for this game. Fallout 3 was mindblowngly good and I had some expectations from New Vegas. I knew it couldn't look like a major AAA title release if it stood in front of FO3, but I was expecting more.Allow me to make things as simple as I can.PROS✔ Loved finding interesting places in the map while scavenging. You can find useful stuff in every corner. There's some attention to the detail in a few settings, like finding hideouts and lookout points that made you feel that someone indeed lived and died there some time ago.✔ Relived the glorious Fallout environment. I enjoyed it, I felt all that overdose of nostalgia left inside me ever since I played FO3.✔ Tribal, racial, community differences. Man I loved exploring them, finding out their background stories. Deciding their future. We need more of that!✔ Side quests with story impact. You know I'm not talking about how one can change a game's ending. But more like how NPCs treat you and talk to you, the way they appreciate you or hate you depending your actions and quests and decisions. i really enjoyed it. it made me feel that what I did mattered, it helped me get into character. It felt like an actually successful RPG element✔ Crafting. ♥♥♥♥ yeah crafting and disassembling stuff rules!✔ Mods. No need to same more. Blow your brains out with tons of them.CONS✖ Terribly limited. One can literally learn byheart every corner of the map. You can literally use and craft every single piece of material in the game in much less time than you could in FO3 or in any elder scrolls game. WTF? Why so small? This game was out as a stand alone title, full priced and with DLCs. There's no excuse to give players such a limited world to roam in!✖ Endless desert. What's up with that? Too bored to design different environments?✖ Cowboy cult. No need to say more.✖ Buggy. It unfortunately still is. My latest example is that my first main character got bugged into a female voice somewhere near the end. Even some NPCs greeted me as a woman lol ✖ Uninteresting story, FO-wise. Nothing memorable to it. No big scale ideals. No massive plans. Just a small story about taking over New Vegas under a power of your choice and a war of hardly 50 NPCs scale. You can literally speedrun the main quest in 2 hours without spending one single bullet and finish it at level 7 or 8.MIXED☢ There were some little graphical improvements done here. I loved the physics from body animations and face expressions. There were tiny bit gore details added when it comes to body dismemberment. Though the rest of the whole game felt exactly the same with FO3. Same engine, same environmental effects and physical geometrical interactions.☢ The voice acting was so carefully done for so many named characters. However the generic onelined greeting and goodbyeing was ridiculously off. For example you could speak to Melissa Watkins in the Brotherhood of Steel, who is designed to have the voice of a young girl, and there was no way in freakin hell you wouldn't miss that different deep mature female voice saying "hello" or "goodbye".☢ Music. To put it simply; I enjoyed the way all levels and moments were designed to much a musical background, the way only Bethesda knows how to introduce, but there's absolutely nothing memorable to it. There's simply no OST value. ☢ DLCs. Gun Runners’ Arsena and Courier’s Stash should had been given to players at RELEASE and not make then pay extra for them. Also in the rest of DLCs introduced there are major environmental designs showoffs. I REALLY enjoyed most of my DLC gameplay (well except the proximity deaths in Dead Money) but they all left me with the taste of unsatisfaction. They could only make nature and massive city designs just for the DLC? Why? Did the developers got too bored to give us that awesome design concept in the main game so they went on to demo-introduce it to us in tiny short bits of experiences? This is not what I would expect to happen in FO4. They better use the information they got from feedbacks to make an awesome job for the next title! Environment is one of the keys of success for this franchise!!☢ 100% game completion including quests and achievements is more like a chore than a unique experience. After 245 hrs on record in this game, I can safely say as much.FINALMy fellow Fallout fans. I'm a fan of the franchise too. But we need more than that in our games.FO:NV is an example of trying to juice out money from the pockets of a crowd that begs for new content.When Bethesda can prove to make wonders just like how FO:3 turned out, we need to expect nothing less than more major game releases with great improvements. Not modified versions of a previous title with a different story-to-be-told shoved in it and push it out the market to make more money.I'm giving Fallout: New Vegas a 6/10. It would had been an 8 or a 9 if they were more inovative with environmental designs. And it could easily drop down to 4 or 5 for all the reasons regarding lazy money making titles.It made me feel that I played a slightly above average game. It left me with tons of mixed feelings.I hope the next title will blow our minds off like FO3 did.Grab it only on special offersCheers

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I remember playing Fallout 2 for countless hours and the same thing applies with NV too. Well, actually I've played it 220+ hours via Steam and some tens of hours from the dvd. It's my third time I'm playing through Fallout NV story. First two times I went without DLC but now I got subplots along the main story aswell. New Vegas is huge and there's simply tons of stuff to go through. The story is catchy but maybe not as good as in the previos parts. The Legion, a well organized group of savages dressed like ancient Romans, is a little bit silly crowd to think living in a post-nuclear wasteland. That's probably the most annoying detail in the story. Other than that, I can't really blame the designers not putting enough effort on the story. Story 8/10In Fallout 3, the wasteland was huge and so it is in New Vegas. However, this time most of the irritating (invisible) obstacles that limit player's movements are removed or replaced with more plausible obstacles. Movement and HUD is pretty much the same as in Fallout 3. Again, a lot of time is spent with the pip boy. Using it simple but somewhat inflexible. Companions get lost sometimes in rugged environment but usually they'll find their way back to the player without any bigger hassle. Player can choose whether to fight taking turns or without and it works nicely. Taking turns feels safer what comes to spending ammo aiming a running enemy in the limbs or head is usually sketchy. Gameplay 8/10The overall graphics are fine: nothing extremely beautiful but works nicely in a story that takes place in a wasteland. Sometimes some shining surfaces look plastic especially when moving around with the flash light on and it actually gives me a headache. Soundscape is minimalistic yet working. Appearance 8½/10Overall experience is really good. At least I got what I wanted and I'm really happy with the game. Yes, there are some bugs and issues with the game but considering the extent of the game these flaws are somewhat acceptable. Moreover, gameplay works most of the time smoothly, so the good experience is not often disturbed. Maybe the best way to describe Fallout New Vegas is that the game holds on to its addictivity and after finishing the story for the first time there's still a lot of stuff to do. In general, this post-apocalyptic concept simply works. In my opinion, Fallout New Vegas might be the second best part of the Fallout franchise after Fallout 2, and not even far behind the first place.For a Fallout franchise fan New Vegas is a must-have, and it gives a good run for a Fallout-newbie's money as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												A fun and frothy experience best coupled with a tall glass of your favorite champaign, and a bowl dead fish stuff.  "Fallout: New Vegas" Is no doubt, an exquisite entertaining digital experience that will leave you satisfied, and yet, will you thirsty for more like a lowlife drunken mongrel who would sell his own mother for just a small sip of alcohol. Of course you withold such pleasures from the desprate man so that he may squirm and shiver for your own entertainment, and with his last bit of strength you promise him he could have the whole bottle if he would just get up do a little jig. Then you sit there, drinking his booze and laughing at him proclaiming "dance, little man dance!" Hahaha. Yes. Quite so. There is no doubt that "Fallout: New Vegas" is a standout amongst it's peers. Though never quite acheiving the sublimity of it's predecessor "Fallout 3", It is still remains  devilishly good fun. By jove, nothing beats the look on the face of unsuspecting passerby as you unceremonously rob him of all he posesses, and then stab him right in the back. Of course there are a number of unsavory mutant types roaming the world. Even the thought of them makes me shiver with terror. But they can be useful in pinch, believe you me, when there is a job that needs doing, a mutant or a raider will get the job done better then anyone else. Or at least good enough. Oh and then there is the music. Simplicity itself. Frank Sinatra would be proud to hear the roaring sounds of Vegas, that once paradice on earth, blasting from the spearks of your personal computer as you blow away yet another unsuspecting innocent with a rocket launcher. Well that's all I have to leave you with for now, dear reader. Enjoy your new digital experience, and remember during those moments of village onslaught, or wandering into some dangerous unknown area with strange green men who own big guns, there is always the load function to start over. Pleasant voyage friend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2012
												The younger and more attractive sister of Fallout 3, New Vegas takes pretty much everything 3 does and makes it better. The gameplay is better, the story has more depth to it, and the setting is just wonderful. It's also worth noting that FO3 wasn't 100% accurate to the FO lore, whereas this isn't the case with FONV.If you're familiar with FO3, FONV's gameplay is basically the same, with a few neat additions. If you're not, think of an FPS mixed with an open world action RPG that's broken up by dialog choices and searching for stuff. It really gets at the survivalist mentality that a lot of people seem to be getting into these days.Where FONV differs from the original, outside the obvious gameplay additions, is the story elements. The characters really feel alive in FONV, there's a real charm that New Vegas has that just makes you fall in love. I wish I had more room to talk about it, the FEEL of the game is just so fantastic.Anyway, I highly recommend this game. Highly replayable.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I remember playing Fallout 2 for countless hours and the same thing applies with NV too. Well, actually I've played it 220+ hours via Steam and some tens of hours from the dvd. It's my third time I'm playing through Fallout NV story. First two times I went without DLC but now I got subplots along the main story aswell. New Vegas is huge and there's simply tons of stuff to go through. The story is catchy but maybe not as good as in the previos parts. The Legion, a well organized group of savages dressed like ancient Romans, is a little bit silly crowd to think living in a post-nuclear wasteland. That's probably the most annoying detail in the story. Other than that, I can't really blame the designers not putting enough effort on the story. Story 8/10In Fallout 3, the wasteland was huge and so it is in New Vegas. However, this time most of the irritating (invisible) obstacles that limit player's movements are removed or replaced with more plausible obstacles. Movement and HUD is pretty much the same as in Fallout 3. Again, a lot of time is spent with the pip boy. Using it simple but somewhat inflexible. Companions get lost sometimes in rugged environment but usually they'll find their way back to the player without any bigger hassle. Player can choose whether to fight taking turns or without and it works nicely. Taking turns feels safer what comes to spending ammo aiming a running enemy in the limbs or head is usually sketchy. Gameplay 8/10The overall graphics are fine: nothing extremely beautiful but works nicely in a story that takes place in a wasteland. Sometimes some shining surfaces look plastic especially when moving around with the flash light on and it actually gives me a headache. Soundscape is minimalistic yet working. Appearance 8½/10Overall experience is really good. At least I got what I wanted and I'm really happy with the game. Yes, there are some bugs and issues with the game but considering the extent of the game these flaws are somewhat acceptable. Moreover, gameplay works most of the time smoothly, so the good experience is not often disturbed. Maybe the best way to describe Fallout New Vegas is that the game holds on to its addictivity and after finishing the story for the first time there's still a lot of stuff to do. In general, this post-apocalyptic concept simply works. In my opinion, Fallout New Vegas might be the second best part of the Fallout franchise after Fallout 2, and not even far behind the first place.For a Fallout franchise fan New Vegas is a must-have, and it gives a good run for a Fallout-newbie's money as well.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												I finally hit 20 hours after about a month and 12 days (thats a guess) of owning F:NV. I love this game, but it has many many flaws. First off, the open world is pretty big. That isnt normally a bad thing, but when you walk slower than a crippled old lady going up a steep staircase. Seriously, and when you press shift it make you even slower! Besides that, this game is extremely difficult for first tim Fallout players. This was mty first Fallout game. I bought it because I wanted to play one of the older Fallout games before I bought Fallout 4. Also, the open world is pretty dull. It's just a desert with some occasional towns. And the Strip is extremely small and not what the first few hours of this game makes it seem like.  Also, loading screens feel more like a teacher giving a boring lesson becuase they take forever. But if you look past this games flaws, F:NV might be one of the best games on Steam.First off, I love the faction system. I joined the legion, and from that I was rewarded with occasional supply drops of ammo and other useful items. This game is definitely rewarding. Also, I love the plot in this game and how it isn't 80% cutscenes. In fact, the only cutscene I've seen so far is the intro, which is only 6 or 7 minutes long. There is ADS, but I personally don't use it much. VATS are pretty useful for close quarters combat. Lockpicking is awesome, and even better on PC. I know this game is old, but there should seriousy be a Steam Workshop for this game. I mean, people mod this game as much as people mod Skyrim, so I dont see why there Isn't a Workshop.Overall though, I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a good story, a good RPG and an amazing game. Whether it's on sale or not, you should buy F:NV, and maybe even the Ultimate Editon for double price and all the DLC.I'd love feedback on this review, so please tell me what you think! Enjoy Fallout New Vegas!Edit:I just finished F:NV. Wow. I loved it. Except for one thing that makes this different from other RPG's.  After completing the main story, it takes you back to the main menu, and asks you if you want to load a previous save. In other words, you cannot explore the Mojave or do side quests. Also, this game has a painfully low level cap of 30. While it does take some time to level up, this is an extremely small level cap. With DLC, though, the level cap is 50 (Each DLC adds 5 levels to the level cap). As I did the final mission, I began to notice some things. First, using guns continuously for a long time makes them feels weird. Basically what I'm trying to say is that the gunplay feels a little off. This somewhat forces you to rely on V.A.T.S. most of the time. But let me say what I have noticed about the game from finishing it that I did enjoy. I definitely noticed that ADS is important at one point, especially with long range kills. Before I wrap this up I want to point out that this game felt kind of short. I expecting a longer campaign, but atleast the replay value is extremely high. So, to wrap this up, (at least for now,) I want say that even though it felt short, and the gunplay feels awkward, and the level cap is very low, I can still say that Fallout: New Vegas is one of, if not the, best games I've ever played and you should definitely buy it, sale or not, Ultimate Edition or normal.(Yes I know that was the longest sentence ever) I plan on buying the DLC for F:NV soon, and I'll do another edit if on what the game is like with DLC. Buying and investing hours of my time into Fallout: New Vegas is one of the best choices I've ever made, and I plan to do it all again.Also I'd like to mention the fact that I have almost 30 hours of gameplay and I've only come across one Deathclaw. Just a little strange to me.March 21, 2016: EDIT 2: I want to point out something. F:NV is only ten dollars without DLC, (I bought it for $2.49 on sale) and I've managed to get 30 hours from it. Some have even got hundreds of hours of gameplay. Think about that. 30 hours, and thats just the main storyline. Yeah, some games are longer, but for this pricetag, that's a lot of gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Fallout: New Vegas is a great game for Fallout fans, old and new. You could help Caesar rid the wasteland of all threats but at a lost for freedom for many. You could help NCR take over but listen to their rules and laws. Let anarchy rule the wastes, but let all be free. Or let Robert House gain total control over the Mojave. One of the terrible parts of the game is the fact that you cannot play after The Second Battle of Hoover Dam. You could destroy all factions, major (such as the Legion) or minor (such as the Kings). You can decide wheter to spare or kill the man who shot the Courier. It shows in-game that starting off as someone of minor abilites could make a large difference, as all Fallout games do, and shows that actions have consequences, good or bad.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2013
												Very, very, very fun game. There are many mods for this game so it won't get boring for a couple hundred hours. One new feature about New Vegas is that now there are factions and you choose what factions to help and how the Mojave will be changed by that faction. Karma isn't a big thing in this game, instead it is more focused on factions. Be careful though, if you help out one faction, you might make another faction hate you. The storyline starts off slow but gets more exciting later. While the main story is somewhat short (13 hours) there are many sidequests to do along with sweet guns, secrets, references to movies and cool DLCS. Steam doesn't put this game on sale that often anymore so if you see it go on sale, add it to your cart quickly! I say it is totally worth $20. The only cons about this game are the glitches. But you can get a mod to patch it. Although, after you reach level 30, the adventure sort of stops because you can no longer gain XP to level up. Another cool thing about the game are the vault's stories. Just go and check some of them out. One last downside to the game is that you cannot continue after you beat the main story so you have to continue a previous save and explore all the cool places the Mojave has to offer. Although some of them are a little dull because it is nothing but a shack. Other than that this game is pretty sweet.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												One of my personal all-time favourites, Fallout: New Vegas is an amazing entry into the franchise. It includes great RPG elements and a fantastic storyline with several choices available for the player to become immersed in the massive and detailed frontier of the Mojave Wasteland, which has many locations and factions that the player can choose to side with- or destroy.An entertaining combat system is introduced, with iron sights and cinematic kills aided by the satisfying VATS.NPCs and companions are better than ever, as almost every character has their own unique tale to tell and can be linked with a large amount of side quests and unmarked quests, without over-using generic fetch quests and other repetitive mechanics to keep the player occupied.One of the best things about this game is the outstanding modding community, which keeps the game supplied with new content even today, 3 years after its release. From graphics enhancements to new quests, items, locations and characters, it can all be used to make this game even better. I highly recommend this game as it's worth every penny, especially right now with the current Steam sales.
