content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												One of the best games I've ever played. You can get so many hours out of this game; I only have 25 at the moment but I only got this game recently on PC, I've mostly played it on 360. There are so many different ways to play, I've started at least four different files and each one felt entirely unique.  Add modding and you've got a game that can last you a long time. Also, this game can run on pretty low-end PCs, which is always a plus. If you don't like the graphics, there are a ton of ENBs as well. And don't even get me started on the DLCs; all four are absolutely amazing. Overall, the only negative thing I can say about this game is that it can be glitchy at times, but they can be funny and there are a ton of fix mods to remove them. $20 is a steal of a price for such an amazing game, and if that's still too pricey, New Vegas is extremely cheap during sales. 10/10ASSUME THE POSITION

												Fallout: New Vegas has definitely improved on some technicalities of its predecessors such as weapons, dialogues and the like. If you are a fan of the series, it is a good game anyway. Nevertheless, I did not enjoy the story as much as in Fallout 3. Your only goal seems to reach New Vegas and once you are there you wander around aimlessly at first. I also did not like the supposedly open choice of which group to join when the game makes it pretty clear who the good guys are, i.e. who you should be joining. Despite this, there are fun quests and places and I enjoyed the allies way more than in Fallout 3. I'd be a Yesman any day for that fun robot!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A game of endless content. Great replay value with many different endings depending on the many -sometimes quite difficult, polically or ethically charged- dicisions made. I must've sunk over 400 hours into it (before I owned it on Steam) and on every playthrough I discover new area's and side-stories. When you finally think you've really seen it all... you get into modding. This is when you find out that all flaws that you used to ignore because the rest of the game is so awesome, have been fixed by the community along with plenty new game mechanics, tweaks and hours, no, days of extra, often fully voice-acted content. I would say this is my favorite game without a doubt, if not for the other masterpieces that have been created with the same engine: Elder Scrolls IV and Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Well, here's my review of Fallout New Vegas. I am going to put it in English and in Spanish, so, let's start.I recommend that game, because (in a part I love Fallout) it's fantastic! You can go wherever you want, you can do whatever you want, and you can find weapons, and buy modifications. You can explore the Vaults, with the terminals understand what happened there, and there's one Vault, where, is an arsenal (obviously the Vault is dangereous because there are a lot of gouls and Gecos), where you can find an unique and super special weapon, The Patriot. It's a Tirator Carabine, but with a lot of more damage. You, in Fallout New Vegas (ALERT SPOILER COMING), in the finale, you can fight with Caesar, Mister House, or the RNC for the Hoover Damm. For me, that game it's fantastic, and in the 10th of november, this year, IS GOING TO COME FALLOUT 4!!.SPANISHYo, recomiendo este juego, porqué (a parte, me encanta Fallout) ¡es fantastico! Puedes ir dónde quieras, hacer lo que quieras, puedes encontrar armas, y comprar modificaciones. Puedes explorar los Vaults (Refugios), con los ordenadores puedes entender que pasó allí, y, hay un Refugio, en el qué, hay un arsenal (obiamente el Refugio es peligroso porqué hay un montón de Necrófagos y Gecos), donde puedes encontrar un arma única y super especial. La Patriota. Es un rifle de Tirador, con un montón de daño. Tú, en Fallout New Vegas (ALERTA SPOILER EN CAMINO), en el final, puedes luchar con Cesar, el Señor House, o la RNC, por la Presa Hoover. Para mí, este juego es fantástico, y en el 10 de noviembre de este año, SALE FALLOUT 4!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Almost perfection, I could honestly talk about this game for hours. I'd recommend it to just about anyone whose into dark settings and high quality storytelling as well as characters that really make you think. With like 3 or 4 mods this game is a perfect 10 to me. It's a shame the game launched in such a broken state.             Okay, so I've played through the game 3 times and all of the dlc twice, I've actually only run into a small amount of bugs, things such as scorpions spawning in the grounds with their tails sticking out of the sand, a dog with eyes floating on the side of his head, getting stuck inside rocks a couple times which is easily fixed through tcl or reloading a save and one single quest breaking bug out of the 173 quests in the game including dlc and not including the miscellaneous quests. I also ran into 1 save corruption. That's it, maybe I'm just lucky idk but my experience was relatively bug free. Just save often and you'll avoid these problems by reloading. I also get crashes which seems to be kind of unavoidable with these games but it doesn't happen as often as it does in skyrim, fallout 3 or oblivion for me personally.        I could talk about the story and characters forever and how well done they all are. Veronica, Boone, Joshua Graham and Mr House to name a few were all awesome. Mr House specifically sticks out as a character I could talk about for a very long time. I continue to think about these characters long after I finish the game. Obsidian really went out of their way to give the characters depth on a level that is competetive with bioware games. Something that most of the time Bethesda doesn't even attempt to do.                I don't know what else to say without extending the review for too long. I obviously recommend this game, it's well worth your time and money but if you're new to the Fallout series I'd still recommend you play FO3 or FO1 first. FO3 is a great way to introduce yourself to the setting but if you play FO3 and miss out on New Vegas you really are robbing yourself of a complete experience. I feel like Fallout 3 is the first quarter and New Vegas is like the last 3 quarters that completes the experience and makes it a real sequel to fallout 1 and 2. Everyone should experience both games. To me this is a 9.5 without mods and on launch it would probably be lower because of how broken I hear it was. If you like fallout 1,2 or 3 play this game, it's worth it, just remember to eat, drink and take several breaks because this game will grab you by the balls and won't let go until it's over.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Fallout New Vegas is a wonderful game, incorperating many elements within from quality of items to karma, appealing to people and keeping yourself alive. Weapons, armor, and many other items are found all throughout the game, and the dlc expand the base game way more. A bonus Hardcore mode makes the game even more realistic, allowing you to have to juggle hunger, hydration, and sleep, and more realistic item settings and ingame stats, which are detailed ingame. Post apocolyptic wasteland is so fun to explore, and the story is actually strewn through all the dlc as well, with many interconnected stories that can intertwine and unlock new options and dialogue. Speaking of dialogue, there are many, many options of dialogue, and skill set and specific attributes can influence dialogue, among other things that are affected. They thought of many different aspects of the game and beautifully blended the game operations together. I love this game so much, despite it being over 4 years old, because it plays so well, and is so well crafted, that i play this game over and over again, and my Steam playtime is not an accurate display of my love for this game. I have Probably 300+ hours into this game on my ps3, and it is still fuin everytime I play the game, no matter the platform. I highly recommend this game, and its predasessor, Fallout 3 with all the dlc as well. I would say play the old one first, as it has some different elements to it, and the feel is very different as well. I love this game so much, and believe everyone should play this game.

The expierence offered is nothing short of spectacular, it's one of the few games I have replayed on multiple occasions to completion and enjoyed every time. content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Every fallout game is a must-play, but if your looking for a more fleshed out Fallout 3 taking place in a more wastelandy region, (Nevada) then this is for you.Not only is this game easy to get into as a noobie to the fallout series, but it is equally as easy to get into as a fan of the fallout series. This is mainly due to plenty of easter-eggs and nods to the classic fallout games.Many people complain that the fallout engine's shooting mechanics aren't very good. That is horse♥♥♥♥♥♥ The shooting mechanics feel good on all weapons. Not a big fan of shooting? Try hitting a giant mutant fire ant with a sledgehammer. Not into hitting things with sledgehammers? You can beat the entire game by just punching everything! Its hard but you can.Fallout is one of the only games in the history of RPG's that is a FPS. It is also, literally, the only game on the market where you can just straight up kill everyone and everything. Not interested in getting revenge? Just kill everyone in town and make it your outpost! Sick of the casino henchmen saying baby all the time? Bring a grenade launcher into the lobby and kill everbody!I have played this game for a ridiculous amount of time. Yet, I still havent found everything in the game. There are still secret weapons, quests, companions, etc. that I have not looted, complete, or met. Even if you do, somehow, find everything in the vanilla game, there are still very cheap dlc you can get, that add loads of new content. Are you so much of a badass that you find and do everything in the DLC too? Fallout New Vegas has a rich modding community.Simply google, "FNV Nexus" into your local google-o-tron and you will find, literally, thousands of mods that will either add something incredible, or change the entirety of the game mechanics.If you totally have no social life at all, and finish every mod ever made, including the constant pipeline of daily content being added for you, you can always make your own mods with the very interesting Fallout SDK. Make your own quests, make your own kingdom, make your own virtual girlfriend (That you most definitely need), not even the sky can limit you!I give Fallout New Vegas:10/10"Like skyrim with guns"If you liked this guide then go ♥♥♥♥ yourself and spend that time playing the game.

												First off, don't believe all that stuff about the game running like♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics being sucky, everything just being awful, it being boring, etc, etc. It's only boring if you try to have no fun. The wasteland is...Supposed to be a wasteland...Some parts...Are irradiated because they're supposed to be...Be a mann and wade through that radioactive sewage! Be a mann and kill those deathclaws! And if this game bores you, just do whatever the hell you want in it. Get power armor and blow up the BOS Bunker with 20200102001 dynamite, slash through hordes of ghouls, just murder everyone. And if murdering everyone and satisfying your bloodlust isn't enough, do it for the nostalgia. And if nostalgia isn't enough/doesn't exist, avoid this game.Gud?1. Many hours of gameplay, many places to explore.2. You get to do whatever you really want to do. Usually with consequences, but go ahead, kill everyone! It's fun!3. Mods. Are. Amazing.4. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Fallout New Vegas:     FNV is an open world, action rpg set in a post-apocalyptic Mojave desert, with civilization starting to re-emerge out of the ashes. The fairly large map (21 square miles) surrounds one of the few places doing relatively well in the wasteland: Vegas. The landscape in vegas can sometimes be a bore, with a lot of dry rolling hills around you, but the excellent 30's, 40's, and 50's music will make you forget all that, and just hum along.      Story wise, FNV is not amazing, but still good. In the opening cinematic, you, a simple courier for the mojave express company, gets shot straight in the head by a suave, but evil and cocky son-of-a-gun fellow named Benny. Once you are healed in the nearby town of goodsprings, your new goal is to hunt him down and bring him to justice. The story brings the player around the whole map, greeting the player with dozens of side quests. Once the player finally does kill Benny, the story really takes off, allowing the player to join one of the three factions viyng for power, or take over by yourself. The three faction are :The New California Republic, a gorup wanting to bring back the world before the apocalypse, Ceasers legion, a crazy dicator bent on ruling like a roman emperor, and Mr.House, a high tech robot wanting to bring back the 'glory of vegas'.    Gameplay is where this game truly shines. With the old-school RPG like character creation complete with a plethora of unique and fun perks, you can create a variety of different classes, each with their own playstyle, allowing for a lot of replayability. There are dozens of different weapons varying from a simple smg, or an orbital strike cannon, or a plasma rifle, a super-sword thing, and dozens more. With the expansive map filled with locations ranging from a ski lodge with super-mutants, to deep vaults giant fire ants, the postapocalyptic world is a truly crazy place.      FNV is not perfect, though there are hundreds of bugs and glitches, which is to be expected with a game of this size. Some of the quests are bland, and some of the locations are quite small and boring. There seems to also be only a few voice actors, evenif thats not the case. Most of these problems can be fized with mods, which brings me to my next point:the excellent modding community. There are hundreds and thousands of mods on the nexus and various other sites, ranging from high quality lore friendly quests, to crazy weapon packs, graphical overhauls, spiderman cars, companion mods, bug fixes, to more risque things.     With the points made above, I strongly reccomend this game to anybody who loves rpg's action games, well written experiences, and pretty much anyone who has likes video games. I do not reccomend this to a completionist though, much like Skyrim, the buggy quests, and the sheer size of the game makes it quite hard to 100% complete, and maybe not in a good way. To anybody else that likes anything, by this game now.Score(do I need this?) = 8.5/10With mods = 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas transports the player to a completely different world. The introductory video will introduce you to people and factions who will become your greatest enemies and your best friends, but it's left up to you to decide who is who. Playing as an amensiac courier, you must piece together your own past, but when you have all the facts, it's time to decide the future. You face difficult choices that will influence the rest of the storyline which culminate in the Battle of Hoover Dam, but your story isn't over. A final video extends the stories of communities and characters well into the future based on your actions.The iconic Fallout style shows throughout the game, and many old factions are shown in a refreshing light. Each faction has a unique style, philosophy, and history, that can only be gleaned through extensive dialogue options.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												As a huge fan of Fallout 3 I decided to go back to NV, even though my first playthrough was rather unsatisfactory. This time around I started modding with Project Nevada, and used a little metagaming because NV isn't all that RP friendly, but you do get used to it. On my first playthrough, my PC died during the last part of the game and took me a few months before I concluded my save file, only to get smacked in the face with a no-playing-after-main-quests-are-done scenario, and because I only just tried to get into it again I dropped it and went and played Fallout 3. Now that I'm playing again I plan on getting all the DLCs done and beat the game on hardcore.So I'll start with the positives. Firstly, the lore and setting of the Fallout Universe is such a great concept and allows for interesting stories and quests, however, I do feel FONV didn't quite take full advantage of the series' potential, but I'll get to that when I go over the negatives. I really enjoy open-world, sandboxy games, and being able to walk from one place to another is a feature that gives the game good immersion value. Combat system is lovely, using both skill and level to determine your performance, it's an aspect of the game I really like. Being able to chose what you say and influence how the story plays out is a mechanic that is essential to a Fallout game, and I think New Vegas did this well, with the odd forced-response here and there.One of the big flaws with the game is that you, The Courier, aren't motivated to do anything. Throughout the first segment of the game, it totally assumes you're going after the guy who shot you (Benny) because you want revenge, but if the character you've created doesn't want revenge, then they're stuck twiddling their thumbs in Goodsprings until you decide that your character is explorative and you wander off to some random place in the tiny Mojave Wasteland, with like, 4 towns. Which brings me to my second criticism; the world is tiny, there's barely anywhere to go, and no motivation for The Courier to go there. Finally, the game is unbalanced and glitchy without mods, some enemies, especially at low levels are bullet sponges that lead to conflicts that go for too long, get boring and frustrating.Overall, FONV is an amazing game to play through and I highly recommend mods when doing so. I still enjoy Fallout 3 more but I've essentially played that game to death, hopefully FO4 is released before I'm bored with New Vegas.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												So I did a review of Fallout 3 a couple years ago, and I forgot to do one of Fallout New Vegas.  Suprizingly I actually liked FNV better than F3!  Fallout New Vegas carries on the awesome open world RPG gameplay that is found in many other Bethesda games. It is so addictive and entertaining!  FNV added a lot of things that were either lacking or not done as well in F3.  I happen to be a bit of a gun nut in real life, and this game hits home hard for those of use that are into firearms.  The amount of real-world accurate weapons in the game is mind boggling.  I think that FNV is one of the reasons I got into reloading my own ammunitions.  I loved that feature. The environment is FNV is also much more dazling and rich than the environment in F3.  You get the sense that you are really out in the wild west wasteland, where life is beginning to spring back, and people have dropped into their western dog-eat-dog lifestyle.  I played the game through between 2-3 times, and found that I most enjoyed playing as a desperado vagabond that went around doing good for the needy and mercilessly destroying any enemies.  The RP aspect is much deeper than F3, and perhaps moreso than Skyrim.If you have any doubts whether to buy this game, do it.  do it now...or when it goes on sale.  You won't regret it!  Please give us Fallout 4 Bethesda!!!! Put the Elder Scrolls on hold!

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												*10.6h played on PC, +500h total including PS3*This game is in my opinion the best Fallout inthe franchise. The missions (both main and sidequests) are interesting and varied, the combat is exciting at higher difficulties, the exploration aspect is very enticing because of the multitude of places and buildings you can stumble upon during your playthrough. The game is very fun overall and has a lot of replayability value due to the multiple paths and factions you can take on. There are a variety of weapons and armor that let you follow multiple different playstyles, such as a sniper, a run-and-gun guy, an explosives expert, etc. However, there are bad points too. The game for one, has some weaknesses due to time constraints during development on Obsidian's side. So there is some cut content and some aspects of the game that feel hollow and leave a lot to desire, like the Legion, which is sadly very shallow. And another thing I dislike is that the game is not as difficult as it should be. Hardcore mode doesn't punish enough and it's not too difficult to eat, drink and sleep in the Mojave, you just have to keep an eye on the counter and that's that. Both these issues can be fixed with mods, so yeah, hooray for PC!To grossly sum it up: it's fun, it's crazy, it may make you play for weeks or months, mods are a thing for this and will make you stay for much longer and hardcore mode is not as hardcore as one may think at first.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas - Welcome to Vegas. New Vegas. It’s the kind of town where you dig your own grave prior to being shot in the head and left for dead…and that’s before things really get ugly. It’s a town of dreamers and desperados being torn apart by warring factions vying for complete control of this desert oasis. It’s a place where the right kind of person with the right kind of weaponry can really make a name for themselves, and make more than an enemy or two along the way. As you battle your way across the heat-blasted Mojave Wasteland, the colossal Hoover Dam, and the neon drenched Vegas Strip, you’ll be introduced to a colorful cast of characters, power-hungry factions, special weapons, mutated creatures and much more. Choose sides in the upcoming war or declare “winner takes all” and crown yourself the King of New Vegas in this follow-up to the 2008 videogame of the year, Fallout 3. Enjoy your stay.Key Features Feel the Heat in New Vegas! Not even nuclear fallout could slow the hustle of Sin City. Explore the vast expanses of the desert wastelands – from the small towns dotting the Mojave Wasteland to the bright lights of the New Vegas strip. See the Great Southwest as could only be imagined in Fallout. Feuding Factions, Colorful Characters and a Host of Hostiles! A war is brewing between rival factions with consequences that will change the lives of all the inhabitants of New Vegas. The choices you make will bring you into contact with countless characters, creatures, allies, and foes, and determine the final explosive outcome of this epic power struggle. New Systems! Enjoy new additions to Fallout: New Vegas such as a Companion Wheel that streamlines directing your companions, a Reputation System that tracks the consequences of your actions, and the aptly titled Hardcore Mode to separate the meek from the mighty. Special melee combat moves have been added to bring new meaning to the phrase “up close and personal”. Use V.A.T.S. to pause time in combat, target specific enemy body parts and queue up attacks, or get right to the action using the finely-tuned real-time combat mechanics. An Arsenal of Shiny New Guns! With double the amount of weapons found in Fallout 3, you’ll have more than enough new and exciting ways to deal with the threats of the wasteland and the locals. In addition, Vault-Tec engineers have devised a new weapons configuration system that lets you tinker with your toys and see the modifications you make in real time. Let it Ride! In a huge, open world with unlimited options you can see the sights, choose sides, or go it alone. Peacemaker or Hard Case, House Rules, or the Wild Card - it’s all in how you play the game.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												If you were planning on buying Fallout New Vegas (or were simply considering it), then I recommend you go for the GOTY edition instead of stock Fallout, as FNV: GOTYE comes with all of the DLC for much cheaper, and the DLC is a lot of what made this game so fun.So for the rest of this review, I am going to assume that you have not gotten any of the DLC. Let's roll.Fallout: New Vegas is a first person shooter RPG and the sequal to Fallout 3. In the game you play as a courier in the city of Las Vegas after a nuclear war. On your way to deliver a mysterious package which was turned down by the previous courier, you are captured by a thug named Benny, who steals your delivery before shooting you in the head twice and burying you.Somehow, however, you manage to survive the gunshot wounds to your cranium and are dug up by a robot named Victor and brought to a doctor in goodsprings. This is where the game begins. As the doctor goes through your medical exam, you get to customize your character to your liking, changing their looks, stats, and starting abilities.As you progress, you come to your first decision in the game, where an escaped convict named Joe Cobb threatens Goodsprings because they are holding someone inside the gas station who Joe wants dead. You are given the choice between joining the powder gangers or holding up a defense against them in goodsprings, or even leaving the whole incident alone.The game has a load of weapons, armor, and items to collect, and many different character and faction builds. From what I have gathered, there are 4 different main endings, followed by an explaination of what happened to all of the other characters and locations you met during your journey.Overall, I would highly reccomend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Fallout new vegas, developed by Bethesda and Obsidian, is a beautiful work of art, this game is what Fallout 3 should have been, its emotionally driven, every person you meet game is perfect. Most of the Side Quest/Stories are well writen.The DLC's and Main Story truely what classifies this game Art. When you leave Doc Mitchells you truely feel free, being able to truely do what ever you want.The atomsphere of this game sometimes reminds me of Mad Max sometimes, due to lonely of the wastes, other times you feel like youre middle of war soon to be over (Depending of your Choices In game.)You as the Courier, are shot in the head and left for dead, but by luck, you are saved by a friendly robot named Victor.He takes you to Doc Mitchells house to get patched up.After leaving his house, its your choice what you do after words.The DLC's (these go in the order they were realeased)1. Dead MoneyDead money is one of the best DLC's of all time in my eyes, after all its amazing writing and interesting characters will you and the others survive this hellish casino in the heist of a lifetime, or will you be a sole survivor, after all,It's Letting Go...2.Honest Hearts You are hired for the Happy trails caravans to get to Zion Canyon and deliver supplies to the tribes (the Dead Horses and the sorrows) until you are Ambushed by the white legs, you alone survive, after being saved by some Sorrows scouts, they take you to the burned man. the first General of caesar, hes hungry for revenge. Can you and the burned destroy the white legs before its to late?3.Old world bluesThere is a expression in the wasteland, "Old World Blues", it refers to those so obsessed with the past they cant see the present much less the furture, for what it is.They stare into the-what was, eyes like pilot lights, guttering and spent, as realties of their world continue on around them. (Keep that quote in mind when playing this DLC.)4.Lonesome Road All roads must come to a end in this DLC, a battle between you and the last courier.This is a brilliant conclusion to the DLC's, can you survive the divide before the last courier awakens the divide giants.If youre looking for a game that hits home, and makes question your choices, and looking for a beautiful story, I highly recommend this game 101%

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Welcome to the Wasteland. The Mojave Wasteland is exactly that; a Wasteland, with sparsely populated territory, and warring factions trying to divide up what land is 'civilized'. You are a Courier, and you have just been ordered to deliver a strange package. On your way to your destination, you are attacked, and left for dead. From there, your story begins. Do you wander free through the Mojave, slaughtering bloatflies like there is no tomorrow?Do you hook up with the New Californian Republic, or their rivals, Caesar's Legion? Or do you ignore that completely and simply try to track down those who attacked you and get revenge? This game is filled with choice- and the first choice you have to make is "Do I want F:NV?" Yes. Yes, you do.

												i take back what i said a year ago, its worth more than one playthrough, and its good. since i first played it a year ago, i liked it, but then started fallout 3 to find that i enjoyed that one more due to its brutality but i never finished that game. fastforward a year and ive got ~25 hours in skyrim and i need something that is a little less, overwhelming.i reinstalled the game to not only find out that new vegas has cloud support, but that i dumped ~80 hours into the base campaign (well, minus th very last main story quest...) and 2 of the add-on/dlc's ("honest hearts" & "old world blues", both of which i loved); and acording to the wiki, i still got half a map to go through and a look at my pip boy says i got several loose ends to tie up. best part is i get to brave through it with some horrible jack of all trades character i couldnt get to work properly!the only real things i still dislike about the game is cazadores (huge amber wing-colored flies that move at the speed of light compared to your annoying snail's pace), simplistic difficulty setup (needing 300 bullets to kill one creature isnt hard, its just boring, time AND resource-consuming, not making a creative way to ramp up the difficulty of a single-player game just makes the game a drag for those who want a challenge), and the fact that you cant continue to play once you finish the game. thats all i can say that's bad about this game, so buy the ultimate edition now!

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												I ♥♥♥♥ING LOVE THIS GAME!!!I really can't be bothered making some witty insightful or professional statement about the game to open this review because I really can't hold my load for that long. This game is just - wow. This game is a ♥♥♥♥ing masterpiece. It's story, characters, world building, humour, replayabitlity, etc, is through the wanking roof. This is to me what porn is to normal people with lives, jobs, reasons to live, who haven't sunk hours upon hours into this game because they have nothing better to do other than contemplate their miserable, meaningless existence. THANK YOU OBISDIAN!!!This game is so nuanced, so well written, so well thought out in its endings, that it has kept me awake for ♥♥♥♥ing HOURS at night just THINKING about its characters, it's ideas, which ending really is best ♥♥♥♥♥♥ even those Legion♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ISIS in miniskirts, have a reasonable enough sounding leader who provides some genuine criticism of democracy. Still♥♥♥♥♥♥♥though). Which ending really IS best? The NCR (who pretty much represent America) is filled to the♥♥♥♥♥♥with good people with good intentions who could make the wasteland a better place and they can even get you the best short term ending in the game if you play your cards right, but it's crystal clear that they are WAY too corrupt and inefficient to properly maintain their territory in the long term. Mr House (who I imagine would represent the big business and corporate America) has some pretty lofty ideas, good intentions and excellent leadership skills (even wants to recreate civilisation to the point of space travel), but seems incredibly disconnected from the rest of the world, incredibly arrogant, a little bit fascist and authoritarian (though he doesn't wish to intrude upon people's lives or in their private affairs as this would be bad for business) and gets you to whack the Brotherhood of Steel. You COULD just say "♥♥♥♥ it all" and take over yourself, bringing freedom and independence to the Mojave, but with that sort of freedom comes chaos and the place just stays an anarchic wasteland, with no one to keep any sort of order throughout the area. You'll see what I mean better if you just PLAY THE ♥♥♥♥ING GAME ALREADY!!!The DLCs are also pretty GG too, I'll probably write reviews on them too, pick them up. Also, I've heard a lot of people complain that it looks a bit too much like Fallout 3 and looks like Fallout 3 DLC. Those people are all dead now and I haven't actually played Fallout 3 yet as it won't run on Windows 10, but from what I've seen of it, it varies wildly in terms of tone, setting, narrative quality and some other stuff that I can't be bothered going through. What I'm saying is, PLAY THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME ALREADY!!!Also, if you want to do all the main variations of the ending, which you should, do NCR first, independent Vegas second, Legion third and Mr House fourth. I don't know why, it just works that way. The only few flaws I can find with the game are very, very small plot holes in one or two conversations with one or two NPCs that are so inconsequential that I won't bother going into them, the AI's a bit iffy, Benny's voice acting is a bit♥♥♥♥♥♥in parts, Obsidian could maybe have had a bit more time to polish the game a bit (they were only given 18 months after all) and it is a bit glitchy and crashy at times.And in summary - ♥♥♥♥ deathclaws. Also, play this game.

												Overall, a great game and my personal favorite video game. Pros:-Interesting characters and quests-a true fallout game-improves on nearly every aspect of fallout 3-amazing, atmospheric soundtrack-loads of replay value (700+ hrs)-great modding community adds even more replay value-great level design across the board-good optimization-simplisticCons:-low-res, unappealing graphics, even for 2010-poor aiming and combat-main story isn't as engaging or interesting as fallout 3-buggyConclusion:A very unique and well done game that improves upon much of Fallout 3's shortcomings. If you didn't like 3, you probably won't like this game, either. Absolutely worth every dollar. There are so many different ways to approach quests & you can be any character you want: bad, good, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, whatever. There are a wide variety of guns and clothes to choose from. If you like this game at all, it can definitely suck your life away. Better than Fallout 4.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Set in a post-nuclear desert known as the Mojave Wasteland, you are a courier searching for the man who tried to kill you. Weapon sights, more varied perks, cooking and crafting systems, quirkier writing and a larger variety of gear and characters separate NV from Fallout 3. Unfortunately, the graphics are terrible (no environment shadows, muddy textures, undetailed meshes, and so on), AI is laughable, and combat is a mess of suicidal NPCs either strafing or standing completely still. Fortunately, combat isn't all - conversations and the choices you make are important. You'll be able to threaten, praise, blackmail and so on, influencing other people - alongside the impact that your skills, traits and perks also have. Sadly, most characters are boring or lifeless due to sloppy writing, terrible animations and sub-par voice acting. Plagued by design problems, bugs and a disappointing ending, NV is quantity over quality. It gets the job done, but it could have been a lot better.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												What is there to say about the absolutely best game that has ever been created, except that it is the best game ever made?Perhaps that the game is epic in every way possible, that the story is increadibly deep, that there is almost too many guns for you to possible obtain in one gameplay... Wait.. That last one is probably false. But even if you could collect every weapon in the entire game, you sure as hell would never EVER be able to carry all of them. Now where was I?   Yes, there!*clears throat*That you can install mods on most of your weapons, as long as you  have the ultra-cheap DLC "Gun Runners Arsenal", that you can blow/shoot/chop peoples arms/legs/heads of, that you can craft both ammunition and various tools and explosives, that every weapon and armor in the game has got a durability, which means that it will break after you've used it a lot, that the game is increadibly entertaining, humoristic, and silly over all, and of course, that YOU decide exactly what you want to do.If you haven't bought it already, you really should.I assure you, it's worth the money to 110%BUTThere is one downside.The game, at least if you are like me, is addictive as hell.Once I start playing it, it's almost impossible to stop.I guess this pretty much wraps it all up.Also, If you've read this far, you've got to buy the game, or else you and all your family will be brutally butchered while asleep.Good night!

content:
Posted: January 3
												I have too much to say about this game, so I'll keep it short. This is the best first-person Fallout. The story and characters are captivating. Silly, crude, and smart dialouge is around every corner. Intricate quests with many approaches. Lore, lore, lore up the wazoo! It gives you a lot of insight. FNV allows you to role-play as whoever you like. Survivalist, Tech-savvy conman, bare-fisted mongoloid. You can be whoever you want. The dialouge isn't like FO4, with only four options, in the way where you often have many different things to say. And with certain perks you can have special dialouge options. The gameplay is fun, playing like you'd expect a first-person rpg to. Pick things up, upgrade your weapons, buy and sell, use drugs to enhance yourself in battle, but don't get addicted! The combat is satisfying. For example, pulverising an enemy with a minigun, vaporizing them with a laser-rifle, or slicing them to giblets with a ripper. This is my favorite game, jam-packed with content. Get it! And the DLCs, they're some of the best DLC ever made! If only New Vegas still ran, I'd play it so much more. It crashes when I load a game. And remember, patrolling the mojave almost makes you wish for a nuclear winter.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												So it's the second 3-D entry of the Fallout series, after three. And it's by Obsidian, made up of most of the people who created the original fallout games. As a result, the story is much better than fallout three, even if it does not have Liam Neeson in it; it does, however, feature several more big-name actors along with the vastly improved script.There's a whole lot to do in the Mojave Wasteland, including the far west of California, a great part around Las Vegas (named New Vegas here, hence the title) and even a bit of Arizona across the Colorado River. There are beleaguered, desperate humans everywhere, Super Mutants, rogue robots and the two major factions of the New California Republic and Caesar's Legion. And that's just outside New Vegas' gates.Inside the walls of the shining city you will find dens of iniquity galore, as well as the strongest bastion of humanity who wishes to hold out against the horrors of the wasteland. But there's also a mysterious intelligence floating around, whose influence can be felt in every corner: Mr. House. And as the expression goes, the house always wins…So eventually does boil down to which faction you choose to support: the NCR, Caesar's Legion, or Mr. House. But if you can find a certain character in a certain hotel, can find a way to work in support for an independent New Vegas! If you don't like the NCR's militaristic ways, the Legion's slavery or Mr. House's desire to retain his iron grip on absolutely everything within New Vegas, there is a certain Yes Man rolling about who can help you choose the path that you set out for New Vegas.By now you might be wondering, why almost 500 hours played? Well, I'm glad you asked! Again, mods are the order of the day here; little or huge gameplay changes that extend the longevity of the game by leaps and bounds. I highly recommend looking into them.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2010
												The gameplay, while essentially the same, is improved. Ironsighted weapons make for extra degree of immersion or reality to firearms and weapon-modifications take some weapons from good to great  and more. Fallout 1 and 2 fans will notice several nods to the previous games and players of Fallout 3 will also see some nice nods in their direction. The story is more original this time and  quickly becomes more than it seems. Characters are dozens of times more fleshed out than those of Fallout 3 and every companion has their own character, history, and personal quest. Those who look for Dogmeat will be disappointed but for those of you who remember K-9, Rex will be a nice replacement.To put it simply: Fallout: New Vegas is what Fallout 3 should have been and is a game you cannot afford to deprive yourself of. If you mourn the loss of the original FO3, Van Buren then you will see major influences brought from it to New Vegas and it is easily worth the cost.Don't miss this game.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												The game has many pros but also a few cons. The reason I voted Yes is because I enjoyed the game and I think people who love games from the fallout franchise will DEFINETLY enjoy this game.The game might not be in the same level as Fallout 3 but you can easily explain that because two diffrent developers made the games, Fallout 3 was made by Bethesda itself and Fallout : NV was developed by Obsidian - PUBLISHED by Bethesda.The story itself is great, the stability of the items, the uniqueness and the overall feeling gives you that feeling that you're in an actual wasteland and you should make the right choises benificial to your survival.A few things that bugged me is that the game crashed A LOT. and I mean A LOT. There are some bugs here and there but you can't expect a game that is 100% bug free. Another thing that has bugged me is that if you finish the main story line - there's no continuation, which is kinda understandable because after you finish the main story line you basicly get a cinematic of what happened to everything based upon your final choise.Overall, I think the game is worth the money and you should defintely give it a try :)

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												One of the best games ever created. This game + all the DLCs is more than worth the 5 bucks you will probably spend for it.Fallout: New Vegas with all the DLCs is at least 50-60 hours long. This game is great for replayability.I spent over 400~ (Not always had this one on Steam) hours playing this game, over 30~ hours modding it, and it never gets old. You can playthrough this game for at least 8~ times,making different decisions and it will never be the same exprience.You can mod it to the core, and there are alot of modifications to be made. If you love modding get this and Skyrim. Only downside to this game is performance, which is incredibly horrible. This game will lag and have stutters with a 2030 hardcore gaming machine as well. If you are going to play this, you HAVE to download mods that will make the game more stable on your machine,because  this game is incredibly buggy and has lots of crashes. (With mods, this can be sorted out)Again, if you like tweaking and modding a game, this game is an absolute must.If you expect an out-of-the-box exprience, go play Skyrim.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												I finally hit 20 hours after about a month and 12 days (thats a guess) of owning F:NV. I love this game, but it has many many flaws. First off, the open world is pretty big. That isnt normally a bad thing, but when you walk slower than a crippled old lady going up a steep staircase. Seriously, and when you press shift it make you even slower! Besides that, this game is extremely difficult for first tim Fallout players. This was mty first Fallout game. I bought it because I wanted to play one of the older Fallout games before I bought Fallout 4. Also, the open world is pretty dull. It's just a desert with some occasional towns. And the Strip is extremely small and not what the first few hours of this game makes it seem like.  Also, loading screens feel more like a teacher giving a boring lesson becuase they take forever. But if you look past this games flaws, F:NV might be one of the best games on Steam.First off, I love the faction system. I joined the legion, and from that I was rewarded with occasional supply drops of ammo and other useful items. This game is definitely rewarding. Also, I love the plot in this game and how it isn't 80% cutscenes. In fact, the only cutscene I've seen so far is the intro, which is only 6 or 7 minutes long. There is ADS, but I personally don't use it much. VATS are pretty useful for close quarters combat. Lockpicking is awesome, and even better on PC. I know this game is old, but there should seriousy be a Steam Workshop for this game. I mean, people mod this game as much as people mod Skyrim, so I dont see why there Isn't a Workshop.Overall though, I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a good story, a good RPG and an amazing game. Whether it's on sale or not, you should buy F:NV, and maybe even the Ultimate Editon for double price and all the DLC.I'd love feedback on this review, so please tell me what you think! Enjoy Fallout New Vegas!Edit:I just finished F:NV. Wow. I loved it. Except for one thing that makes this different from other RPG's.  After completing the main story, it takes you back to the main menu, and asks you if you want to load a previous save. In other words, you cannot explore the Mojave or do side quests. Also, this game has a painfully low level cap of 30. While it does take some time to level up, this is an extremely small level cap. With DLC, though, the level cap is 50 (Each DLC adds 5 levels to the level cap). As I did the final mission, I began to notice some things. First, using guns continuously for a long time makes them feels weird. Basically what I'm trying to say is that the gunplay feels a little off. This somewhat forces you to rely on V.A.T.S. most of the time. But let me say what I have noticed about the game from finishing it that I did enjoy. I definitely noticed that ADS is important at one point, especially with long range kills. Before I wrap this up I want to point out that this game felt kind of short. I expecting a longer campaign, but atleast the replay value is extremely high. So, to wrap this up, (at least for now,) I want say that even though it felt short, and the gunplay feels awkward, and the level cap is very low, I can still say that Fallout: New Vegas is one of, if not the, best games I've ever played and you should definitely buy it, sale or not, Ultimate Edition or normal.(Yes I know that was the longest sentence ever) I plan on buying the DLC for F:NV soon, and I'll do another edit if on what the game is like with DLC. Buying and investing hours of my time into Fallout: New Vegas is one of the best choices I've ever made, and I plan to do it all again.Also I'd like to mention the fact that I have almost 30 hours of gameplay and I've only come across one Deathclaw. Just a little strange to me.March 21, 2016: EDIT 2: I want to point out something. F:NV is only ten dollars without DLC, (I bought it for $2.49 on sale) and I've managed to get 30 hours from it. Some have even got hundreds of hours of gameplay. Think about that. 30 hours, and thats just the main storyline. Yeah, some games are longer, but for this pricetag, that's a lot of gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Ah, Fallout. Such an amazing franchise. And New Vegas is no exception, unsurprisingly.I must admit, most of my friends told me that NV was better than F3, but when I started it, I wasn't quite convinced. It sorta started out a bit slow (more so than F3 anyway), and who can beat Liam Neeson?! I'm not incredibly keen on Westerns, but with all the hype I figured I'd carry on with it. Man, am I ever glad I did.The Good - I don't really like Skyrim that much (yep, currently readying myself for the barrage of insults headed my way) because I find it too open-ended. I kinda find the amount of things you can do overwhelming, since it's more or less "Ok here's the world, go explore it!" Oddly, despite Fallout being much the same, I actually really enjoy it. There's enough of a main storyline to keep my ADD-riddled brain interested, and I love the kitschy feel of the game. Of course, the dialogue is also amazing, and the Perks are generally pretty cool/useful (I can't even count how many LOLs the Black Widow Perk has given me). The vast amount of weapons allow for pretty much all styles of battle to be effective. But besides battle, sometimes you just wanna blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, and that's entirely possible/encouraged here.The Bad - Not a lot of bad that I found. Sometimes it's glitchy, but since it's not especially new, most of the problems have been fixed (or at least, I haven't had much of a problem with my version). The few glitches I HAVE come across have been pretty irritating, but nothing to write home about. Some of the DLCs have been hard enough for me to rage-quit several times (but that's not really anything to do with the game, more like my own bad temper, haha).All in all, this game is amazing, and the good far outweigh the bad. I'd recommend it to anyone, regardless of their game preference. If you haven't played, it probably means you've been stuck under a rock (or in a Vault?). If this is the case, welcome to the real world! Now go play.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												In ''Fallout: New Vegas'', you return to the post-apocalyptic West Coast of the ruined United States of America, like in the first ''Fallout'' game and its sequel ''Fallout 2''. For the first time you get to explore Nevada and the city of New Vegas. A city untouched by the nuclear warheads that devestated the rest of the world. You take the role of a courier from the Mojave Express in Primm. You were supposed to deliver a platinum chip to the Lucky 38 in New Vegas. A seemingly easy task. But as misfortune would have it, you get ambushed near Goodsprings by a man in a checkered suit and a handful of Great Khans (the descendants of the Khans and New Khans). The man in the checkered suit tells you that it was bound to happent to fall prey to his ambush, before shooting you in the head.You awaken in the clinic of Doc. Mitchell, the doctor of Goodsprings. Here starts your tutorial level and you get to create your character and define their traits. The character creation has been slightly expended upon, since ''Fallout 3'', since you have an age slide now, but other than that it's identical.Once you have done that, you are supposed to talk to Sunny Smiles to start the tutorial level. Here you get taught how to use firearms and V.A.T.S. ( Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System ) and have the optional objective of being tutored in the new skill ''survival''. This skill is particularly handy when you're using Hardcore Mode ( where you can die from hunger and thirst. ).Overall the game is really enjoyable and I have spent many hours on it. You have a lot of freedom, because of the enormous mod database at Nexus Mods and the decisions you make throughout the game have impact at the end game. But don't worry, the choices you make are easily recognised wether they're good or bad. Although if you start the end game, there's no turning back and you're just finished with the game after the slide-show and narrating about the impacts of your action. Luckily, the game automatically saves your game, just before the end game starts, and you can just return to the Mojave Desert after that.Overal I give the game a 9/10

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Fallout New Vegas:     FNV is an open world, action rpg set in a post-apocalyptic Mojave desert, with civilization starting to re-emerge out of the ashes. The fairly large map (21 square miles) surrounds one of the few places doing relatively well in the wasteland: Vegas. The landscape in vegas can sometimes be a bore, with a lot of dry rolling hills around you, but the excellent 30's, 40's, and 50's music will make you forget all that, and just hum along.      Story wise, FNV is not amazing, but still good. In the opening cinematic, you, a simple courier for the mojave express company, gets shot straight in the head by a suave, but evil and cocky son-of-a-gun fellow named Benny. Once you are healed in the nearby town of goodsprings, your new goal is to hunt him down and bring him to justice. The story brings the player around the whole map, greeting the player with dozens of side quests. Once the player finally does kill Benny, the story really takes off, allowing the player to join one of the three factions viyng for power, or take over by yourself. The three faction are :The New California Republic, a gorup wanting to bring back the world before the apocalypse, Ceasers legion, a crazy dicator bent on ruling like a roman emperor, and Mr.House, a high tech robot wanting to bring back the 'glory of vegas'.    Gameplay is where this game truly shines. With the old-school RPG like character creation complete with a plethora of unique and fun perks, you can create a variety of different classes, each with their own playstyle, allowing for a lot of replayability. There are dozens of different weapons varying from a simple smg, or an orbital strike cannon, or a plasma rifle, a super-sword thing, and dozens more. With the expansive map filled with locations ranging from a ski lodge with super-mutants, to deep vaults giant fire ants, the postapocalyptic world is a truly crazy place.      FNV is not perfect, though there are hundreds of bugs and glitches, which is to be expected with a game of this size. Some of the quests are bland, and some of the locations are quite small and boring. There seems to also be only a few voice actors, evenif thats not the case. Most of these problems can be fized with mods, which brings me to my next point:the excellent modding community. There are hundreds and thousands of mods on the nexus and various other sites, ranging from high quality lore friendly quests, to crazy weapon packs, graphical overhauls, spiderman cars, companion mods, bug fixes, to more risque things.     With the points made above, I strongly reccomend this game to anybody who loves rpg's action games, well written experiences, and pretty much anyone who has likes video games. I do not reccomend this to a completionist though, much like Skyrim, the buggy quests, and the sheer size of the game makes it quite hard to 100% complete, and maybe not in a good way. To anybody else that likes anything, by this game now.Score(do I need this?) = 8.5/10With mods = 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Plain and simple, if open world exploration where your choices affect the outcome of the game is your thing, then Fallout: New Vegas will be a home run with you. My two biggest beefs with the game are that the graphics look pretty rough and the story is pretty bland. Poor textures and stiff looking characters are seen throughout. I never really got into the lore of the story either. Oh, and the AI for companions is just plain awful. Playing it on hardcore is not worth as your companions will often bolt off to who knows where and you are greeted with an alert that they have died (setting them to stay or passive is no help).The plus sides far out weight the negatives. Complete freedom in what you wish to do, a hearty helping of a variety of weapons and armor, crafting, skills, implants, etc. You really do get to play any way you want to. I would recommend getting all the DLC as each pack ups the level cap by 5 levels so you can go all the way to 50. Granted, once you are this high, you will have so many perks you will feel close to unstoppable but there are still a few legendary enemies out there that you will have to be a bit strategic with. While it is worth it to raise the level cap, do not expect too much from the DLC. Dead Money is pretty bad but the others are passable.Overall, 8.7/10.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												*10.6h played on PC, +500h total including PS3*This game is in my opinion the best Fallout inthe franchise. The missions (both main and sidequests) are interesting and varied, the combat is exciting at higher difficulties, the exploration aspect is very enticing because of the multitude of places and buildings you can stumble upon during your playthrough. The game is very fun overall and has a lot of replayability value due to the multiple paths and factions you can take on. There are a variety of weapons and armor that let you follow multiple different playstyles, such as a sniper, a run-and-gun guy, an explosives expert, etc. However, there are bad points too. The game for one, has some weaknesses due to time constraints during development on Obsidian's side. So there is some cut content and some aspects of the game that feel hollow and leave a lot to desire, like the Legion, which is sadly very shallow. And another thing I dislike is that the game is not as difficult as it should be. Hardcore mode doesn't punish enough and it's not too difficult to eat, drink and sleep in the Mojave, you just have to keep an eye on the counter and that's that. Both these issues can be fixed with mods, so yeah, hooray for PC!To grossly sum it up: it's fun, it's crazy, it may make you play for weeks or months, mods are a thing for this and will make you stay for much longer and hardcore mode is not as hardcore as one may think at first.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Undoubtably one of my favorite games. You cant go wrong buying it. At any price it would have been worth my money. The Fallout games always have a strongly immersive enviornment that really grabs you and pulls you into the game. The soundtrack, NPC detail, and substance in the world all contribute to this. NPC's have personality; NPCs act acording to their peronality and the post apocolyptic envionment that surrounds them. The soundtrack (radio songs) give the game an "Old Western" type feel that goes great with the chaos and disorder of the world. They also make the world feel somewhat eerie and desolat; wandering the wasteland, everythings quiet, something could pop out and eat you alive at any moment and your listening to Jingle Jangle. It's a good contrast between sunch a "fun" song and a dark enviornment. The songs definently end up growing on you. Every corrner has a secret behind it. The world is full of mystery and curiosity. You can wander in some abondoned building only to discover it ihabited by the hostile robots who once used to work there or find some cave at the bottom of an ocean. The more unfamiliar the world is, the more lost you feel, the more exciting the game is. Mods add even more too the game, adding more immersion, longevity, and options. Some mods might be immersion breaking, I wouldnt recomend those. The game runs stable on most machines I would assume. The quests will never leave you unentertained as they are numorous and almost never "go fetch this" of "find this dude." The DLC adds hours and hours of playtime so I highly recomend you buy the Ultimate Edition. The DLC is unique, adds characters, story, weapons, items, quests. Each of them are like mini-main story lines, heir more than side quests. The Fallout series is just too great. I hope 4 will be as good as this one. War, war never changes

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Fantastic game, lots of choice, great writing, fantastic world to explore. Really feels like a wasteland. If you have ever been interested in a Bethesda-style open world game before, this is one of the best ones out there. The only problem is its a 32 bit program so with modding the best you are going to get is 4gb of ram. Which is unfortunate because it seems to run out of that fairly quickly if you use any noteable number of mods. It also isn't as well-optimized as it should be (or perhaps i'm just doing something wrong.), as even with a few performance mods I'm still not able to keep a steady 60 fps everywhere with the highest settings.Nevertheless, a fantastic game and definitely worth a try. Do yourself a favor and pick up the ultimate edition. The DLC is great, and a good number of mods require the DLC.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas - Welcome to Vegas. New Vegas. It’s the kind of town where you dig your own grave prior to being shot in the head and left for dead…and that’s before things really get ugly. It’s a town of dreamers and desperados being torn apart by warring factions vying for complete control of this desert oasis. It’s a place where the right kind of person with the right kind of weaponry can really make a name for themselves, and make more than an enemy or two along the way. As you battle your way across the heat-blasted Mojave Wasteland, the colossal Hoover Dam, and the neon drenched Vegas Strip, you’ll be introduced to a colorful cast of characters, power-hungry factions, special weapons, mutated creatures and much more. Choose sides in the upcoming war or declare “winner takes all” and crown yourself the King of New Vegas in this follow-up to the 2008 videogame of the year, Fallout 3. Enjoy your stay.Key Features Feel the Heat in New Vegas! Not even nuclear fallout could slow the hustle of Sin City. Explore the vast expanses of the desert wastelands – from the small towns dotting the Mojave Wasteland to the bright lights of the New Vegas strip. See the Great Southwest as could only be imagined in Fallout. Feuding Factions, Colorful Characters and a Host of Hostiles! A war is brewing between rival factions with consequences that will change the lives of all the inhabitants of New Vegas. The choices you make will bring you into contact with countless characters, creatures, allies, and foes, and determine the final explosive outcome of this epic power struggle. New Systems! Enjoy new additions to Fallout: New Vegas such as a Companion Wheel that streamlines directing your companions, a Reputation System that tracks the consequences of your actions, and the aptly titled Hardcore Mode to separate the meek from the mighty. Special melee combat moves have been added to bring new meaning to the phrase “up close and personal”. Use V.A.T.S. to pause time in combat, target specific enemy body parts and queue up attacks, or get right to the action using the finely-tuned real-time combat mechanics. An Arsenal of Shiny New Guns! With double the amount of weapons found in Fallout 3, you’ll have more than enough new and exciting ways to deal with the threats of the wasteland and the locals. In addition, Vault-Tec engineers have devised a new weapons configuration system that lets you tinker with your toys and see the modifications you make in real time. Let it Ride! In a huge, open world with unlimited options you can see the sights, choose sides, or go it alone. Peacemaker or Hard Case, House Rules, or the Wild Card - it’s all in how you play the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												So I did a review of Fallout 3 a couple years ago, and I forgot to do one of Fallout New Vegas.  Suprizingly I actually liked FNV better than F3!  Fallout New Vegas carries on the awesome open world RPG gameplay that is found in many other Bethesda games. It is so addictive and entertaining!  FNV added a lot of things that were either lacking or not done as well in F3.  I happen to be a bit of a gun nut in real life, and this game hits home hard for those of use that are into firearms.  The amount of real-world accurate weapons in the game is mind boggling.  I think that FNV is one of the reasons I got into reloading my own ammunitions.  I loved that feature. The environment is FNV is also much more dazling and rich than the environment in F3.  You get the sense that you are really out in the wild west wasteland, where life is beginning to spring back, and people have dropped into their western dog-eat-dog lifestyle.  I played the game through between 2-3 times, and found that I most enjoyed playing as a desperado vagabond that went around doing good for the needy and mercilessly destroying any enemies.  The RP aspect is much deeper than F3, and perhaps moreso than Skyrim.If you have any doubts whether to buy this game, do it.  do it now...or when it goes on sale.  You won't regret it!  Please give us Fallout 4 Bethesda!!!! Put the Elder Scrolls on hold!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas is a game in the Fallout Universe that takes place in 2281, 4 years after the events of Fallout 3. You are a courier hired by the Mojave Express to deliver a secret package to Mr.House in New Vegas. A casino manager by the name of Benny wants the?package to take over Vegas so he finds you with aid of the Great Kahns (one of the tribes in the Mojave Wasteland, Benny takes the package (soon to be know as a Platinum Chip) (The Chip can override the securitrons, Robots that protect Vegas. Anyways Benny shoots you in the head and buries you in the Goodsprings Cemetary, a securitron named Victor digs you out of the grave and takes you to the Goodsprings doctor , Doc Mitchell.So you wake up in the Doc's home and you set up your character and all that, After you leave the doctors home you can go to the "Prospectors Saloon" and meet a girl named "Sunny Smiles" she will give you a gun and let you do target training. In the Mojave Wasteland you can do quests for four opposite factions : NCR (a military army that tries to bring good across the Wasteland), The Legion (a group of slavers, evil people led by Caesar), Yes Man (a securitron?reprogrammed by Benny that would help him take over Vegas), Mr.House (the father of New Vegas who protected most of Vegas from the nukes of the Great War of 2077) The game is addictive so much greatness, you can do quests for people across the wasteland to earn caps, weapons and good or bad karma. I highly recommend the game if you are a fan of Fallout 3 or the past Fallout games, the game is not really that difficult it depends if you are new to Fallout or not. Sounds are great but the game full of npc's should have more voice actors, Graphics are awesome, The game offers a lot especially the DLC's Just be warned the "Dead Money" DLC will fill you with rageThe DLC's are:Lonesome Road Honest HeartsOld World BluesDead MoneyCourier's StashGun Runners ArsenalIf you want  a game thats $10 i highly recommend this games $10 is almost a steal

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas is a good game, maybe even a better game than Fallout 3, and here's why. Pros: - The best thing about this game is the music. It's upbeat and hilarious. Even if you're not normally a fan of songs about homicidal cowboys, a lot of these classic 40's and 50's tunes will get stuck in your head all day nonetheless.- The Mojave is a vibrant, interesting background for the kinds of fun shenanigans that make Bethesda games a blast.- The characters in this game are great, and in many ways more interesting than the characters in Fallout 3. - The game engine now allows you to aim using iron sights, as well as a time-freezing mechanic called "V.A.T.S." Fallout 3 had only V.A.T.S., no iron sights. - Enemies are more varied and interesting than the same old rehashed enemy types from Fallout 3. Now you can kill "giant flies" and "glorified LARPers in Roman armor made from football gear", as well as the tried and true "radioactive zombies" and "giant scorpions."- There's a big modding community that's put a lot of work into creating free content to extend your wasteland experience even further. Sometimes the mods are even as good as the content in the vanilla game.Cons: - It's a Bethesda game. Luckily by now most of the bugs have been patched, or can be patched if you download a few mods from the Mod Nexus. But still, buggy, crashy, sometimes laggy. - The story's a bit meh. Even though the characters are, IMO, better than Fallout 3's, the story isn't quite as fulfilling or engaging. All around, New Vegas is a lovely game with a beautiful soundtrack and a lot of really fun elements to it. Another masterful example of the RPG genre from Bethesda.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I highly recommend this game, to anyone who likes action RPGs. One problem I have with it, is the games abundance of bugs and glitches. Compared to Fallout 3 there are a thousand times more bugs and glitches. Luckily, these problems can be easily fixed with unofficial patches and fixes provided by the modding community. Thanks, to the modding community the lifetime of this game has been increased greatly. One thing I liked most about Fallout: New vegas, is the similar features it shares with its predecessors Fallout 1 and 2, such as traits and getting perks every other level. Fallout 3 was the more stable game of the two, but Fallout: New Vegas gave old players of the franchise a nostalgic feel. Also, Fallout: New Vegas, gave players a wide variety of weapons to choose from, unique locations to visit, and brought back old characters, and factions. Whether you are a longtime Fallout fan or new to the series, you should strongly consider adding this game to your library.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												One of the best games I've ever played. You can get so many hours out of this game; I only have 25 at the moment but I only got this game recently on PC, I've mostly played it on 360. There are so many different ways to play, I've started at least four different files and each one felt entirely unique.  Add modding and you've got a game that can last you a long time. Also, this game can run on pretty low-end PCs, which is always a plus. If you don't like the graphics, there are a ton of ENBs as well. And don't even get me started on the DLCs; all four are absolutely amazing. Overall, the only negative thing I can say about this game is that it can be glitchy at times, but they can be funny and there are a ton of fix mods to remove them. $20 is a steal of a price for such an amazing game, and if that's still too pricey, New Vegas is extremely cheap during sales. 10/10ASSUME THE POSITION

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												*10.6h played on PC, +500h total including PS3*This game is in my opinion the best Fallout inthe franchise. The missions (both main and sidequests) are interesting and varied, the combat is exciting at higher difficulties, the exploration aspect is very enticing because of the multitude of places and buildings you can stumble upon during your playthrough. The game is very fun overall and has a lot of replayability value due to the multiple paths and factions you can take on. There are a variety of weapons and armor that let you follow multiple different playstyles, such as a sniper, a run-and-gun guy, an explosives expert, etc. However, there are bad points too. The game for one, has some weaknesses due to time constraints during development on Obsidian's side. So there is some cut content and some aspects of the game that feel hollow and leave a lot to desire, like the Legion, which is sadly very shallow. And another thing I dislike is that the game is not as difficult as it should be. Hardcore mode doesn't punish enough and it's not too difficult to eat, drink and sleep in the Mojave, you just have to keep an eye on the counter and that's that. Both these issues can be fixed with mods, so yeah, hooray for PC!To grossly sum it up: it's fun, it's crazy, it may make you play for weeks or months, mods are a thing for this and will make you stay for much longer and hardcore mode is not as hardcore as one may think at first.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												A fun and frothy experience best coupled with a tall glass of your favorite champaign, and a bowl dead fish stuff.  "Fallout: New Vegas" Is no doubt, an exquisite entertaining digital experience that will leave you satisfied, and yet, will you thirsty for more like a lowlife drunken mongrel who would sell his own mother for just a small sip of alcohol. Of course you withold such pleasures from the desprate man so that he may squirm and shiver for your own entertainment, and with his last bit of strength you promise him he could have the whole bottle if he would just get up do a little jig. Then you sit there, drinking his booze and laughing at him proclaiming "dance, little man dance!" Hahaha. Yes. Quite so. There is no doubt that "Fallout: New Vegas" is a standout amongst it's peers. Though never quite acheiving the sublimity of it's predecessor "Fallout 3", It is still remains  devilishly good fun. By jove, nothing beats the look on the face of unsuspecting passerby as you unceremonously rob him of all he posesses, and then stab him right in the back. Of course there are a number of unsavory mutant types roaming the world. Even the thought of them makes me shiver with terror. But they can be useful in pinch, believe you me, when there is a job that needs doing, a mutant or a raider will get the job done better then anyone else. Or at least good enough. Oh and then there is the music. Simplicity itself. Frank Sinatra would be proud to hear the roaring sounds of Vegas, that once paradice on earth, blasting from the spearks of your personal computer as you blow away yet another unsuspecting innocent with a rocket launcher. Well that's all I have to leave you with for now, dear reader. Enjoy your new digital experience, and remember during those moments of village onslaught, or wandering into some dangerous unknown area with strange green men who own big guns, there is always the load function to start over. Pleasant voyage friend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Set in a post-nuclear desert known as the Mojave Wasteland, you are a courier searching for the man who tried to kill you. Weapon sights, more varied perks, cooking and crafting systems, quirkier writing and a larger variety of gear and characters separate NV from Fallout 3. Unfortunately, the graphics are terrible (no environment shadows, muddy textures, undetailed meshes, and so on), AI is laughable, and combat is a mess of suicidal NPCs either strafing or standing completely still. Fortunately, combat isn't all - conversations and the choices you make are important. You'll be able to threaten, praise, blackmail and so on, influencing other people - alongside the impact that your skills, traits and perks also have. Sadly, most characters are boring or lifeless due to sloppy writing, terrible animations and sub-par voice acting. Plagued by design problems, bugs and a disappointing ending, NV is quantity over quality. It gets the job done, but it could have been a lot better.

												Though its younger Elder Scrolls sibling gets a lot of credit as the most popular sandbox RPG of all time, Fallout: New Vegas is the best plotted and written. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2012
												If you haven't bought this, well, then you're a complete silly since this is one of the best games I've ever played. Fallout New Vegas combines the amazing sprawling open world gameplay of Fallout 3, but mixes in the atmosphere of the first 2 games, making the ultimate Fallout experence. Fans of the first games will feel right at home, and fans who played 3 only will love this to death. The storyline is an incredibly cool power struggle between 3 factions warring for control of Hoover Dam, and ultimately New Vegas itself. New Vegas is the last beacon of humanity, a city untouched by nuclear holocaust. You play a Courier, assigned to deliver a package to New Vegas, when you are shot in the head and left for dead. And so begins a tale of revenge and power. Gameplay is almost identical to Fallout 3, with a few new features. The DLC is great, and it's just fantastic. Buy this now.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												I highly recommend this game, to anyone who likes action RPGs. One problem I have with it, is the games abundance of bugs and glitches. Compared to Fallout 3 there are a thousand times more bugs and glitches. Luckily, these problems can be easily fixed with unofficial patches and fixes provided by the modding community. Thanks, to the modding community the lifetime of this game has been increased greatly. One thing I liked most about Fallout: New vegas, is the similar features it shares with its predecessors Fallout 1 and 2, such as traits and getting perks every other level. Fallout 3 was the more stable game of the two, but Fallout: New Vegas gave old players of the franchise a nostalgic feel. Also, Fallout: New Vegas, gave players a wide variety of weapons to choose from, unique locations to visit, and brought back old characters, and factions. Whether you are a longtime Fallout fan or new to the series, you should strongly consider adding this game to your library.
