content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Fallout New Vegas is a wonderful game, incorperating many elements within from quality of items to karma, appealing to people and keeping yourself alive. Weapons, armor, and many other items are found all throughout the game, and the dlc expand the base game way more. A bonus Hardcore mode makes the game even more realistic, allowing you to have to juggle hunger, hydration, and sleep, and more realistic item settings and ingame stats, which are detailed ingame. Post apocolyptic wasteland is so fun to explore, and the story is actually strewn through all the dlc as well, with many interconnected stories that can intertwine and unlock new options and dialogue. Speaking of dialogue, there are many, many options of dialogue, and skill set and specific attributes can influence dialogue, among other things that are affected. They thought of many different aspects of the game and beautifully blended the game operations together. I love this game so much, despite it being over 4 years old, because it plays so well, and is so well crafted, that i play this game over and over again, and my Steam playtime is not an accurate display of my love for this game. I have Probably 300+ hours into this game on my ps3, and it is still fuin everytime I play the game, no matter the platform. I highly recommend this game, and its predasessor, Fallout 3 with all the dlc as well. I would say play the old one first, as it has some different elements to it, and the feel is very different as well. I love this game so much, and believe everyone should play this game.

												A game of endless content. Great replay value with many different endings depending on the many -sometimes quite difficult, polically or ethically charged- dicisions made. I must've sunk over 400 hours into it (before I owned it on Steam) and on every playthrough I discover new area's and side-stories. When you finally think you've really seen it all... you get into modding. This is when you find out that all flaws that you used to ignore because the rest of the game is so awesome, have been fixed by the community along with plenty new game mechanics, tweaks and hours, no, days of extra, often fully voice-acted content. I would say this is my favorite game without a doubt, if not for the other masterpieces that have been created with the same engine: Elder Scrolls IV and Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												I give this game a B-.The crafting and new ammunition/weapon modifications are improvements over Fallout 3, but the storyline has decidedly less charm (you're not from a Vault).The one thing I really do like about this game are the efforts by the designers to present firearms and ammunition more realistically in their components and effects (i.e. handloading).What's disappointing is that many item textures are poor quality.  Also, items and enemies frequently fall through the world.  These faults were in Fallout 3 and should have been fixed.All in all, it's a good game.  You will have fun with it.  But save often because the bugs will grind on you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Almost perfection, I could honestly talk about this game for hours. I'd recommend it to just about anyone whose into dark settings and high quality storytelling as well as characters that really make you think. With like 3 or 4 mods this game is a perfect 10 to me. It's a shame the game launched in such a broken state.             Okay, so I've played through the game 3 times and all of the dlc twice, I've actually only run into a small amount of bugs, things such as scorpions spawning in the grounds with their tails sticking out of the sand, a dog with eyes floating on the side of his head, getting stuck inside rocks a couple times which is easily fixed through tcl or reloading a save and one single quest breaking bug out of the 173 quests in the game including dlc and not including the miscellaneous quests. I also ran into 1 save corruption. That's it, maybe I'm just lucky idk but my experience was relatively bug free. Just save often and you'll avoid these problems by reloading. I also get crashes which seems to be kind of unavoidable with these games but it doesn't happen as often as it does in skyrim, fallout 3 or oblivion for me personally.        I could talk about the story and characters forever and how well done they all are. Veronica, Boone, Joshua Graham and Mr House to name a few were all awesome. Mr House specifically sticks out as a character I could talk about for a very long time. I continue to think about these characters long after I finish the game. Obsidian really went out of their way to give the characters depth on a level that is competetive with bioware games. Something that most of the time Bethesda doesn't even attempt to do.                I don't know what else to say without extending the review for too long. I obviously recommend this game, it's well worth your time and money but if you're new to the Fallout series I'd still recommend you play FO3 or FO1 first. FO3 is a great way to introduce yourself to the setting but if you play FO3 and miss out on New Vegas you really are robbing yourself of a complete experience. I feel like Fallout 3 is the first quarter and New Vegas is like the last 3 quarters that completes the experience and makes it a real sequel to fallout 1 and 2. Everyone should experience both games. To me this is a 9.5 without mods and on launch it would probably be lower because of how broken I hear it was. If you like fallout 1,2 or 3 play this game, it's worth it, just remember to eat, drink and take several breaks because this game will grab you by the balls and won't let go until it's over.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												This game... When it was released, I hated it. The map was smaller than 3's and it just didn't feel like how I wanted it to. But then as time went on and it seemed as if we were never going to get a Fallout 4, I came back to it, started modding it and really just enjoying the game for what it is. AND THEN, YEARS LATER.... FALLOUT 4 CAME OUT! While I did and still do enjoy FO4 from time to time, it really made me appreciate New Vegas. Fallout 4 has the huge map, the shooting mechanics and the great graphics, but where it failed is where New Vegas shines, in the gameplay, the RPG elements and actually good game mechanics. If you're looking for the REAL Fallout experience then play Fallout New Vegas, it's a great game with a HUGE modding community to keep you busy for hours and hours before or after you fininsh the main storyline depending on whether or not you're using CAGE (Continue After Game Ending). If you're having stuttering problems, get Fallout Stutter Remover. Want weapons? Check out the Millenia team on Nexus. If you're looking for a quest mod, check out the New Vegas Bounties series by Someguy2000. For those of you who are scared by the word "MODDING", as a grizzled modding veteran, here are a few tips I will give you.1. The first thing you should do for ALL BETHESDA GAMES is download the corresponding Script Extender for that game, for New Vegas it is NVSE.2. There are numerous tools you can (should) use to mod your game: Nexus Mod Manager/FallOut Mod Manager to install your mods for you and LOOT to manage your load order (which is the order by which your mods are loaded and if done incorrectly you will have compatability problems like missing textures or Crashes) but not to worry, LOOT will do that for you. 3.Then, there's FNVEdit, this tool is used for cleaning mods, and it requires a bit of modding know-how so for people new to modding, don't get this till you're a little more experienced.4. Don't feed the Yao Guai... That is all...Well.... I guess that's it then, To all you Fallout newcomers reading this: Enjoy the ride, it's going to be a long one, and to those, like me, who have devoted countless hours into playing and modding this game, I guess we've got a case of the Old World Blues.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2010
												The gameplay, while essentially the same, is improved. Ironsighted weapons make for extra degree of immersion or reality to firearms and weapon-modifications take some weapons from good to great  and more. Fallout 1 and 2 fans will notice several nods to the previous games and players of Fallout 3 will also see some nice nods in their direction. The story is more original this time and  quickly becomes more than it seems. Characters are dozens of times more fleshed out than those of Fallout 3 and every companion has their own character, history, and personal quest. Those who look for Dogmeat will be disappointed but for those of you who remember K-9, Rex will be a nice replacement.To put it simply: Fallout: New Vegas is what Fallout 3 should have been and is a game you cannot afford to deprive yourself of. If you mourn the loss of the original FO3, Van Buren then you will see major influences brought from it to New Vegas and it is easily worth the cost.Don't miss this game.

												Old World Blues Specifically: This is the way to do DLC right. They listened to what the fans wanted: more humor, more bigger-than-life personalities vying for attention (Think Tanks! The SINK!), unique weapons that are more than just a higher damage number and a boring same-y model (K9000 cyberdog gun!), a new player home base that's upgradable and alive with activity/things to do, and a new story with an actual twist that makes you think.If every DLC was like this I wouldn't worry about paying $10 for them. One character, one mission and 2 new weapons like most devs give you just isn't cutting it compared to this.Great game and great DLC.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												If you like games with deep, immersive story lines, this is the game for you.Fallout: New Vegas is very well written, as it adjoins dark, somber plot points with welcome humor and lightheartedness.  The game is made even more interesting by the degree to which the player can affect the story and the outcome.  There is very little in the way of a linear plot.The game's combat system does tend to get slightly repetitive but very little of the game is actually spent in combat.  It is mostly a matter of making decisions and exploring the semblance of society that exists in the Mojave Wasteland.Although I've heard the game get a bad reputation due to bugs and the like, I found that it ran very, very smoothly on even a standard PC and the few bugs did not interfere much if at all with the gameplay.If you can get this game for cheap during a sale, it is mandatory to purchase it.If you want this game but there is no sale, it is still well worth it because you will probably not playing much else for the next few weeks, at the very least.P.S.: The mods are pretty gorgeous too :)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												When it comes to the Fallout games, the biggest questions you need to ask yourself usually consist of "Is it still canon?", "Is it really that moddable?", and probably "Is it enjoyable?". Rather fortunately for New Vegas, the answers tend to be yes.The franchise itself is not without some tarnish (looking at the PS2 and Xbox game I'm not fond of mentioning!) but New Vegas is more than capable of delivering the brand from the dark, gritty, heavy metal future it was careening into and taking the series back to its roots: gratuitous sex, violence, political intrigue, and 1950's Americana.New Vegas isn't exactly a flawless jewel of the desert, though. It does have a rushed feel to the ending, like the majority of Obsidian's games (read: KotOR 2 and Alpha Protocol) and the game has an entire phylum of bugs indicitive of a Bethesda game. The game also lacks any sort of sandboxing continuity following the ending, a major flaw for a game this expansive. Play it, regardless.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												You're wandering out in the Mojave Wasteland, just wanting to get to a destination for a quest when suddenly you're faced with 3 Deathclaws, giant vicious beasts, coming towards you...this is going to happen at some point, or maybe not? This is the world of Fallout: New Vegas.If you loved Fallout 3, you'll enjoy this game. It features the same engine and overall gameplay, adding in some new elements as well. For example, the companions you get in this game won't die, but they will get knocked out, so you can take them through the entire game, and each one gets a little quest of their own. The game certainly has a Western feel, as one would expect, especially from the radio station playing songs that conjure up images of cowboys and the like. The main story has you being shot and left for dead, but you survive and on a mission to find out what happened...and to  avenge your death as you see fit. You'll come up against familiar and new creatures in the wasteland, meet some new friends and spend endless hours going place to place wondering what's around the next corner.The main hub is, not surprisingly, New Vegas. Here, you can enter casinos and even gamble, plus a few quests including the main one. There's lots to do here in this game.One nitpick I had with Fallout 3, and it's just a personal one, but one I've heard echoed by others, is that the D.C. area was hard to navigate, and the metro was confusing as well. That is one reason I prefer this game over 3, just barely, but I never got lost in this game. If that was an issue for you, this presents a nice alternative.There's more to find out and discover, but in a game like this, it's best if you experience yourself. If you liked open-world games, and maybe more to the point, if you enjoyed Fallout or The Elder Scrolls series, give this one a go. It has its glitches, but nothing I've encountered that's too bad or very often. I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Fallout has always been a phenomenon in the post-apocolyptic genre. It is highly regarded for its amazing atmosphere and provoking exploration. In the Fallout universe you are set out into the wasteland to survive, and make difficult choices during odd situations. The humor, and interesting characters you stumble upon during your trek in the Wasteland makes Fallout an enjoyable franchise. Fallout: New Vegas takes place in Nevada, specifically the Mojave Desert. You, the Courier, are tasked out to unite the Wasteland, evil or good. Along the way through your journey in the Wasteland, you will encouter terrifying creatures, and unexplored locations by prospectors.The combat in Fallout: New Vegas is very similar to Fallout 3, if you have ever played it. However, Fallout: New Vegas makes some notable changes in its combat system, and difficulty system. In Fallout: New Vegas, you are able to aim down sights, and are able to modify weapons to a larger degree. A new difficulty system was also shipped with the game, hardcore. Enemies are notably more difficult, and hydration is necessary for surivival. With any Bethesda Softworks game, or in this Obsidian Entertainment. Fallout: New Vegas is completley moddable, for more better experience. Want to download high resolution textures? You can. Want to download more content, such as quests or characters? You're free to do so. Fallout: New Vegas has an unlimited amount of content developed by the community. Fallout: New Vegas is a title that everyone should play at least once.Summary: Positives: +Mods+Humorous  +Atmopsherical+Open World+100+ hours of content+Enjoyable characters+Freedom of choiceNegative:-Crashes (can be fixed with mods)-Buggy (can be fixed with mods)-Companion system is bland.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2013
												If you loved fallout 3, you'll find a new world to explore and waste hours adventuring. The quests are tighter and much more enjoyable. You'll get to do a little vault diving again. The plot is almost nonexistant and the game leaves you to roam where ever, find plenty of new and interesting weapons, and see the sights. On the other hand, the game is as glitchy as ever. I once saw a scorpion clipped through the ground trying to attack me. There are invisible walls everywhere, so that little hill you want to get over is impossible, I don't understand this design choice for an open world environment. You rely much less on vats due to less volatile movements and improved aiming. The special system seemed to be much more important as each attribute has its pros and cons and played in more during conversations. the skills have much more diverse uses, expect finding practical uses for repair and medicine. The worst part however is this amounts to a reskin of fallout 3. While new weapons and enemies keep it fresh, combat is the same and many places seem familiar. If you enjoyed fallout 3, be prepared to be drawn into a new world along with a few hiccups here and there.

Posted: April 20, 2014
												Me, being a huge fan of both the post-apocolyptic genre, and Fallout 3, freaked out when I heard of Fallout: New Vegas. I worked up the dough to buy it, and bought it I did. Ultimate Edition is the only way to go.So, I booted it up, started it, and sat there, biting my fingernails. I did the same thing you did in Fallout 3, made and named your character, (Mine being as ugly as can be and being named♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥McGee, also unintentional rhyming!) put points into S.P.E.C.I.A.L., etc etc. When I finally made it out of the shack you start in, I walked straight ahead and never looked back on the little starting town called Goodsprings. That's the amazing thing about the Fallout series: It's completely open! You can ignore the storyline and just go around popping Deathclaws in the face with your 50 cal sniper rifle, or you can bargan with merchants to get better and better gear. You can almost literally do whatever you want from the very start of the game. I haven't quite played another game that felt like this.Final verdict: It is a game WELL worth your 20 bucks. It's a gaming experence you can never truly forget.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												If you have any love of FPS+RPG hybrids, Fallout: New Vegas is one of the best examples of the genre.  Building on what Bethesda established with Fallout 3, Fallout: New Vegas gives you a lengthy, nuanced plot, tons of side-quests, and a robust character system under it all.  An average play through will take 20 hours at a minimum, and that's assuming you skip side quests and DLC. With all that content you can easily spend 60+ hours per playthrough, and you will enjoy every minute.  Throw in mod content and you can easily spend years playing this game.Compared to its predecessor (Fallout 3) New Vegas has a lot of improvements, particularly in terms of balance, stability, and engine capability.  The new repair system is a lot less frustrating, the Cpmpanion Wheel control system is a great improvement, and the expanded crafting system is a dramatic step up from the frankly hacky iteration in FO3.  It's not without its downsides though; fans of FO3 will notice that the Mojave Wasteland has a lot less areas to explore compared to the Capital Wasteland, and will likely also lament the loss of the random encounters system.  Despite that, it's still a step forward overall, even if you might miss the denseness of the Capital Wasteland from time to time.All that said, this is still a game you can easily sink hundreds of hours into.  The plot is good, the game mechanics well designed and balanced, the DLC worthy in its own right, and overall has enjoyable, rewarding gameplay.  In other words, it's a  great entry in the Fallout series.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Rarely do I write reviews for games on here, but this game is too fantastic not to promote. It took me almost 100 hours to do one playthrough with the DLC, and I regret nothing. The sheer size of this game (I believe it's 10BG for the base game) might be a turn off for some, to which I say shame on you. This is a game I keep on my laptop at all times because I can just boot it up and play whenever and still have a great time. The game, of course, is set in a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland (who would've thought?) better known as the Mojave desert. These games are notorious for the large amount of decisions, and this one is no exception. It might be a bit buggy, but that's a small price to pay for a fantastic game. I would suggest, however, getting the Ultimate Edition on sale. Five dollars for hundreds of hours of fun is a great bargain, and one you should no doubt take advantage of. If you like the Elder Scroll games, but find yourself wishing from time to time that you had a gun or could level up with an experience point system instead of a skill level system, this is a fantastic match. It's also great for science-fiction fans, as laser weapons and robots are abundant in this game. The DLC are all fantastic and are all connected very neatly and in ways it took me until halfway through the third one to realize (I hadn't realized I should be looking for connections yet). Of course, my half-coherent ramblings won't tell you nearly as much as the game can show you. I've played about 50 hours in the past two weeks, and I can think of few ways I'd have rather spent that time.

I will be most sad when I will be unable to play on pc due to conflicts caused by newer hardware/software (Current issues with Fallout 3). My favorite all time line (my moto in life when things go bad)... "The game was rigged from the start" (sometimes fitting with a buggy Bethesda game). Great game if you are into mods as well - huge modding community out there. Probably some of them have fixed some of the bugs in the game, but I haven't checked into it yet. Enough mods to keep the game fresh for people who get bored easily with multiple play throughs (unlike myself). lol

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas' Plot and story is very well made and offers something for any kind of gamer. There is no way that you'll ever get bored because there is so much to do. At first, the story may seem slow as you struggle to get decent supplies, but as you progress through the game everything makes more sense and you'll quickly find your bearings. The only bad things about this game that I've realized is that sometimes the game crashes unexpectantly and the terrain can be rather depressing albeit it's supposed to be a wild west theme. Overall, I would give this game an 8/10 for a good story, and great gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												This is probably the closest thing I have to a favorite game. I spend a lot of time drifting from favorites to favorites; some days it's Deus Ex, somedays it's Planescape: Torment. This is a game that I always come back to no matter what because it has everything I really want in a game.- Active modding community.- Well-written story that's faithful to its predecessors.- Opportunity for completionists and roleplayers alike.- Ability to kill very nearly everyone you meet (even story characters!).- Interesting characters (don't get me wrong, I like Fallout 3 but the characters all have the personality of sandpaper).- Infinitely replayable.- Ambient music, as well as some old-timey Vegas music. And Marty Robbins, if that's what you're into.- Actually fun (fun is this crazy new concept in the game world that is, contrary to popular belief, NOT synonymous to overpriced downloadable content).So as not to sound like a blind fanboy, I'll also fault the game on a few issues.- While this game allows you to develop your character as you choose, I will admit that everything leading up to Freeside/New Vegas feels relatively railroady (as in you're not forced to go forward, that's just where all the action is and there's no good reason not to go forward). Not that this is a major issue, as Fallout 1 and 2 were the same way.- Crazy amount of bugs. Like, game-breakingly bad bugs. Some bugs can render the game unplayable, and you may need to reload a save. If you're like me and you tend to play RPG's late at night, you might find yourself getting nightmares from the following bugs:* Dogs with floating eyes!* String cheese people!* Game freezing while really eerie music plays and you're in an underground bunker surrounded by feral ghouls, and all you can hear is a repeated sound clip of their ghastly taunts!* FalloutNV.exe has stopped working.Thankfully, many of these can be fixed with patches, then broken again with the next twenty mods you inevitably add right after.- Sub-par graphics, but they're passable enough to ignore and there's plenty of community-made ENBs, patches, and graphical tweaks.- The engine isn't great, but it's VERY popular with modders. Some people can accomplish amazing things with it, just look at some of the quest mods.Overall, this is the only game I've ever played that I would give a 10/10. Any issues I find that I have a problem with can be patched and improved. This game is extremely addictive, and I have given it at least 500 hours of gameplay when my time playing it on PS3 is taken into consideration.

												An excellent game. This review is going to be presented very loosely, sorry. I had owned this game before but decided to get it on steam.There's all sorts of tales this game is waiting to tell. Accepting to do a quest which may seem intriguing at the time may not later as it'll sacrifice others which may seem more worth your time; for example, a companion insists that we take down two big companies as they had done something cruel, however doing this will remove the chance to converse with a myriad of interesting characters, which when killing them, may feel like beating up petty dogs- because you hadn't found out their ambitions and characteristics. The game is tailored to the whims of the player and makes you try to justify your actions in order to avoid feeling regretful. Any game can do this on paper, but to make it this enrapturing, requires a team that's dedicated to setting a benchmark instead of satisfying greedy shareholders. This paragraph also highlights the replayability of the game.The quests are intertwined into a bigger system often making you meet new npcs- they give you a better grasp of the motives of the factions and will give you the neccessary information to make your mind up about the ultimate ending. Go through computers and tapes as these tend to be fleshed out with stories. Another example: There's a staff complaint about the unexpected shipment of stealthboys, as some mischievous staff have been using them to satisfy their curious minds, or perverted in this case.I find the unsettling atmosphere to be very engrossing: the sun soaked visuals, rough tarnished surfaces along with the ambient sounds and fallout's occoasional press of a sombre piano key blend in to make New Vegas a belivable wasteland.More songs on the radio(s) would be nice( mods could sort this out though) but then again you'll spend quite a  bit of time in combat, so listening carefully to your surroundings will help and reward you. You may find this game frustrating on harder difficulties when you're suddenly outnumbered and your skills don't seem to be paying off. You're suddenly relying on vats more often to get the dirty work done, and when you're out of it, you're spamming your favorite pistol- which till now had been working wonders just isn't so you're dead. There's always a way avoid these situations.  This is a role playing game in which all the mechanics and options to manevoure a tricky situation in your favour have been realised. If you think not, there's an abundence of mods out there that are dedicated to polishing this gem.Luckily for me, I played this long after the launch date so I've very rarely encountered bugs and I am playing without mods, which i should have a look at.The game truly has spurs that jingle jangle jingle: there's always something which keeps me coming.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2013
												If you loved fallout 3, you'll find a new world to explore and waste hours adventuring. The quests are tighter and much more enjoyable. You'll get to do a little vault diving again. The plot is almost nonexistant and the game leaves you to roam where ever, find plenty of new and interesting weapons, and see the sights. On the other hand, the game is as glitchy as ever. I once saw a scorpion clipped through the ground trying to attack me. There are invisible walls everywhere, so that little hill you want to get over is impossible, I don't understand this design choice for an open world environment. You rely much less on vats due to less volatile movements and improved aiming. The special system seemed to be much more important as each attribute has its pros and cons and played in more during conversations. the skills have much more diverse uses, expect finding practical uses for repair and medicine. The worst part however is this amounts to a reskin of fallout 3. While new weapons and enemies keep it fresh, combat is the same and many places seem familiar. If you enjoyed fallout 3, be prepared to be drawn into a new world along with a few hiccups here and there.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Me, being a huge fan of both the post-apocolyptic genre, and Fallout 3, freaked out when I heard of Fallout: New Vegas. I worked up the dough to buy it, and bought it I did. Ultimate Edition is the only way to go.So, I booted it up, started it, and sat there, biting my fingernails. I did the same thing you did in Fallout 3, made and named your character, (Mine being as ugly as can be and being named♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥McGee, also unintentional rhyming!) put points into S.P.E.C.I.A.L., etc etc. When I finally made it out of the shack you start in, I walked straight ahead and never looked back on the little starting town called Goodsprings. That's the amazing thing about the Fallout series: It's completely open! You can ignore the storyline and just go around popping Deathclaws in the face with your 50 cal sniper rifle, or you can bargan with merchants to get better and better gear. You can almost literally do whatever you want from the very start of the game. I haven't quite played another game that felt like this.Final verdict: It is a game WELL worth your 20 bucks. It's a gaming experence you can never truly forget.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Fallout has always been a phenomenon in the post-apocolyptic genre. It is highly regarded for its amazing atmosphere and provoking exploration. In the Fallout universe you are set out into the wasteland to survive, and make difficult choices during odd situations. The humor, and interesting characters you stumble upon during your trek in the Wasteland makes Fallout an enjoyable franchise. Fallout: New Vegas takes place in Nevada, specifically the Mojave Desert. You, the Courier, are tasked out to unite the Wasteland, evil or good. Along the way through your journey in the Wasteland, you will encouter terrifying creatures, and unexplored locations by prospectors.The combat in Fallout: New Vegas is very similar to Fallout 3, if you have ever played it. However, Fallout: New Vegas makes some notable changes in its combat system, and difficulty system. In Fallout: New Vegas, you are able to aim down sights, and are able to modify weapons to a larger degree. A new difficulty system was also shipped with the game, hardcore. Enemies are notably more difficult, and hydration is necessary for surivival. With any Bethesda Softworks game, or in this Obsidian Entertainment. Fallout: New Vegas is completley moddable, for more better experience. Want to download high resolution textures? You can. Want to download more content, such as quests or characters? You're free to do so. Fallout: New Vegas has an unlimited amount of content developed by the community. Fallout: New Vegas is a title that everyone should play at least once.Summary: Positives: +Mods+Humorous  +Atmopsherical+Open World+100+ hours of content+Enjoyable characters+Freedom of choiceNegative:-Crashes (can be fixed with mods)-Buggy (can be fixed with mods)-Companion system is bland.

The Mojave Wasteland isn't as interesting as the D.C. Wasteland in Fallout 3, but it still gives you a good Fallout experience. Excellent Gameplay, but the Gunplay is pretty boring without mods. 2. A very extensive modding community. Which add's replayability.3. It's mostly made by the creators of Fallout 1 & 2 (Both great games)4. Has a lot of side quests. Unlike Fallout 3.5. Has ironsights on weapons. Unlike Fallout 3.Con's1. You will crash a lot due to the old engine, but you can fix the problem's in 10 minutes or so.2. Annoying stutters, but also can be fixed quickly.3. A f*ck ton of bugs and yet again can be fixed with modssssssssssssssssssssssssssss...In conclusion it's a lot better than Fallout 3 or 4, so currently it's probably the best Fallout game ever made. EDIT: Forgot to mention, mods are very easy to install.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												I waited on rating NV until after I played Fallout 4. I really hoped it wouldn't come to this, but I felt mildly disappointed with 4. After spending around 70ish hours on 4, I went back and played NV. Now I have to say that NV is one of the best fallout games out there. 4 wasn't terrible, it was actually pretty good. It just lacked the genuine "Fallout" feel. No karma system, no weapon condition and only 4 vague dialogue options.. If you're wondering why I mention Fallout 4 so much, is because I just want to make a comparison. NV contains those genuine elements which make the game interesting and full of various choices, whereas FO4 removes most of them, making the game much more dull and not as fun to play. To those who want to play a classic fallout game with those [amazing] elements, NV should probably be close to the top of your list.

												One of the greatest RPGs of all time. Incredibly expansive, rich, and rewarding, with no cheap content to be seen. Arguably the best addition to the Fallout franchise, taking place in a truly believable post-apocalyptic world with equally believable factions and characters, almost all of which are presented in one shade of gray or another. Ambiguous morality is perfected here and coupled with an unparalleled emphasis on player freedom; presented through a nearly endless supply of highly complex quests that constantly change the Mojave Wasteland. New Vegas is the standard all RPGs should strive to achieve. It is destined to be remembered as a classic and a masterpiece for it is truly without equal.Welcome to Vegas. New Vegas. Enjoy your stay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Howdy, pardner! Let's get riiight on with it. Yeehaw!THE POSITIVES:+A well-realized world: The way the environmental storytelling adds to the immersion, stories, and overall feel of the game world never bores me. Hell, I'd bet it'd not bore anyone. There are so many factions each with their own interesting take on the world and philosophy. There are so many quests for all kinds of gamers. There is much to learn about the world and use it in a meaninful way to achieve things.+a unique and interesting plot: You are a Courier who was shot in the head during a high-priority delivery. You made it out alive, quite amazingly. Now you are all set to find the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who shot you between the eyes. Essentially, you're a kick♥♥♥♥♥mailman with a vendetta. Will you "deliver" your vengeance to the person it's addressed to?The plot might seem simple but the plot points and events that connect the plot together are amazing in that they offer a variety of outcomes and variety in actions achieving said outcomes. Plus, from a purely writing stand-point, the plot has many surprises and engaging events. Best of all, you made them happen. In essence, the plot goes from being simple to amazingly complex - all because of your actions.+amazing characters that feel real: Each guy you encounter feels different. They don't feel like sacks of exposition and cliches. Their needs, their wants, their actions, their inactions, their beliefs,  all are things that compel us to take action that affects them in some way. What way they're affected, depends on your own opinion and subsequent actions on such people, which can make for some tense, funny, creative, serious, and sometimes just WTF situations and outcomes.All in all, the writing coupled with the gameplay creates an amazing world with rich characters that make us feel part of this interesting world and feel proud and awesome while feeling so. +Gameplay: The perks, the skills, the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system are familiar (but nonetheless awesome) territories, and the game, as a set of rules trying to create a challenge, is good.But the star of the show is the amazing variety in player-influenced situations and outcomes that encompass most of New Vegas. During each mission, you're given an objective. The way you complete that objective is upto you, and the best part is, you don't even know what ALL the things there are that can be done in a certain scenario. You have to stick your nose in others' businesses, pry and fiddle with things and people until you surprise even yourself by the amazing things you didn't know you could do to resolve/achieve/prevent/worsen such scenarios.Also, there's the gunplay - which is okay for a game like this. This game is trying to be an rpg (and kicking♥♥♥♥♥at it) and not an action-y shoot 'em up. For all intents and purposes, the gunplay is good enough. It can even improve if time is put into it. It works in this game well enough. For example, there are some cool emergent scenarios but they're all mostly encounters with different enemies. But they still feel different because you're not the same guy each time you face them. You're more experienced with guns and can almost always land a proper shot by the time you're 25% into the game. It's only a one-way uphill ride from there.Plus a lot of perks are useful, but also, a lot of them are straight up cool. I won't spoil as surprise is key in New Vegas.Too sum up the positives; This game is one of the best combinations of gameplay and writing I have seen in quite some time. It's like being spawned in a random, but real and challenging world full of opportunites worth investing time and money into.NEGATIVES:Maybe I'm too early into the game to fully detail the shortcomings of this amazing game, but as of writing this I've spent 9 HOURS( plus 40 or so hours outside Steam long time ago) and I've seen my share of them:-Glitches. They are not game-breaking. Hell no. But sometimes you'll see a random merchant from another town sitting on plain air in the middle of the road saying "Howdy" like he has no idea where he is. Sometimes, it can cause certain events to not happen, or to not happen in time, or to not happen because you didn't so something which it isn't your fault. When I quit the game, I was already experiencing another minor glitch where all NPCs and player just sort of jump in and out of the ground like the ground itself was going up and down.These glitches took up 0.000000001% of my total playtime though. so I guess no biggie. But some people out there might have their immersion broken. -This is, for the most part, not an aesthetically pleasing game. I say this as I have seen visual-minded people all over the interwebs and just my immediate surroundings.  And I'm speaking not just from a photorealistic point of view but also from an artistic one. The choice of color palette, the colors you'll see in the entire game, are, for the most part, dull. I know it's the end of the world, but some color is always appreciated in a bleak world. But you can change that with MODS. Which I'm sure will only improve your experience.And as I sit here thinking of another flaw, I am out of ideas. I cannot honestly list a real flaw that really affected my playthrough.I'll probably update my review if I come across more flaws. No movie is without sins. Why not games?But I've enjoyed all the hours I've put into the game so far, with occasional hiccups here and there.Obsidian has created a gem. Perhaps an overlooked one. Bethesda could really learn some lessons here (particularly in the writing department)Thus far. my rating for Fallout: New Vegas is 9.5/10.Happy Trails, pardner!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Fallout : New Vegas epitomizes what a 3D, action-oriented Fallout game should be. From the gameplay systems to the visuals and story. Fallout : New Vegas nails it perfectly on the head the feeling of playing the Original games made by Interplay in a First Person RPG setting. Bethesda could learn a thing or two from Obsidian's execution on New Vegas moving forward and it really makes you wish that Bethesda lets Obsidian develop another Fallout game.Graphics : 7/10The Graphics in the game while they aren't exactly the pinnacle of last gen's graphics but they take advantage of the setting of the game to really draw your attention away from some shaky textures or color theme. Character models still definitely felt rather outdated even for the time but that can partially be attributed to the Gamebryo engine that Bethesda provided to develop the game in. However for the shortcomings of the character models are more than made up in the diversity and quality of clothing and armor models which you will be seeing more often than your character's face.Setting : 10/10Fallout : New Vegas really optimizes what a Fallout game should look like given the time gap that we see between Fallout 2 and New Vegas in the Western territories. Due to a lack of government it allows Obsidian to present us a great Post-Apocalyptic portrayal of an "Old West" style game. The zones in game feel varied, especially if you have the DLCs installed. New Vegas could have been more impressive if console limitations didn't hold it back from being completely open but that's negligible. As for the DLC's the setting really just sets the tone perfectly for what they are about. Honest Hearts feels varied enough from the Mojave to make it feel fresh, same can be said for Old World Blues. Blood Money is a refreshing chance of scenery taking place in an almost untouched Casino and Lonesome Road takes us back to the Mojave feel we have grown used to.Gameplay : 10/10This is where I feel like New Vegas shines over every other Fallout game period. It keeps the skill system we all have grown to expect from a Fallout game that was disappointingly absent from Fallout 4. But let's stay on track. Some skills were condensed in order to bring in other systems that really add more depth to not only roleplaying but giving different avenues to play the game. Survival is a welcome addition to the game as it gives the player character more avenues to explore and really lends itself to Hardcore mode. The change to giving a player a perk every 2 levels and the addition of challenge perks lets the player choose more "interesting" perks that change gameplay opposed to just increasing damage by x%. Going back to Hardcore mode, it hones in on the games core... it's a Post-Apocalyptic Survival RPG and it is very well implemented it definitely changes the way you approach the game. The gunplay definitely feels improved over Fallout 3, and is actually tolerable if you invest points into the respective skill and the addition of true iron sights really makes the gunplay feel better aiming downsights as well as firing from the hip. Lastly the skill system really comes in true more in this game than in Fallout 3, every skill you have can allow you to bypass combat... find new avenues to complete quests and you have the option to play the game VERY diplomatically. If you want to avoid combat you can, and that adds volumes of replayability to the game.Story : 9/10The Story in New Vegas takes a step back and emphasizes exactly the lesson Fallout tries to express in every game. War never changes. In New Vegas you take on the Role of a Package Courier in the employ of the Mojave Express delivering a Platinum Chip to a one Mr. House the proprietor of the Lucky 38 and the big man behind the New Vegas strip. Now the story here begins with you getting shot in the head by a man named Benny and it leads you on a quest to find the man who killed you and grows in scope from there.Now the story here I feel is much better developed than in Fallout 3, from the Main Quest, to the side quests, to the companion quests. The main story takes you all the way across the Mojave Wasteland introducing you to the game's major factions (Which play a huge role in the second half of the story) gradually. This definitely helps establish an overall narrative which culminates later during the second battle for Hoover Dam and who you decide to assist significantly influences your route through the game, as a Fallout game has always been about the Journey and not the destination. The factions are well fleshed out and each faction (even the not story relevant ones) feel like they belong in the world and have some purpose in the world as almost every action you perform has a direct repercussion on how the factions perceive you. Examples being if you are a friend of the NCR (New California Republic) and the Legion detests you, because the NCR likes you they will give you a communicator that will dispatch a troop of NCR Rangers to assist when you use the time.... on the flip side there is direct consequence to some of the factions hating you; like in the example above. If the Legion were to hate you they would send out hit squads to kill you, which creates a nice dynamic for random events occurring... such as NCR and Legion teams fighting eachother.DLC - 9/10New Vegas is shining example of how to do DLC right. None of them feel like tacked on content (We're talking about major DLCs not small packs like Gunrunner's Arsenal) much like Operation : Anchorage or even Broken Steel felt like in Fallout 3. Not to mention Fallout : New Vegas granted us with one of the best DLC story arcs in gaming history as they are all tied in one way or another to each other and the story as a whole.Old World Blues is in my opinion the second best DLC available, but is not to be discounted. It is a nice lighthearted step away from the gritty seriousness that is the main story line, playing off 50s Science Fiction featuring some absolutely hilarious characters like Dr. 0 and Dr. Mobius. It also serves to introduce us to 2 characters that would appear later other DLC's if you go out of the way to try and find them. Honest Hearts takes us away from the Mojave and puts us straight into Zion National Park which is a welcomed change of scenery as it feels more like a vacation in the first place. This DLC introduces us to a character only previously mentioned in the main game, Joshua Graham and tells us his story after the events of the first battle of Hoover Dam, and gives us some more development on a character that would appear later.Blood Money is a change of pace; how welcome that change of pace is really depends on if you enjoy stealth missions and a shake-up of the game's mechanics. Regardless this DLC introduces us to Father Elijah who you can hear about and catch references to in not only the main game from Veronica and the Brotherhood of Steel but in Old World Blues. This DLC takes you on a stealth style mission to rob the previously unopened Sierra Madre casino and uncover it's old world secrets. It's solid but if you like it really depends if you enjoy stealth gameplay.Lastly we have the final DLC chapter; Lonesome Road which not only has a great story and ends the DLC storyline beautifully but we uncover ED-E's backstory and really changes at some level how you see the lovable little robot, and introduces us to a character that has been hinted at in the main game and the previous DLC. Ulysses, this is a very philosophical approach to telling the story of the game and creates an almost introspective narrative that really lends itself well to the hard waste of The Divide and is by far my favorite DLC of the bunch.Final Verdict : 9.5/10While Fallout : New Vegas is by no means a perfect game, it is however what I would consider a true game to Fallout's roots and provides hours of enjoyment.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												A fun and frothy experience best coupled with a tall glass of your favorite champaign, and a bowl dead fish stuff.  "Fallout: New Vegas" Is no doubt, an exquisite entertaining digital experience that will leave you satisfied, and yet, will you thirsty for more like a lowlife drunken mongrel who would sell his own mother for just a small sip of alcohol. Of course you withold such pleasures from the desprate man so that he may squirm and shiver for your own entertainment, and with his last bit of strength you promise him he could have the whole bottle if he would just get up do a little jig. Then you sit there, drinking his booze and laughing at him proclaiming "dance, little man dance!" Hahaha. Yes. Quite so. There is no doubt that "Fallout: New Vegas" is a standout amongst it's peers. Though never quite acheiving the sublimity of it's predecessor "Fallout 3", It is still remains  devilishly good fun. By jove, nothing beats the look on the face of unsuspecting passerby as you unceremonously rob him of all he posesses, and then stab him right in the back. Of course there are a number of unsavory mutant types roaming the world. Even the thought of them makes me shiver with terror. But they can be useful in pinch, believe you me, when there is a job that needs doing, a mutant or a raider will get the job done better then anyone else. Or at least good enough. Oh and then there is the music. Simplicity itself. Frank Sinatra would be proud to hear the roaring sounds of Vegas, that once paradice on earth, blasting from the spearks of your personal computer as you blow away yet another unsuspecting innocent with a rocket launcher. Well that's all I have to leave you with for now, dear reader. Enjoy your new digital experience, and remember during those moments of village onslaught, or wandering into some dangerous unknown area with strange green men who own big guns, there is always the load function to start over. Pleasant voyage friend.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Ain't That A Kick In The HeadWhere do i begin i adore Fallout New Vegas i used to play it on the Xbox 360 and each day i would come back from school and play it until i have to go to sleep, then i got this game on my PC now in reality i have put more time into Fallout New Vegas than any other game but enougth of that lets talk about the game shall we. Fallout New Vegas is set around the old ruins of Las Vegas, the Mojave Desert to be exact, kind of a western cowboy feel now, you can also say that the Wild West meets Fallout for the first time, the are many new factions now such as the NCR, Legion, Powder Gangers and even some old ones return such as the Brotherhood Of Steeal or The Enclave, Remnents to be clear.Some of you may ask is this any better than Fallout 3, and my answer is HELL YES! There are many new and better features in New Vegas than in Fallout 3, such as the reputation system, and many more, also you can chose who to side with at the end of the game, there is alot of choices that will appear in your ending. There is also many amazing and fun quests that it would be hard to do them all in a single play through. The DLC adds many more hours of fun although it is quite varied in flavour and in value, but all of them are worth playing at least once.But then there are also mods. Falllout New Vegas has over 15K mods now that is alot but the thing about it is it goes from Weapons to Armour to hell even a 8 hour long quest mod. You will spend hours upon hours modding your game with new armors, weapons and playing new quests.If you want an amazing quest mod that will give you tons of giggles and laughs, then check out The Christmas Special Quest Mod.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/54511/?---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out Gopher's New Vegas Mod Clinic if you want tutorials on how to install certain mods.


YouTube™ Video: Fallout New Vegas Mod Clinic - Part 1 (REVISED) : Stutter Remover 

			Views: 217,747		

			Mods covered in this video: 1: New Vegas Stutter Remover : http://www.newvegasnexus.com/downloads/file.php?id=34832 IMPORTANT: This mod requires NVSE (nvse.silverlock.org).		

Is Fallout New Vegas worth buying? = Absolutely it is the best FPS & RPG shooter game to date. Oh and one more thing if you say that the game is not worth getting because the graphics suck then dont worry there are ENBs, retextures and a ton of new content which make your game look like it was made in 2015 have fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Undoubtably one of my favorite games. You cant go wrong buying it. At any price it would have been worth my money. The Fallout games always have a strongly immersive enviornment that really grabs you and pulls you into the game. The soundtrack, NPC detail, and substance in the world all contribute to this. NPC's have personality; NPCs act acording to their peronality and the post apocolyptic envionment that surrounds them. The soundtrack (radio songs) give the game an "Old Western" type feel that goes great with the chaos and disorder of the world. They also make the world feel somewhat eerie and desolat; wandering the wasteland, everythings quiet, something could pop out and eat you alive at any moment and your listening to Jingle Jangle. It's a good contrast between sunch a "fun" song and a dark enviornment. The songs definently end up growing on you. Every corrner has a secret behind it. The world is full of mystery and curiosity. You can wander in some abondoned building only to discover it ihabited by the hostile robots who once used to work there or find some cave at the bottom of an ocean. The more unfamiliar the world is, the more lost you feel, the more exciting the game is. Mods add even more too the game, adding more immersion, longevity, and options. Some mods might be immersion breaking, I wouldnt recomend those. The game runs stable on most machines I would assume. The quests will never leave you unentertained as they are numorous and almost never "go fetch this" of "find this dude." The DLC adds hours and hours of playtime so I highly recomend you buy the Ultimate Edition. The DLC is unique, adds characters, story, weapons, items, quests. Each of them are like mini-main story lines, heir more than side quests. The Fallout series is just too great. I hope 4 will be as good as this one. War, war never changes

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I actually have much more hours but on another version (non Steam version)... just re-bought it and replaying it...oh man. EPIC GAME! Fallout New Vegas is second favorite game of all time. Fallout 3 is my top best.The New Vegas storyline hearkens back to Fallout 1 and 2 which isn’t surprising given that Oblivion is holding the reins again and here is where I fess up to having never played the first two. I had to do a bit of Wiki-ing (which always leads to me reading waaaay too much about Eleanor of Aquitaine – call it Wikigressing) to understand what was going on and I still don’t really get the part about Hoover Dam. Anyway. I’ll have to leave the majority of comparisons between the first two Fallouts and this one to those who’ve played all the games but I will say I was impressed with how seamlessly Oblivion’s New Vegas integrated the Fallout 3 experience – especially The V.A.T.S. system, morally polarizing quests, and somewhat unreliable yet still tantalizing map markers.I know the graphics are very 2001 and the endless running though the wasteland should bore the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of some but it doesn’t and here’s why: The base level of difficulty in New Vegas is hard. Like dying every 15 minutes hard. This is a twenty hour campaign which could easily turn into a nine hundred hour campaign based on the hordes of irradiated critters ALONE. I wish I could explain why this is good rather than annoying and maybe it’s a mixture of nostalgia, the Mister Vegas radio program, and Snuffy the Mole Rat but instead of falling asleep in my sarsparilla I find it soothing.I also find shooting a chem fiend in the face with a sawed off shotgun soothing so take that with a grain of salt.  This is a classic my friends. Don't miss out.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really love the Fallout series and I have heard from a lot of people that New Vegas was their favorite entry into the collection, and I can definitely see why. Fallout New Vegas takes everything that was great from Fallout 3 and improves upon it. There's a different kind of karma meter, instead now you have fame for each group or town and depending on what you do for or to those people, they will like you more or less, and you'll get better rewards or hunted by mercenaries depending on which extreme you go to. Gameplay is pretty great, they introduced ammo types, so in addition to using different guns you can now use different ammunition depending on the enemy you're fighting. If you're looking at getting this, I would recommend the ultimate edition or whatever they called it, it has all of the DLC, and the DLC in New Vegas is amazing. Same as with Fallout 3, modding is a huge part of this game now and it's easy to understand why. You can add chracters, change the way people look, the way your weapons look, and apply unofficial patches to help with game stability. The modding community for this game isn't as large as say Skyrim, but it's still pretty impressive with all the different ways you can modify the game. Some have said this is the best Fallout game in the franchise, so if you're looking at getting this, go for it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Thoroughly from start to finish. One of the most fully realized and most weel thought out settings in fiction. Any question you have about the culture, daily lives, or townsfolk of New vegas and the outlying areas will more than likely be answered.Pros:-Great writing-usually Great Voicework-Solid engine-Deep character building, unlike some open world rpgs i could mentions (Cough Cough Skyrim)-Game world feels like just the right size. big enough to feel daunting and massive, but no so much so that hiking from one side of the map to the other ever seems outright impossible.-Sweet mother of mods, Batman! Project Nevada is a must, NMC's texture pack to fix those blurry textures, and whatever ENB fits your preferences and the game instantly gets a hell of a lot better that just "Great." Thats not to mention mods for bounty hunting, new quests, a survival system, new lands to discover, and a lot more. Cons-Scenery is a bit repetitive. I know its the apocalypse and I know that its in central Nevada, but holy crap do the endless orange deserts and brown praeries ever get boring. There are a few spots that change it up a bit, but they are far and few between and usually out of the way of your usual walking. -The City of New Vegas is underwhelming. After all the buildup throughout the game that makes out Vegas to be some sort of seedy haven from the harshness of the wasteland, when you finally get there, vegas is remarkably dirty and destroyed looking. This is probably the only part of the plot/setting that I can take any fault with, and I'm aware it's as petty as can be. Im my mind, Vegas should be in perfect condition at all times. Its undoubtedly the largest population center in Nevada, and probably one of the largest in Fallout's America, and should undoubtedly be the most decadent and beautiful. For some reason though, Vegas is in nearly the same state of disrepair as any other town in the wasteland. Given that House has literally an entire army of free labor at his disposal, you would think Vegas and The Strip wouldn't look like a total wreck, and yet it does. Not helping this is that Vegas feels incredibly small, with only around 10 or so buildings that you'll really be visiting frequently. A minor gripe, but one of the most curious setting quirks in the game.-Matthew Perry is a wet napkin in this game. Seriously, he sounds like he's completely stoned, has a cold, and is literally phoning in his lines. This is pretty unfortunate given that he's one of the main antagonists of the game. Overall, should you play Fallout: New Vegas? Yes, and heres hoping that Fallout 4 takes more after this game than Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												Fallout 3, while not the most played game in my library, enveloped a deeply rooted love of RPG essence that engulfed my love of Role-Playing/ Open-World games once again. This spinoff Fallout game developed by Obsidian, sparked an ephemeral love of Fallout 3 back to life because of the immersion that it encompasses. Self-proclaimed Intrepids can really get lost in this game.Fallout: New Vegas delivers on the open world experience because of the riveting desert, mountainous terrains. From the rural, isolated and rustic towns to the grand strip of Vegas. From the intimidating tribes to the amicable town-goers comes an immersive setting that grips convivial and intimidating variables to the game that really engages the player to think about their decisions. The apocalyptic setting leaves the player to roam aorund to unearth secrets, locations, expansive quests and hidden incentives to really pleasure the player for the price that they get this game at. The story arc of New Vegas does have a lot less of memorable moments from its predecessor: Fallout 3. Nevertheless, the main tale provides a solid plot from which to hang a  number of tasks and stand-alone parables. Many of these quests are quite lengthy, and great dialogue and good voice acting will engage you to learn more about the characters, as well as keep you elated about what will happen next. The choices you make might lead to a dramatically different experience from another player's experience. The same is true of many supplementary quests. There's a ton of flexibility in how you might approach certain tasks. which can lead to a state of quandary or a state of serenity.The many different personalities can circumvent your own morality, whether it be trust a shifty character or betray a benevolent character. An illusive computer program-man, who presides in the New Vegas strip, focuses is entirely on himself and his robots to alter your experience in the strip either negatively or positively. The leader of a Roman-inspired legion is also an illustrious presence and a violent opposite to the upright and learned leader of the Brotherhood of Steel's local contingent. The player can even find an interesting kindred spirit to accompany you. As with Fallout 3, you can bring a companion along with you; this is handy not only in combat, but it also gives you an extra inventory for dumping detritus. Interacting with your companion is simple, thanks to a wheel that lets you choose behaviors for your fellow traveler. You can only have one at a time, but you'll encounter multiple individuals willing to join you, and they all make interesting and funny quips when you interact with them. They also reveal different quest opportunities, giving you a chance to learn more about what makes them, well them.Fallout: New Vegas is an expansive and sometimes abstruse RPG that encourages you to see and do as much as you can. This is an explorer's game, always lavishing new and interesting quests on you and giving you a lot of flexibility in how you approach many of them. It builds upon Fallout 3's mechanics in interesting and enigmatic ways, making it a comfortable advancement to one of the best games RPG Games. Fallout: New Vegas is periodically awesome and often compelling. If you crave an expansive and branching adventure in which your choices matter, this is one game that will deliver. I rate this game a 8.75/10 and recommend to anyone that has played Skyrim, Fallout 3 or any other RPG's from Bethesda, aswell as advocates of open world games.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I am an avid role player myself, assuming she is a nurse and I am a naughty patient. But in real life (otherwise known as video games to me) I have trouble with the concept. I find myself following the pretty arrows a lot rather than creating my own adventure. Then again, I can’t be alone because otherwise they wouldn’t even god damn be there. So in Fallout New Vegas I woke up and was told I might have brain damage. Well good job, game over; it’s hard to save the world when you have a seizure every ten minutes. But I was told by the good people of tutorial village that I should pursue more danger. Well, the glowing arrow meant I couldn’t disagree and so I set out into the Mohave Desert. In usual Sylvester Stallone/Bruce Willis/Arnold Schwarzenegger style (choose your own bloody action hero) I got into trouble and was forced to shoot desperadoes to achieve a meaningless ending. Meaningless in the sense that the story just ends, you spawn back in the world and no one has any idea of the events that took place.Maybe it is just me, but I can’t actually role play in a story that’s already been created and decided. I know it’s several decades before we have more open-ended games but others have been able to hide the closed-endedness (shut up, it’s a word now). New Vegas brought in a new hardcore mode which supplements survival into the mix. You have to eat, drink and sleep to stay alive. I have yet to try this mode, but I can assure you, like always, mods will make it better. So go buy this game and leave me alone. I’ve played it many times and I have better things to do than tend to your need for reassurance and laughter. I have my brain damage seizures and a dog for that.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												A direct sequel to Fallout and Fallout 2 that incorporates many elements from the originally cancelled Fallout 3 (Van Buren), New Vegas shines as a truly ambitious and rewarding RPG where reactivity to the player's actions can be seen in direct and subtle ways. The richness of the Mojave Wasteland's logical consistency and characterisation makes one completely absorbed in the world, where politics, corruption, idealogical clashes and the consequences of war make F:NV considerably more intelligent and thought out than many games out there.Thankfully the final patches to the title have amended the glaring bugs present in the vanilla release, and with a fantastic collection of DLC that expands on the universe's rich canon, one won't easily forget the fantastic side stories such as Randall Clark's trials and tribulations as a lone survivor in Zion National Park, Christine Royce's pursual of Father Elijah from Big Mountain through to the Sierra Madre, meeting the legendary "Burned Man" Joshua Graham, and ultimately, the player character being hunted down by Ulysses, the original "Courier Six", and uncovering his motivations for doing so. As a side note, I was honoured to have interviewed staff at Obsidian and Bethesda discussing their insights on the development of the game, with links available here:- JE Sawyer - Fallout New Vegas lead designer and Honest Hearts DLC director[www.gamasutra.com]- Chris Avellone - Part 1 - Obsidian creative lead and Fallout New Vegas DLC director[www.gamasutra.com]- Chris Avellone - Part 2[www.gamasutra.com]- Chris Avellone - Part 3[www.gamasutra.com]- Jason Bergman - Bethesda producer[www.gamasutra.com]- Tim Cain - the Father of Fallout[www.gamasutra.com]- The Fallout From Fallout 3 - an analysis of the cancellation of Van Buren through to Bethesda's Fallout 3, and what happened next[willooi.com]

												Fallout New Vegas is a game I love a lot. It's a fantastic blend of story telling, fps and rpg elements all mixed in with the classic Fallout post nuclear waste land and bizarre humour.I would highly recommend that anyone who has not played this gem should. You will have a lot of fun and unlike the previous games the story line with the abhorrent slavers Caesar's Legion vs the quasi capitalist, democratic NCR gives you two very different 'protagonists' to fight for with radically different societies and philosophies.All of the DLC you will get has great value (well the gun runners weapons and ammos are a bit iffy) but the 4 main expansions add serious additional content to the game with huge new areas and plots from the Tribals in Xion Valley to the crazy disembodied scientist brains at the Big Empties Think Tank.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I actually have much more hours but on another version (non Steam version)... just re-bought it and replaying it...oh man. EPIC GAME! Fallout New Vegas is second favorite game of all time. Fallout 3 is my top best.The New Vegas storyline hearkens back to Fallout 1 and 2 which isn’t surprising given that Oblivion is holding the reins again and here is where I fess up to having never played the first two. I had to do a bit of Wiki-ing (which always leads to me reading waaaay too much about Eleanor of Aquitaine – call it Wikigressing) to understand what was going on and I still don’t really get the part about Hoover Dam. Anyway. I’ll have to leave the majority of comparisons between the first two Fallouts and this one to those who’ve played all the games but I will say I was impressed with how seamlessly Oblivion’s New Vegas integrated the Fallout 3 experience – especially The V.A.T.S. system, morally polarizing quests, and somewhat unreliable yet still tantalizing map markers.I know the graphics are very 2001 and the endless running though the wasteland should bore the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of some but it doesn’t and here’s why: The base level of difficulty in New Vegas is hard. Like dying every 15 minutes hard. This is a twenty hour campaign which could easily turn into a nine hundred hour campaign based on the hordes of irradiated critters ALONE. I wish I could explain why this is good rather than annoying and maybe it’s a mixture of nostalgia, the Mister Vegas radio program, and Snuffy the Mole Rat but instead of falling asleep in my sarsparilla I find it soothing.I also find shooting a chem fiend in the face with a sawed off shotgun soothing so take that with a grain of salt.  This is a classic my friends. Don't miss out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												It's not as atmospheric as Fallout 3, nor is the story any better than Fallout 3, what you hear from the New Vegas fanboys are just a bunch of idiots following the band wagon. I remember when Fallout 3 was out, everyone was praising it, and then came New Vegas, and all of a sudden everyone started hating on Fallout 3 out of nowhere.Anyway, back to the purpose of the review, the gameplay is quite solid, the ironsights could use a little work. The game also has a hardcore mode which I would recommend for realism/immersion purposes (required to eat/drink/sleep to survive). The companion system is much nicer here than it is in Fallout 3, you're given more choices with them and some companions have their own little quest which tells you a little bit about their background. My favorite part of the game would be the faction system, although it's a bit silly that killing a few of their faction members would make you villified amongst their entire faction, even if you manage to kill all the witnesses, but on the bright side you can suit on one of the faction's uniforms to disguise yourself as one of their own.  What faction you choose to side with determines the outcome of the ending, or if you don't want to align yourself with a faction, you're given the choice to be your own faction in a certain point of the story. This entire review so far has been centered around the base game, if the base game is good, the game is good, unlike Skyrim where people say the mods make it good which sounds ridiculous in my opinion. I would recommend playing the base game before spoiling yourself with mods. Trust me, with the replayability of this game, you'll have no trouble going back from the start and playing all over again.If you're looking for mods after finishing the base game as I suggest you doing, I would recommend these mods, so write them down on a notepad or something:1. Project Nevada (not recommended for casual players)2. ELECTRO CITY3. iHud (for those hardcore immersion players)4. RH_Ironsights (I know the game has ironsights by default, but this mod slightly tweaks some weapons)5. Improved Sound FX (makes gun sound like they actually do damage)6. Populated Casino (ever wonder how the casinos make so much money if only two people are standing around gambling?)7. Fellout (makes the nights MUCH darker, it's a little strange how enemies can't see you with high sneak when you're right at their face in a blue night that isn't even dark, can be buggy at times)8. F O O K [no spaces, Steam censors the spelling of this mod by default] (this mod used to be huge for Fallout 3, but it's not quite as popular in New Vegas, adds new weapons and armor and other content, don't remember the details)

												This is one of the best open ended action rpgs. The world is very well designed, having little set pieces such as a camp over run by over sized bugs. The game never directly references it and you have to find it but it adds depth to the world most other games like this (Even Fallout 3) fail at. It has a cast of characters that are pretty good though it has a lot of reused voices. The multiple endings and senerios based on your actions make this game very replayable as you actions have active effects on the world(like enermy spawns faction ownership and so on. The game also manages to make you start as someone who is very unimportant to the man who shapes the world and people react to you based on your actions.I strongly recommend this game and no I do not play with mods other then one that adds music.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												A sequal to the masterpiece, Fallout 3. This game feels more like your playing a modded version of FO3, but that is because this game uses the same game engine as FO3. Though this game improves off of what Fallout 3 did not have. This game has fun gameplay. You travel the wasteland as a Courier who cheated death when shot in the head attempting to deliver a Platinum Chip, something that has a secret behind it. The story is more badass than FO3. The game is surrounded by choice. Say you were attacking a base you could take a couple different routes which would lead up to something different than the other. There are factions in the game that you can join and each is different than the other. Each unique. There are tons and I mean TONS, of weapons. Each unique in it's own special way. There is also ton of gore in this game. Heads explode, spines go flying out, eyes balls fly. Though you may just asking is the game any good? Yes it is. And it is a hell of a lot of fun. 9.2

												I remember drooling at the mouth when I heard that Fallout: NV was in development.  This game is very much like Fallout 3, which I also played endlessly, in that its an open world experience with tons of content to offer.  For those who like to roleplay you'll find a ton of material to work with to craft your character and create your own story the way you want.  The modding scene was never as popular as Fallout 3 and certainly not anywhere as heavy as the Elder Scrolls series.  Regardless, FO:NV has a lot to offer and is well worth any RPG fan's attention.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Fallout: New Vegas feels very much like the Fallout 3. The main thing that felt different were the different factions that determined the narrative for the game. I checked out a couple of the endings and they had really different feelings to each other. Other than that it’s still just good old Fallout 3 action. You’ll definitely enjoy it as much and maybe even more depending on which style you like more: East or West America. I just jogged around with my hunting rifle and kept raiders hugging the ground. That’s a good gaming afternoon to me. Dialogue was interesting and felt like coming from real people. I enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												You should play Fallout: New Vegas. Before buying the Ultimate Edition on Steam, I played over 150 hours on the base game for Xbox. From the first time I walked out of the doctor's office and into Goodsprings, listening to Dean Martin on Radio New Vegas, the atmosphere and attitude of this game hooked me. The clever humor, fun perks, and the variety of characters you meet in your travels through the wasteland make for an engrossing and entertaining adventure. When describing Fallout to friends new to the series, I often describe it as similar to an Elder Scrolls game set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Obviously, there are key differences in gameplay, atmosphere, and mechanics, but they are alike in their near-perfection of the single player RPG. Few single player games come close to matching the depth of either series and even fewer have held such a dedicated and fanatical following. Just check the number of mods available on nexusmods.com (and the fact that new mods are put out nearly every day) and you will get an idea of how people feel about this game. Some people like Fallout 3 better than New Vegas; some people point to the fact that Obsidian developed NV while Bethesda developed Fallout 3 and the modern Elder Scrolls games as evidence that New Vegas a farmed-out product of lesser quality. While there is no accounting for taste, I prefer New Vegas to Fallout 3 because I love the music and old-west atmosphere of New Vegas. While the game is great without mods, I must say that even after 150 hours on the vanilla game, playing again with dozens of mods and all the expansions on PC is close to a totally different experience. Project Nevada, NMC's texture pack, Weapon Mods Expanded (to name a few of the best) really make New Vegas feel at home on PC as a platform and add a level of challenge and scrappiness that should please any Fallout veteran who may find the basic mode lacking in difficulty.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2012
												Okay, so picture this: A bear and a rabbit are pooping the woods. The bear tries to pickpocket the rabbit but fails and his hand gets covered in doo-doo. Well, the rabbit is angry, so he uses VATS to freeze time, and shove the bear's doo-doo covered hand in his face. The bear then screams "POOPIE IN MY FACE" and runs away. That's pretty much what this game is. War. War never changes.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I'm not a first person shooter gamer most the time, but I had little trouble playing through this. The gameplay is perfect, there's story EVERYWHERE, and I can always find something to do. Fantastic game. Only complaints is the dialogue is often campy and the voice acting is sometimes unnatural. Biggest complaint though is the AI, which could've used work. Still totally worth buying though just for the hndereds of hours of content.
